So....I hate the idea of Roguelikes. The concept boggles my mind. When I was a kid, getting your save corrupted on your memory card meant that you would throw your PlayStation 1 out of the window in blind hatred and everyone outside nodded, as they understood your plight very well. Nowadays, losing progress is a feature in games. Even in normal games, saves have been replaces by checkpoints that are placed ever further apart.

Hades, however, at least gives a good reason for that mechanic. You are an immortal, trying to escape the underworld and dying in the underworld just means that you are going to be reborn from the pool at your house. At least, the mechanic makes sense in this context. However, I must say that this format of game is, at its core, still quite unfriendly. 

As you get stronger, you play for longer, as you get further into the levels, but you can't just save your game and go get groceries or go to work, because you will lose all your progress if you do that. Furthermore, on each play-through, you are still forced to go through all the bosses you defeated previously, and your strength often depends on random chance, because the power-ups that become available to you are somewhat random, so you can still die at one of the "easier" bosses if you are not very lucky or sharp. Getting far in the game and then dying, though, makes you lose the will to live, as you realise that you have to do it all over again, including fighting all the previous bosses.

After many attempts, I finally got to the final boss with the right power-ups and brought his liffe bar to the bottom only to see his life bar refill to 100%. I don't know how many lives this boss has, but I think I am now done. Go f*ck yourself, game. Now, additional content does get unlocked after losing to the main boss, so I know this is all by design, but at this point, I am quite done with the game. I just don't have the patience for games that waste my time like this.

Nonetheless, the fighting in this game is fun and the game itself is pretty, so that the gameplay is sufficient enough to make you come back to the game (after you do something else for while, out of frustration). If you have more skill and patience than I, then I bet you will have fun with Hades and will see it through.

I just finished acquiring the Steam achievements for Hades and this is probably the only game where reaching the epilogue of the story takes longer than any other achievement.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

The concept behind the game is simple; you need to get through three levels containing multiple sub-levels. 

Initially you are extremely weak so you derive enjoyment from trying different things to get a bit further each time. Later it becomes easier to get through the levels so you will want to look into trying different weapons and builds. I highly recommend looking up builds as some of them are really cool but unintuitive.

I'm not really emphasising it here but the game has a massive amount of replayability.

[b]Everything Else[/b]

I feel that the absolute main focus of this game is gameplay, everything else was chosen to be cost effective but implemented at the best quality. For exmaple, the graphics have a very simple 2D top down appearance but are beautifully drawn with atmospheric lighting. There are only three levels... but each has a very unique setting and atmosphere. The cutscenes aren't animated, but the voice-acting and character portraits are top tier.

The overall theme is quality over quantity.

[b]Closing Words[/b]

I want to thank the devs for making this awesome game, not only was playing it enjoyable, but arriving during COVID was perfect timing. I will never forget those rainy days working from home and playing Hades in my downtime.
 
It's barely been a couple of years and it already makes me nostalgic.

Actually I spent more than 200 hours playing this game but on another platform. I was willing to buy this game on Steam again and spent another 50 hours on it. I think that's enough to let you know how good this game is. 

As a longtime DOTA player, I can see how much Hades is inspired from the legendary MOBA game. This makes it combat system so diverse and satisfying. There is no useless skill in Hades, and you can even beat the game by dashing only! I mean, you are free to be whoever you want and most of the time you'll not go wrong with your choice. A caster bombarding his enemies with stormy fogs? A sniper who follows the principle of one-shot, one-kill? A martial artist with lighning fast punches? Or an engineer melting even the hardest boss with homing icy laser turrets? Hades will give you all! 

Be the water. Be the storm. Be the light. Be the wind. Be the love. Be the war. Be the chaos. And be ... drunk.

I had no idea what I was getting myself into with Hades, but am I so glad a friend recommended it to me.

The pacing is rapid fire - with the "Just one more run" feeling being stronger here than in any game I can think of for almost a decade.  So frequently, I'd tell myself "Just one more game - it'll be like 10 minutes" which turns into a 40-minute run that *felt* like 10 minutes.

It scratches a very specific itch for me: nonstop action and story optional. That said, the story is clever and actually quite moving, but more than anything I appreciate that the story is *optional*, rather than a bunch of writers jerking themselves off over how hard they had to force the story down the players throats through cut-scenes.

On top of the that, the soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal.

Trully the best Roguelike out there. Outstanding gameplay, story, acting, music and vibe in general. Even though I am not even someone who has ever liked Roguelike games. They are fun to watch on stream, but to actually play them myself, always felt boring. And then I found Hades. The first time I saw this game was back in 2020 when it was nominated for pretty much every game award that exists, and it felt strange to me that a game looking like that is up there with names like The Last of Us Part 2, Ghost of Tsuhima and all the other amazing games from 2020. It really caught my eye but I didn't really feel like I was going to enjoy it so I didn't buy it, until recently when the game was on sale. Turns out I f*cking loved it. Can't remember the last time I had so much fun in a Single-Player video game. It's An Absolute Masterpiece. It has a very unique and special aura around it. As a person who absolutely loves Greek mythology, I was pleasently suprised with how accurate their spin on it was. It would be even more exciting to see all of the gods from Hades return to Hades II, on top of all of the new gods who will undoubtedly be present in a sequal. Imagine getting to build around the powers of like 15 gods, it would be insanely awesome. Either way, I was easily hooked to this franchise and now I'm forced to sit here and watch as the time passes by, waiting for Hades II.

This is my favorite game at the moment. For anyone who takes interest in Greek Myths, I highly recommend this. Regardless of the Greek Myth aspect, the art for the characters in game is outstanding and the gameplay is high quality. The game offers many challenges, and is overall the best game I've played in years.

Let me start by saying this video game is a masterpiece. The music and artwork alone make the game outstanding. The gameplay, story, characters, and voice acting are incredible as well. Combat is satisfying and it's fun to progress through the many layers of Hell on your journey to escape the underworld. The world that the devs created comes together and just flows, especially when you start to talk to the characters more and learn more about their stories.

The game hits all the right notes and was a joy to play. I would recommend it to anyone! 9.5/10. However... there are a few flaws that I would like to point out that I can't get past.

First, the main story does not conclude in a way to me that makes sense. [spoiler]You need to escape 10 times in order to fully complete it, and on run 8 or 9 your mother comments that she is not coming back to the House and will remain on the surface, forever. However, very shortly after she changes her mind, has her bags packed and ready to go, abandons her home on the surface, comes with you to the underworld, everyone cheers, story done. What? This progression of meeting your mother > she refuses to come back to the house > nevermind let's do it was WAY too quick for me. Perhaps I grinded the game too quickly which gave the illusion of this speed, but I can't get past it, even many runs and hours later. It took away from the immersive narrative that I spent so long investing into, only to have this 'oh.... okay' moment at the end. Don't get me wrong, it was a great time and I still fully enjoyed the story. But this part made me think that the ending to this story was rushed. I'm fine with the fairy tale ending of everything working out, but I feel like there could have been a bit more build up or conflict.[/spoiler]

Next, the epilogue is even worse. [spoiler]You spend hours grinding through playthroughs, maxing your bonds with all the gods, performing favours, leveling up etc., only to have your hard-earned epilogue be a voice over narrative with ONE new image depicting Hades and Zeus shaking hands. This, again, did not feel like a proper conclusion to A. the amount of time and effort put into getting to this point and B. the story itself. Once again, there was a huge build up of 'how will we get the Olympians to be okay with this?' and the answer, was just to have a dinner party. Ok! All is forgiven. The entire post-main-story game was spent wondering how will we stop an all out war from happening when the Gods find out the queen has returned, only to have all of them forgive all at once, in a lacklustre cutscene.[/spoiler] I really really love this game but the weak endings to both stories just left me unsatisfied and wanting it to be different.

The last point I want to bring up is the replayability of the game. [spoiler]The four regions and four identical boss fights get old, quick. Even with the slight variation, fighting Meg, then Bone Hydra, then the champion+bull, then Hades is exhausting after a while. I don't want to fight the same bosses every time - the boss fights SHOULD be exciting and rewarding. But sadly, after a while the lack of variation feels repetitive and more like a chore. "Here we go again, hit big snake head, then small snake head, then big snake head....". Knowing exactly what you are going to fight every single run for a boss is tiresome in my opinion.[/spoiler]

I could go on about how the weapons don't have much difference in their aspects, or how the boon system doesn't feel like it impacts your run in a meaningful enough way, or the enemy variety, but the truth is I really enjoyed my time playing this game. I WANT to be able to pour hundreds of hours into it because I love it so much, but due to the above points I really don't see myself continuing to play now that I have most of the achievements done.

I'd like to conclude by saying these are all nitpicky points that I'm making after playing for 50+ hours. I still would recommend anyone to try this game and experience the masterpiece that is Hades. Excellent job Supergiant, I can't wait to see what else you have in store for us in the future.

From the moment I started playing Hades, I was captivated. This game is a masterpiece that seamlessly blends elements of Greek mythology with gameplay mechanics reminiscent of Diablo and World of Warcraft’s Torghast tower in Shadowlands.

The game’s narrative is deeply rooted in Greek mythology, offering a fresh and engaging take on the timeless tales of gods, goddesses, and mythical creatures. The story unfolds as you progress, keeping you hooked and eager to uncover more.

The gameplay is a delightful mix of strategy and action. It’s clear that the developers have taken inspiration from classics like Diablo and World of Warcraft, but Hades stands out with its unique twists and mechanics. The challenges are well-balanced - tough enough to keep you engaged, but not so difficult that they become frustrating.

The graphics are stunning, with a distinctive art style that fits perfectly with the mythological theme. Each level is beautifully designed, and the character models are detailed and expressive.

But what truly sets Hades apart is its replay-ability. Every run is different, every decision matters, and every death is a new beginning. This game will keep you coming back for more, eager to explore every nook and cranny, unlock every secret, and conquer every challenge.

I cannot recommend Hades enough. Whether you’re a fan of Greek mythology, action RPGs, or just good games in general, Hades is a must-play.

Its very fun for a few hours of gameplay. Once you beat the final boss for the first time, it gets extremely grindy for the meta-progress parts (bits of story and slow power increases + unlocks of new playstyles). After an hour post first clear I realized I was gonna need, like 50 more hours of repetition to see everything, and had to go mod the game to fast unlock everything. Its also not quite as "every run is completely different" as some roguelikes; the loot system is impactful, but not as run-warping as games that imo have higher replayability.

Still, the core loop is good for 8-10 hours, and if it really gets your hooks into you I could imagine experimenting with the roguelike loop and trying out builds for a good while longer.

After earning all of [i]Hades[/i] Achievements I am finally ready to review this brilliant game. I had extremely high expectations going into [i]Hades[/i], aside from the game getting a ton of praise this year including multiple relevant GOTY nominations, it's developed by Supergiant Games, the award winning studio that developed [i]Bastion[/i], one of my favorite games of all time. Additionally, the combat and graphical style of [i]Hades[/i] looked similar to [i]Bastion[/i] which really raised my hopes for the game.

[i]Hades[/i] is a roguelike that has quite the expansive story. You play as Zagreus, the son of Hades, and you're trying to escape from the underword through all of your father's undead defenses. You call upon the Olympians for help on your journey and they grant you different skills that make your escape attempts easier, and different than the last. You also have multiple weapons you can choose from which dramatically change how the game is playing. 

Without spoiling anything I'll say there is a ton of content in [i]Hades[/i], the main story took me 20+ hours to complete, and I just finished the epilogue with 100 runs logged. There is so much to do, unlock new weapons, upgrade weapons, build relationships with other characters, unlock new items, upgrade items- even now with around 80 hours of playtime and all achievements earned I don't have all relationships maxed out, weapons fully upgraded, or prophecies fulfilled. 

Furthermore, Supergiant created a modifier to the games difficulty called "heat" which makes runs as challenging as you like far after you've rolled credits. On the reverse side, upgrades through the mirror of darkness and the house contractor will continuously make runs easier until you get to the point where you win every single time unless you're challenging yourself by increase the heat.

Artistically the game is stellar. Each mythological character has been imagined in a new unique style by the Supergiant team, and they all have hundreds of amazing voicelines. Meanwhile, Supergiant has continued its trend of having beautiful music in its games. [i]Bastion[/i] and [i]Transistor[/i] both have countless memorable tracks from Darren Korb and Ashley Barret, and [i]Hades[/i] features some of their most enjoyable music yet. 

I've really enjoyed all my time with this game, it's fun, addicting, and challenging. You can focus on the story and play on god mode with no heat, you can play on high heat and suffer, or you can challenge yourself to squeeze all the content out of the game.

Ultimately, this is the best Supergiant game and easily one of the best games ever. It took everything that [i]Bastion[/i] did right and implemented it into a fast-pace Greek mythology-based roguelike with a ton of well-written, voiced-acted story content with difficulty options that give the title nearly endless replayability. It makes complete sense that [i]Hades[/i] is getting as much praise as it is based on the product, and makes even more based on the price; this game is a steal. I would highly recommend [i]Hades[/i] to anyone.

[b]Necessary Play[/b]

I found out about this game 4 years ago when it was nominated for Game of the Year. This is the game that started my love for rouge-like games as a whole genre, and became one of my top 10 games of all time.This game offers amazing game play for those who want a challange. Great storytelling and diverse characters.  The graphics are truly one of a kind. The voice acting is some of the best I have heard from any game. Darren Korb did an amazing job on the sound track, as he does with any game he does the OST for. There is truly nothing I would ever want to change in this absolute gem of a game. I think it goes without saying, I cannot wait for the second game. Full on 10/10 experience right here.

This game is absolutely amazing from writing, sound design, art, music, voice acting, and gameplay. The characters are all beautifully designed, wonderfully written, and brilliantly voice acted. The entire writing of the game is very amusing and sincere and every character has an amazing personality that fits the character they are representing. 

The story is pretty simple, but because of the nature of the gameplay, it always makes you want to come back for more (especially after you beat Hades). The main story is very simple to keep up with since it progresses for each run you complete. The side stories can happen whenever and all depend on certain things. You'll get special dialogue if you're carrying someone's Keepsake; your relationships with certain characters will deepen depending on how much Nectar/Ambrosia you decide to give them. But there are no requirements to complete any of that, you can beat the main story without doing the rest if you so wish. 

The art style is absolutely incredible and one of the most beautiful ones I've seen in a while. Every character is just so amazingly designed with this distinct art style that it's basically eye candy anytime I interact with them. That even goes to the level design as each level of the Underworlds is just incredibly amazing. What I found interesting about the game is the 2D levels, but the 3D sprites. It really made the visuals pop. 

The gameplay is absolutely amazing. This game (being a roguelike) has so much replay value it's insane. But because there are so many things you can do/complete, you'll want to keep doing runs. There's lots of stuff to collect such as Titan's Blood, Treasure, Darkness, etc. There are 6 different weapons that you can do runs with which makes sure that each replay will be interesting and unique (along with all the boons that you can get that really do effect how you will play the game). Once you complete your first run, you'll get new challenges that will make the game much more interesting to play. However, if you are just here for the story, there is a God Mode that you can turn on so you can solely experience the story, but I think the gameplay is genuinely fun and once you beat your first run, you'll be beating them like crazy. 

The music is on another level. This soundtrack is one of the best and each level has its own theme along with each boss and they all just are *chef's kiss*. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game to someone who's looking for a genuine fun game to play with lots of replayability that will allow you to sink hours into. The eye candy of the visuals and ear candy of the music and SFX are also huge side benefits that will add to the enjoyment of the game.

Simply put, Hades is the flagship of roguelite games. The visuals, the voice acting and the writing is among the best in the whole game industry. On top of that, you get an addictive loop that is well polished and will last for you for dozens of hours.

The only negative thing that comes to my mind are the HW requirements when some parts are quite resource heavy and there are no options to tune the graphics down. For a modern PC, this is no concern, but comparing this game to other from the same genre, this is something to think about.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Hades" is an extraordinary game that seamlessly blends engaging gameplay, captivating storytelling, and stunning visuals into an unforgettable experience. From its dynamic combat system that keeps you on your toes to its richly developed characters and their compelling narratives, every aspect of "Hades" is expertly crafted.

The game's art style is a true feast for the eyes, with its vibrant colors and detailed character designs bringing the world of Greek mythology to life in a way that is both beautiful and evocative. Combined with a phenomenal soundtrack that sets the perfect tone for each encounter, "Hades" creates an immersive experience that is hard to match.

Overall, "Hades" is a masterpiece of game design that deserves all the praise it has received. It's a game that not only entertains but also challenges you to think and strategize, making it a must-play for any fan of action games or Greek mythology.

Smooth & fluid action packed dungeon crawler with good replay value. At it's core Hades is a very simple and "small" game but man oh man, the level of depth in this game is something else. A single successful run won't take more than an hour at best, probably like 20-30 minutes if you're a veteran but the roguelite dungeon romp itself is just half the package.
Death and defeat, while gruesome and bitter at times does not feel all that bad in Hades due to the rather unique story structure that takes full advantage of this core feature of the genre.

Death, instead of signifying a setback will serve as a vessel to advance the story and allows you to explore the characters further. It's not overly complex really but given that the art, writing, voice acting and the overall theme is all neatly packed together and quite high quality makes the "failure" feel like progress - and it is.
I wouldn't quite say you WANT to die at times but it's probably not far off. Part of the enjoyment with Hades is to take a break back at home after you melt in a pool of blood and just chat with people. Witty dialogue and good presentation makes it a very compelling experience.
It's hard to do justice to the writing with a review just telling it's good. I don't want to hype it up to be something extraordinary but it simply does captivate and entertain you in a way you'll rarely experience in games. You can tell that the dev team put a lot of effort to it and it shows.

Gameplay itself feels just right. Combat is simplistic mechanically, but the vast variety of skill & perk combinations coupled with half a dozen of different main weapons makes for quite rich experience. Your typical "easy to learn, hard to master" system done correctly.
Dungeon design is quite structured and rigid, consisting of single rooms you clear in order to advance to next one and the meta dungeon is always the same. Act 2 will always have same environmental hazards and so on. This might seem like a boring and uninspiring design choice but while actually playing, it doesn't feel bland at all. It adds certain consistency to the game world and in the end you'll be more invested in seeking out cool new combos and killing enemies in new fancy ways.

At the time of writing this, I've died 22 times and beat the game twice. Both victories felt like impossible luck giving all the right pieces for a smooth run and I can't imagine to have that all the time even going forward after two actual victories although the permanent upgrades do make things easier alongside the player getting more experienced.
With some 19 hours banked in the game it feels like I'm still midway with the content. There's more story to explore, certain weapons I haven't barely touched at all, basic permanent upgrades are still work in progress not to mention the customizable endgame difficulty setups.

So. Good aesthetics and good gameplay. This is one of those rare diamonds of a game out there and deserves a straight 10/10.

Hades is an extraordinary blend of fast-paced action, compelling storytelling, and rich, detailed world-building, making it stand out as a true masterpiece in the roguelike genre. This game isn't just about battling your way out of the Greek underworld; it's a deeply immersive experience that combines challenging gameplay with a narrative that's as captivating as any epic saga.

The brilliance of Hades lies in its ability to make each run through the ever-changing labyrinths of the underworld feel fresh and exciting. The combat is exhilarating, with a variety of weapons and powers that allow for a wide range of playstyles. The game challenges your skills and reflexes, making every victory feel earned and every setback a chance to learn and adapt.

But what truly sets Hades apart is its narrative and character development. The story unfolds with each attempt to escape, revealing more about the protagonist, Zagreus, and the richly drawn characters he encounters. The voice acting and writing are top-notch, bringing depth and personality to the gods, heroes, and mythical beings of the game.

In conclusion, Hades is a triumph of game design, artfully blending action, story, and strategy. It's a game that's as rewarding as it is challenging, with a depth that keeps you coming back for more. Whether you're a fan of roguelikes or Greek mythology, or just looking for a beautifully crafted gaming experience, Hades is an absolute must-play.

Hades is not just a game; it's a journey through Greek mythology where I die more times than a cat has lives. Zagreus, my determined underworld explorer, is like a Greek Sisyphus, but with cooler hair.

I've faced so many bosses that I'm starting to think the Underworld is hosting its own managerial retreat. But hey, dying is just a minor inconvenience; it's more of a spa day for my soul. I've made friends with the shades, had heartfelt conversations, and even organized a dance party in Tartarus – because who said the afterlife can't have a good beat?

The gods keep giving me boons like they're Oprah on Mount Olympus: 'You get a boon, and you get a boon, everyone gets a boon!' But despite all the divine help, I still manage to get smacked by a Hydra head or charmed by a Gorgon. Maybe I need a divine intervention or just better reflexes.

Hades, where death is just a pit stop on the road to redemption, and the only constant is Zagreus' stylish attitude. 9/10, because even in the Underworld, I've never felt so alive, even if it's just for a moment before getting obliterated again.

Hades stands out for trying something new in terms of art and narrative in an otherwise established genre. The hack-and-slash combat, though a little one-note, is solid. The "roguelike" aspects are somewhat overstated in the game's marketing since it's pretty light on procedural generation; it has permadeath, permanent upgrades between runs, and randomization of room rewards. As a fan of the completely unpredictable nature of traditional roguelikes, I found that a little disappointing, but it does other things really well: fun strategic builds, an interesting narrative premise (you play a minor god attempting to break out of hell with the assistance of Olympian gods), and an extremely professional artistic presentation. I look forward to the sequel.

This game is basically a top down "Diablo" style hack and slash game that puts your skills to the test. In every new weapon that you get throughout the game, there are different styles and strategies to learn how to complete the entire game. If you are skilled and knowledgable, you can beat the game within 2-3 hours. However, it will take most people at least a good 10-20 hours to learn the ins and outs of the game. Having said that, the grind to become skilled at the game is one of the best games I have played. This goes to show that you do not need a fancy AAA game to enjoy videogaming.

Hades is a fast paced and forgiving RPG game.

(Game was Gifted)

I'm not going to let the Styx take me before I have expressed my biggest thoughts on this game. But I'll make the headline apparent:

Hades is phenomenal. Without any question. 

I had this game put off for the longest time since I wasn't confident in it aligning well with my preferences, so after expressing mild interest and acknowledging the game indeed did look really good, I had it gifted to me. After having finished the main quest now, with more still to go, I really sincerely wish I had purchased the game myself.

Hades at it's core feels like a love letter when it comes to giving it's own interpretations of the Greek Mythology, following the son of Hades in his attempts to escape the underworld, battling through different biomes of increasing difficulty and unique enemies in order to escape to Greece, all aided by the Gods of Olympus granting their boons to help him in his efforts. Each God, each character, feels like a really authentic interpretation of the Mythos (which, granted, I am not familiar with in any capacity), and it doesn't require that knowledge to really get into, and further aiding this is the fantastic voice acting for each character. Everybody sounds distinct and provides the proper flair that each God deserves. From the chilled out carefree tone of the God of Wine to the imposing booming voice of Hades himself. It doesn't need a lot of detail, it's just really damn good voicework. Simples. 

The son of Hades, Zagreus, is your playable character through this. He's honestly the star of the show, because it would've been easy for his role to fall into the angst, rebellious level of teen archetype that this sort of narrative would encourage, and he isn't that in the slightest. Zag carries himself with lots of warmth and a kindhearted nature towards all the other characters (except his father). He knows what he has to do is causing strife within the Underworld, but it's not stopping him from doing what he can to make amends with people and build relationships with others. Everything about Zagreus is extremely likeable, and he's probably one of the best protagonists I've played as. Definitely can't wait to see how they handle his sister in the sequel.

Oh, as we're talking visuals... It's an incredible; You're greeted by beautiful environments oozing with colour and personality, with each of the characters, Gods/Goddesses all being illustrated in uniquely wonderful portraits. The visual identity of Hades has so much love poured into it, and it shows in how seamless everything blends together. The effort even extends into how the different visual effects for the boons of the gods stack over each other, as well as enemy attacks and environmental hazards. I can still keep track of everything going on despite the visual colour war going on, because it's just handled that damn fucking well! Supergiant really brought their S-Rank effort into this element of the game and I cannot praise it high enough.

Gameplay is split between your escape attempts and your roaming around the hub area, that being the House of Hades (all shown from an isometric top down perspective). Every escape attempt has you jump down through your escape route and battle your way through chambers of varied creatures, each room leading to randomised rewards, be it money to spend or one of the gods granting you a series of boons to pick from to boost your power. As the nature of this is rogue-lite, there is a lot of combinations that you can have of these God favours, which can lead to crazy different play-styles with each of the 5 weapons you can get to play with, depending on how you get buffed. There is also a hammer that can be used to select a permanent change to your weapon, which can range from altering how you attack with it to increasing it's damage output in a specific way. 

The above would be moot if the combat itself wasn't phenomenal, and I can assure you it absolutely is. The controls alone are extremely tight for both controller and m&k, but the combat itself is fast paced, intense, and fluid beyond all belief. Zagreus moves so seamlessly between his moves with each weapon, bolstered further by how things get further altered the more upgrades you apply to him. You can feel like the most powerful hybrid god fighter with the right combo, and even if you DON'T, it still feels like an extremely fair game in how it presents it's challenge. Will it be easy? Hell no, it'll get really brutal if you get unlucky, but it IS fair, and it leads to a masterfully crafted combat system that feels incredibly orgasmic and satisfying when you get good at it. Admittedly it does fall into the button mashing issue that fighting games can fall into, but I find that trivial to nitpick on due to how much the combat gets done beautifully. The runs themselves will not take you much longer than 30-40 minutes if you're able to complete them, with 4 areas each with an ending boss fight; Boss fights offer the correct amount of challenge and variety for their area, and each feels unique and the aforementioned variety extends to how some of them have proper 'variations' where they're fights are different. I love this, as it can really helps alleviate that repetition that comes from fighting the same bosses over and over. Furthermore, beating the first run unlocks the Pack of Punishment; a Hades contract that will offer you the unique rewards again in exchange for adding additional difficulty modifiers to make things much harder on yourself. It's completely optional too, but it's damn tempting if you wanna test your skills and get more rare items much quicker than waiting for them to appear in the hub shop.

But since this is the Underworld, and it is brutal, you're going to die. A lot. But what makes Hades a star in this aspect too is how it uses each death. As you climb out of the River Styx each time, you will get to wander round the House of Hades and chat with each of the characters, each run giving you new lines of dialogue and the ability to gift rare items to each of them to start forming bonds. It kinda turns into an RPG style mini-game, because aside from talking with people, you can put in contract orders to customise Zag's bedroom, maintain the state of the court, and change the cosmetic appearance of the different areas. As you progress you will also get to add more additions to your upcoming runs to aid you, and with some other items in-game you can go into Zag's room and use the mirror to upgrade your base stats while also unlocking new ones to keep making Zagreus permanently stronger and more capable of getting further in each run. So with every death, you're still progressing, while also getting the opportunity to spend time in the house with the different characters as more information get drip fed to you. Plus, a couple of them you can romance with enough dedication, both male and female, and none of it feels forced in. It's a wonderful little bonus they didn't need to add. Not a bit add, but it's still a really welcomed one. 

I nearly forgot to talk about the soundtrack, so to end off on my favourite aspect, the music is fantastic. Every single track is a joy to listen to. From soothing melodies or quiet peaceful tracks to the bombastic sounds that blare during major combats and boss fights. Special shout out to the final boss...just look up "The Unseen Ones" if you're morbidly curious. It goes SO HARD.

It goes without saying: Hades is incredible and I love it to death, so it's hard to be super objective after all. So... so if you'd per-perhaps.... consider picking it u-up... if this sorta style of game is your jam.. then.. ugh...

I enjoyed most of my time with Hades but the last 10% of this game left me feeling frustrated, unfulfilled and disrespected as a gamer and consumer.

First of all the Hades boss on its own is a good boss fight but in the context of the game is badly designed in terms of difficulty.  Throughout the game there was the odd difficulty spike which is welcome such as the first and third boss and the poison rooms before Hades but the Hades fight itself is about 10 times more difficult than anything else in the game.  This is poor balancing.
What comes after it is far worse.  Upon 'finishing' the game when you are sent back to the beginning I looked up how many times you would need to kill Hades to get an ending and was shocked (10 times).  I think what the developers have done is quite disgusting to dangle players on a string just to keep them playing.  It's probably the worst ending in terms of concept I've experienced since Mass Effect 3.  In fact I think it's worse than that.  I don't even want to watch the ending on YouTube as I feel I'd be paying the developers too much respect in watching their content, respect that they haven't paid me.  When I was playing the game I had plans to play it again on God and Hell mode (I was playing on normal) but such a deflating last 10% of the game has totally removed any desire to play it again and I don't think I'll be buying Hades 2 either.

Hades is a Rogue-like fictional telling of the son of Hades.  Thing to note, Zagrius is not actually a strong representation of the mythology he is based on so a lot of liberal narrative choices have been taken with this story.  But, it is good!  
The mechanics of the game are tied very well with the story and one clearing of the dungeon is not enough to mark the game as complete.  Despite having completed the story I do find myself coming back to the game which is more a testament to it's gameplay than it's story.
The biggest thing this game has going for it, despite my previous praise of gameplay, is it's characterization.  Every character feels like a person, not one dimensional and very responsive to your in game choices.  However, that is also a limiting factor as your in game choices do not impact the narrative.  You can unlock more of the scripted narrative but you cannot mold it.  This is not a strike against Hades, but more a forewarning for those of you who enjoy your decisions having an impact on the game.
I think the developers took a very careful and thoughtful approach to this game, and wanted both the story and gameplay to mesh.  I believe they have succeeded but I also believe there are things to be improved upon.  I think that given they are using an unestablished demi-god, of the underworld they could be a bit more liberal with their story, but they do choose some rather boring decisions for conflict and progression.
Most of the interesting dynamics writing wise are through side dialog.  
The mechanics of the game are fairly simple and get harder (or easier if you prefer) based on how you choose to start each run.  I find the weapon variety satisfactory, and the perks to be fairly diverse.  
If this is your first rogue-like game (Starting from the same starting point to progress towards the end with rng elements of upgrades) then this is a great stepping stone into this world.
If you are a Veteran of this genre, you may find it lacking in certain aspects, and if you are here for the story, while I will fully die by the sentiment the first 3/4 of the main story are gold.  I will aslo admit, the end of the story and many of it's resolutions are lacking and feel like an afterthought.
I would definitely recommend this game overall, but with caveats.

[h1] ▀▄▀▄▀▄ Hades ▄▀▄▀▄▀ [/h1]

[u][b]TL,DR Review[/b][/u]

An exceedingly well-made rogue-like, Hades has everything that even some AAA games fail to deliver. Excellent voice acting/music, a really good story, and an addicting game-play loop. This is not a game you want to miss.

[u][b]Full Review[/b][/u]

Supergiant Games has created their best game yet with Hades, a isometric fast-paced hack-and-slash action game with an engaging rogue-like loop. You'll be playing as Zagreus, the immortal son of Hades and prince of the Underworld. Who is trying to escape to see the surface world despite the efforts of his father to stop him.

Combat entails entering chambers\combat arenas and facing off against different enemy types depending on what region you're in with a boss at the end of the region to face. You are given a reward with completing each chamber and this can vary from currency, added max health, gemstones or a boon from an Olympic god. The Olympic gods are distance relatives to Zagreus and their boons vary from alterations to your normal attack, special attack, dashes & more. What items you'll be able to carry over after each run allow you to upgrade passive stats like higher tier boon rate, health regained when exiting a chamber, & more. There's much more going on than what I'm outlining here but I'll leave that for you to experience yourself.

Outside of combat is where to story is where much of the story is fleshed out, with dialog with Cthonic gods like Nyx, Chronos, & Charon. You'll find that there is more going on with keeping Zagreus in the Underworld and may have some connection to his real parental origins..... The story here has been engaging throughout my time with this game and the writing so far has been very good. Voice acting is well done & the music is perfect for the setting, it doesn't falter at matching the combat in any point in a run. Visually it looks great with some amazing digital artwork that nails the look of the Greek Underworld.

There is so much to do & see in Hades, even in early access there was a ton of content to experience. I'm nearing 70 hours and there is still new dialog to hear with more to unlock as well. This is objectively one of the best rogue-likes out there and one of the best bang for your buck purchases that you can get. I'm not sure how Supergiant can top this with their next game but if it's in anyway as good as Hades, it'll be an instant success.

[h1] Zagreus Got That Big Himbo Energy [/h1]
     
     It's a fun as hell rogue-like that somehow manages to pull off a progressive story over the course of... a lotta runs, gonna be honest. But the mechanic fits so well into the universe you almost look forward to each death. The characters are familiar spins on classical Greek myths and give the game so much spice it's like Arrakis out here. But the actual meat & potatoes, and what made this game the 2020 GOTY (Last of Us Part 2 won b/c it was controversial not a better game. [i] Come at me[/i]) is the buttery smooth combat and downright delicious soundtrack that blend eargasmically.

     You know that magical feeling in the newer DOOM's when the nightmare-synthmetal syncs up perfectly to your murder-ballet, and the hairs on the back of your neck stand on end as you feel your pupils dilating? Hades also conjures this same witchcraft. Only now you're unleashing divine fury gifted by the Greek Pantheon upon the tortured denizens of the underworld, whilst metallo-greek riffs get your blood boiling during every ascension. Honestly, I just want some DLC. I'd pay $20 for a $25 game's DLC, that's how blisteringly good this game is. Why are you still reading this, [b] BUY IT AND PLAY IT ALREADY! [/b]

This game is absolutely amazing. It's Supergiant Games makes a roguelike.

Sure, it's still technically in Early Access, but it's almost completely done. The randomized boon system, keepsake system, and weapon upgrade system are interact amazingly with the main character's own dedicated levelup system, allowing progress to be made.

It's also quite hard. As a veteran roguelike and Binding of Isaac player, this game still beat the shit out of me.

This is Supergiant Games, so the dialogue and story are top notch. It's a little less then some of Supergiant's other titles, but it is also a roguelike - that said, they make the roguelike aspect make perfect sense, and Zag's snarky remarks and commentary are amazing in the interactions with everyone.

If you like Roguelikes, or Bastion, even Transistor, or just generally well crafted games, then this is well worth more then the full price. If there's a sale, grab it. If you hate fun, then good luck with that I guess.

Easily one of the best games I've ever played.

It has several cool mechanics, and it presents them to you slowly, so it never becomes overwhelming. I won't talk much about the mechanics themselves because part of the fun is to learn them as the game progresses, but I will mention the one that blew my mind. You get to choose how the game gets more difficult. Not the usual enemies-become-damage-sponges-that-kill-you in-one-hit, which is the only way most games progress. You get to set what you find more fun to be your challenge. You want the tradidional way? Cool. You want something else? Deal. There are several options.

Another striking quality of this game is how balanced it is. There is no clearly weak weapon or god. All of them provide useful bonus and cool mechanics. Moreover, as the game progress, you get ways to slightly nudge the game randomness in the direction you prefer. These two factors (good balancing + a bit of control over the randomness) make this game much more enjoyable than most similar games where basically you keep praying that you don't get only crappy options to choose from. There's almost always something useful to work with. And if it's crappy, just sell it and buy something else.

Lastly, the final piece of brilliance is that the quests and achievements in this game are mostly directed to have you experience the different facets of the game. When a god give you his options, most of us (myself included) tend to always go for the same ones. But if you wanna complete the mission, you will have to at least once choose the options that seemed worse. And the beauty of this mechanic is that sometimes, when you choose the option that seemed worse, you get to see its advantages that were not clear to you beforehand.

All in all, a masterpiece. With beautiful art, interesting characters and compeling music to complement such wonderful gameplay.

"Hades," developed and published by Supergiant Games, is a rogue-like dungeon crawler that has garnered critical acclaim since its official release in 2020. Set in the richly mythological universe of the Greek gods, the game follows Zagreus, the son of Hades, as he attempts to escape from the underworld to reach Mount Olympus, seeking answers and assistance from his Olympian relatives. This review evaluates "Hades" based on its gameplay mechanics, story and character development, graphical and audio presentation, replayability, and overall entertainment value.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Hades" combines fast-paced, fluid combat with a deep arsenal of weapons, abilities, and power-ups, known as Boons, granted by the gods of Olympus. Each escape attempt from the ever-changing labyrinth of the Underworld is unique, thanks to the procedurally generated rooms and the variety of enemy types that challenge players to adapt their strategies. The game expertly balances difficulty and progression, ensuring that even after failure, players feel a sense of achievement and growth.

Story and Character Development
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
The narrative of "Hades" is compelling and richly layered, exploring themes of family, rebellion, and fate through witty and poignant dialogue. Character development is a standout feature, with each run revealing more about Zagreus, his divine relatives, and the inhabitants of the underworld. The game's storytelling is dynamic, with characters reacting to player choices and successes, making the world of "Hades" feel alive and responsive.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Supergiant Games is known for its distinctive art style, and "Hades" is no exception. The game's visuals are stunning, featuring vibrant, hand-drawn characters and environments that bring the world of Greek mythology to life. The audio design, from the adrenaline-pumping soundtrack to the voice acting, is equally impressive, enhancing the game's atmosphere and immersing players in the action and drama of Zagreus's journey.

Replayability
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
Replayability is one of "Hades'" strongest aspects. The rogue-like nature, combined with a vast array of weapons, Boons, and upgrades, ensures that no two runs are the same. The game's narrative unfolds across multiple attempts, encouraging players to keep trying not just for gameplay but to discover more of the story. Additionally, the introduction of post-completion content and challenges adds even more depth and longevity to the game.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Hades" offers an exceptional entertainment value, blending challenging gameplay, a compelling narrative, and beautiful presentation into a cohesive and addictive experience. It's a game that appeals to both fans of the rogue-like genre and those who might not typically enjoy its inherent difficulty, thanks to its engaging story and character-driven progression.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 9.4/10 - Masterpiece
"Hades" stands out as a masterful blend of action, storytelling, and artistic design, setting a new standard for rogue-like games. Its innovative approach to narrative integration within a genre known for repetition and difficulty makes it a landmark title that is both accessible and deeply rewarding.

A must-play game for fans of rogue-likes, mythology enthusiasts, and anyone looking for a richly narrative-driven game. "Hades" is a triumph in game design, offering a challenging yet immensely satisfying experience that rewards persistence with a story and characters that stay with you long after you've put down the controller.

A friend convinced me to buy Hades. I had been tracking it since Early Access and it was on sale anyway, so I did. And then I played so much that my chronic tendonitis flared up again. And then I convinced another friend to buy it. And now we have a fourth friend convinced to try it too!

I highly recommend this game if you like the sound of an RPG with hack and slash combat taking place in roguelike instanced dungeons. No matter how much this game is simply marketed as a “roguelike”, it is more accurately a hybrid of genres. For the story, you have to beat the final boss 10 times, which I completed in about 50 hours. But it doesn’t end there! In post game, there is also a final story epilogue to unfold. After reaching the final story conclusion, you might still be in the process of befriending all NPCs, unlocking hidden versions of each weapon, achievement hunting, decorating your house, or challenging yourself by turning on the “Heat” to make it harder.

I would prefer to play with keyboard and mouse, especially for ranged weapons, but the apm requirement of this game is quite high. I pretty much had to switch to gamepad to avoid seriously injuring myself because I'm nuts. 

Hades is my personal Game of the Year because the final product is extremely polished: 

1. Art

The character portraits are gorgeous. From each NPC’s dynamic pose to wardrobe design to the color palette, the art is a visual treat. During the gameplay itself, the art is more simplified, almost cartoonish but stylized. The depiction of the underworld especially reminds me of Disney’s Hercules. The game is set from an isometric bird’s eye view, like Supergiant’s other works.   

2. Story

Simple story, good characters. If you have general knowledge of Greco-Roman mythology, you won’t predict exactly how the story ends up, but you won’t be too surprised by the plot. The same goes for the thematic concepts present in the game. Although I didn’t find the commentary on relationships, communication, family, and parenting mind blowing, each had its place. The impact was simple and effective without being proselytizing.

The NPCs are complex, and you get to know them better as you continue to interact with them and deepen Zagreus (Zag)’s relationships with them. The reactive dialogue pools are no joke. Over 125 hours in, and I am still receiving new lines and interactions directly building off on previous interactions. Some of Zag’s lines are long winded and come off fanfiction-y, but I can forgive them because the character interactions make me genuinely laugh, smile, or otherwise react. 

In comparison to most games, the Steam achievements and in-game goals for Hades are fairly easy to unlock if you simply put in the time. I honestly don’t set out to 100% games; it burns me out. Although I mainly knock out what I can along the way, I am surprised to see that I am close to 100% completion for Hades. The reason why I didn’t stop after completing the post-game epilogue is because the game is still unveiling new subplots based on my maxed out NPC relationships.

The only complaint I have in this area is Zag’s weird British accent. It sounds like someone pretending to be British and trying really hard to sound the elegant kind of British. Why is he even British? Hollywood usually associates ancient civilization with British accents, but not all NPCs in Hades have one. Skelly’s New York accent sounds oddly restrained too.

3. Gameplay

Although the chambers (instanced dungeons) have randomized rewards, enhancements, and minibosses, there are permanent combat-enhancing elements in the game. The first are Keepsakes, or items that you receive after having one level of affection with each NPC. Keepsakes can buff Zag’s stats or provide some other benefit for wearing it. Certain NPCs with maxed affection will gift you a Companion that you can summon a limited number of times for a benefit. Finally, the Mirror of Night in your room acts like a pseudo skill tree of sorts. The Talents (Mirror benefits) are permanent, but you can easily reset and respec the points to better match a build you want to try. 

Weapons are fairly balanced and each of them have a unique playstyle. Everyone has a different personal ranking for them because of how they like to use them. Dealing damage is split into 5 main categories: Attack, Special, Cast, Dash, and Call. These categories are enhanced by Boons given to you by gods that you encounter in chambers. Boons and other dungeon rewards are randomly generated. They can be influenced by Keepsakes and Mirror Talents.

Combat can be punishing like any roguelike. One seemingly innocuous decision can unravel your entire instance with snowball effects. The game is most difficult at the start when you have few Mirror Talents, and at post-game when you turn on a large number of Heats. You have to open your eyes and learn. Do the prophecies (in-game completion goals) to learn all possible Boon combinations and evolve your playstyle with each weapon. 

My gripe with the combat is that RNG can be frustratingly unfair, resulting in playing with the same builds repeatedly. Many of my attempts to create something new go downhill due to staunch RNG. For example, I once wore a Keepsake that was supposed to guarantee a god to show up. I went through two entire maps without seeing them! I gave up and either took the same old build or killed Zag off to reset the chamber reward permutations. I’ve also lost to the final boss because I couldn’t complete my build in time due to RNG. I know this isn’t unique to Hades, but most roguelikes do not give you the option to influence rewards in the first place. Thus, I expect it to be easier to accomplish with Hades.

This game has been a bunch of different things to me over the years. At the start it was awkward and frustrating and I didn't get it, but I'd get a glimpse of something really fun when I'd dash through an enemy at just the right time. Getting enemy timings down, using dodge properly, etc. was rough. I didn't even realize at the time how bad my boon picks were. Then I beat the first boss, and on to struggling with the second area. Then I spent a lot of time banging my head against Theseus, but while I was stuck there spinning my wheels, I started spending time playing the dating sim that's embedded, and redecorating the palace. Then I beat Theseus and soon after [REDACTED] himself. Then it became a game about designing the perfect combo of weapon and boons to get me through the next heat level, and even some speed running. I ticked them up one level at a time for a while, before I realized I'd started growing faster than the difficulty and started jumping 5 or more levels per run. I've beaten the extra-double-final boss and seen the whole epilogue and gotten all the achievements. Nowadays, it's meditative. I can grab any weapon and casually tear through low-30's heat (except the sword. Still high-20's with that guy). If I want a challenge, I can dial up the heat 'til it's frustrating to deal with. And someday, maybe, even that will feel trivial.

All of that stuff felt impossible when I tried it the first time, and eventually I got to the point where blowing up Theseus's dumb chariot is practically a given. Sometimes it's frenetic and chaotic and other times it's sentimental and occasionally, it's very chill.

Also the soundtrack goes so fucking hard. Good Riddance and The Unseen Ones are both worth listening to on their own and somehow both fit in-context, even though one is a gentle duet about the perks of being dead and the other is a high-speed electric guitar smasher about [spoiler]beating your dad to death with your Fists[/spoiler]. Spiritually, it is anyway. Darren Korb and Ashley Barrett deserve incredible praise.

This game experiments with the relationship between story and gameplay. The characters "die" but they don't forget what happened, so stuff that happened in past runs influences what characters talk about in future runs. The game actually executes on this very well. It never feels formulaic. It is often hilarious, like when Zagreus gives a boss a nickname and then that becomes its actual name, and again in future runs.

The only issue is, it quickly becomes very difficult to follow the story. It's not a complicated story. The problem is that as the story advances, the levels stay exactly the same (the only exception to this is the bosses, which get more powerful versions). In almost every other video game that has ever existed, story events are associated with specific levels, making them easier to remember. There is a good reason for this. We (human beings) remember things by association.

Don't take this as a criticism of the game. We need more experiments like this in video games. I also have no idea what Hades 2 is like.

Game is fun if you don't overcook it - if you dont put something like 200+ hours into the game. The game's strongest aspects by far is the character design, dialog, and voice acting, creating a truly one of a kind experience, I still find myself listening to the dialog and interactions on youtube from time to time.
 I enjoy the combat, it definiately feels great, but it lacks the needed variation for a roguelite, and after exhausting all the dialog (which takes a remarkably long time), it does start to feel quite repetative. Heat is added in the game to solve this issue, and it does for a short period of time as some heat options are fun, while others are obviously artificial difficulty (Enemies do slightly more damage, slightly have more health, spawn a bit more in each room). Its in your hands to create an experience you find thrilling, which can add a few more hours for the game's enjoyment, or a few hundred hours depending on the type of gameplay you enjoy. 
 Overall, this game gives one of the strongest performances I've experienced with witty dialog, interesting characters, which strongly drive the gameplay loop forward for about 70 hours, but because if its strong dependence on characters rather than gameplay, it faulters after the interactions are all done, leaving the player without a strong reason to go back after they have experienced it all.

One-of-a-kind story, amazing visuals, and an addictive gameplay loop. Hades is one of those games that will leave you shocked at how great a game can be.

Story: They couldn't have handled the Greek mythology and the messed-up family dynamic that the Olympians have any better. I am normally the type of player to skip dialogue almost every chance I get but in this game? No chance. I played hours upon hours just to learn a little bit more about each character.

Gameplay: It has a gameplay loop that somehow manages to never get boring, even after hundreds of escape attempts thanks to the customization of each run. You can have thousands of different runs with different weapons, different boons, different mirror abilities and different keepsakes! You can also micro-manage games difficulty for your liking. The game has 10/10 replayability, I find this extremely hard for the Roguelike genre.

Graphics: All of the characters look tasty. Amazing art style that has inspired me as an artist. I have even studied the art style a little bit to improve myself. The character personalities are also top-notch; their dialogue never gets boring, even after your 100th escape attempt.

Music: It's simply godly (pun intended). The sounds are also tasty. That's all I have to say.

Overall, Hades is a masterpiece for sure, I am looking forward for SuperGiant Games's upcoming games.

Hades - A Mythical Masterpiece

Hades, a masterpiece by Supergiant Games, seamlessly blends Greek mythology with enthralling gameplay, earning it a solid 9.8/10 from me.

The Good:
Soundtrack: Divine music elevates every moment, from atmospheric exploration to intense battles.
Story: Sharp writing and witty dialogue create a captivating narrative, delving into the complexities of the gods.
Replayability: Ever-changing chambers, diverse weapons, and unfolding storylines ensure each attempt feels unique.

The Bad:
Initial Story Pace: It takes time to fully appreciate the narrative; early runs may feel repetitive.

In conclusion, Hades is a must-play, offering a perfect blend of storytelling, sound design, and addictive gameplay, solidifying its place as a modern gaming classic.

I'm okay getting blasted for this opinion, but personally I just couldn't get into Hades. I enjoy a ton of other roguelites, but I feel like the variety of builds in Hades is significantly lower than most and the lack of much procedural or variant layouts makes most runs feel strikingly similar. The lack of boss variety and differing paths to take also really hurt the experience of the game for me, as games like Dead Cells of Risk of Rain 1/2 provide incredible variety of paths to take and side areas to explore.

I can say one thing that absolutely differentiates this from other roguelites is the emphasis on the story of the game and the amount of progression between runs. The game takes advantage of the roguelike format to allow you to see all the characters in the story and see all of their own questslines and characters develop while playing the game over and over, which is honestly the game's strongest point for me. The story, writing, dialogue, and incomparably the art are just honestly incredible. It makes me sad the game just doesn't scratch the same roguelite itch for me, as the game encourages repeated runs by giving insane bonuses to you with enough invested currency. While many argue they aren't necessary, I think most would agree that you can't experience the game in full without all of the progression systems and difficulty settings. 

Understandably, most people still like the game and the progression systems. I share the love for the incredible art and VA in the game, but I personally couldn't get into the flow of the game despite my love of the genre already. If you enjoy the feeling of gaining permanent powers and progression in a more static world, you might like Hades. If you prefer variation in runs and branching paths with less permanent progression, then I can't say I recommend Hades, which saddens me.

I bought this on Switch a while ago, played the hell out of it (ahem), and gave it a 9/10. I've recently been coming back to it on Steam, starting from a fresh save, with the goal of finishing off the epilogue and other content I never got around to.

Somehow I got significantly more absorbed on this second playthrough, which is damn impressive considering how enamored I was to begin with.

The narrative presentation of this game is simply sublime. The voice acting is hands-down the best I've ever heard in a video game, ever. Dialogue is oozing with wit and charm while still leaving room for more somber moments. Character designs are gorgeous. The depiction of mythology is simultaneously a faithful homage and a creative new take.

In a genius move, this narrative is sprinkled throughout the gameplay loop as you keep coming back for more runs to gradually progress storylines and hear more dialogue. Of course, that gameplay loop is also sublime. You get six unique weapons, which each have 4 upgradeable variants to choose from, which then get further customized by random god blessings and hammers during a run. After a run, you get to take the resources you earned and funnel them into permanent upgrades, weapon unlocks, and decorations. Once you get good enough to where the game becomes easy, the modular difficulty system allows you to mix and match stipulations for harder runs to keep earning resources. Variety and replayability is insane. If I had one minor complaint, the endgame (like, about 60+ runs deep good lord) can feel a bit grindy; over-cranking the difficulty is a great challenge, but it's impractical since easier runs (while more tedious) also make it easier to keep gathering permanent resources.

Combat feels fantastic. Enemies are fair (with a few exceptions, particularly at higher difficulty levels) and hits are satisfying. With the weapon variety on offer, you're practically guaranteed to find favorites. And the right builds can take weapons I don't usually like and make them a lot more fun.

---

[h1]In the name of Hades...[/h1]
If you have any interest/doubts about this game or happen to be my friend: please, read this review.
It contains meme-tales of my personal experience + actual game info for you to see what you'll be dealing with.

At first glance at Hades -- I wasn't impressed. I didn't even understood why people like it. I miserably failed my 1st run and didn't think about coming back to the game, wasn't exactly my type of game. My pal, who introduced me to Hades, was very shocked by that fact and convinced me to try again. And so I did, after couple of weeks of consideration.
And then I fell in love with this gem of a game.

I've had 3 sessions of Hades obsession. After 1st break for couple of months and return to the game I was so fascinated and couldn't understand why did I stop playing, the game is a damn masterpiece. In couple of hours I remembered: my fingers and hands were hurting from smashing those buttons, I just couldn't physically continue at the time. :D
Good gamers with great reaction will not understand, but me, being pepega such as I am, I've panicked and pressed too many buttons to kill and survive. Took me a while but I've learned how to play it not like a guitar hero but to learn timings and positioning.

The game itself is very well made on each and every aspect:
[olist]
[*] [b]Story, dialogues and voice acting[/b] is on the next level. I have about 200-300 screenshots on my pc from this game and most of them just dialogues. They are witty, fun, wise. 
This game, if you read and listen, can show you and teach you a lot. Psychology have always been my hobby and it was cool to see how this game shows: at least 3 types of problematic relationships between children and parents(indifferent/abandonment, overcontrolling, cold+tyranic); about 3 to 5 examples of romantic relationships(friendly romantic, toxic tough love, kinky exploring type, etc); bunch of situations regarding different friends/aquitances, god-mortal, god-to-god, and ofc it has Cerberus, whom you can pet as many times as you like.
Your progression thru the game and progress with certain characters changes your interactions with them and their lines. 
You going to dislike some characters at first but will grow to love and respect them(avoiding spoilers) and this is a great experience.
If you are a fan of Greek Mythology, you're going to have a blast looking at all the interpretations of the appearances and characters of mythic creatures, gods, heroes and monsters etc. Every character, especially gods, are very well represented and have amazing and unique vibe. Sometimes the gods going to be pleased with you, sometimes they'll be angry and it's cool to see how they change in a matter of seconds, it all feels like they are real characters and they would say/act the way they do.
Trust me, there is much more to tell, but I'd love to avoid spoilers and the size of this review is getting out of hand.
[*] [b]Variability, weapons, god powers and staff.[/b]
The game has 6 weapons, each weapons has 4 aspects, each of them offer different playstyle and has different passives and bonuses, each of these aspects can be upgraded up to 5 times, this upgrade stays forever. And during the run, usually you stumble upon Dedal's Hammer, up to 2 times, which have number of upgrades for your weapon: these are staying only for the current run. They can change your gameplay drastically.
During your run/escape attempt, you going to get help from Olympian gods. Each god have number of unique powers and combinations with other gods. All this powers work differently with different weapons. Zeus is all about lighting, Poseidon all about crushing force of the waves, Artemis - crits and hunt and ofc we have Dionysus, who's all about the booze and hangover effects for your enemies :D
Variability is insane. You have to see for yourself. I have yet to try many cool builds.
[*] [b]RNG[/b] 
Hella annoying how it should be in any rogue-like: you think you know what build you going to get and you end up with half of what you wanted but it works. Sometimes your build becomes so strong you really feel like a god and think that this should be nerfed. Then you try to repeat the build and you realise it was very good run and ton of luck, probably won't happen again. Apreciate what you have and learn combinations and boons. In this game RNG will teach you new things, it'll teach you lessons, you'll appreciate it. RNG here isn't like unforgiving RNG in Darkest Dungeon, it's kind. But don't get fooled: it'll tease you and you'll have to respect it and be smart about your choices.
[*] [b]Difficulty.[/b]
If you're struggling or just want to go thru the story - game has God-Mod option in the menu. You'll be hella strong. Especialy after you die. Yes. Spoiler alert: you going to die. Nobody gets out alive. But I might be lying to you. Find out for yourself ;)
Games too easy..? No problemo, senior. Game has Pact of Punishment system -- you can up the difficulty yourself, you're choosing exactly what's going to get harder. Up to 64 levels of Punishment, I think. That's going to be insane, but it's possible. Examples of punishment: 1)+% number of enemies; 2)+dmg/hp to enemies; 3)enemies/bosses have additional abilities. And for each additional difficulty lvl you going to be rewarded ofc.
[*] [b]Progression[/b]
Well, during the run you have progression which mentioned above, but you also progress by collecting some resources during the run, which can help you make yourself stronger in the long run, you can change cosmetic aspects of the Underworld or use resources to help certain characters with their troubles. Oh, yes, sometimes you can fish as well to get more resources, it's pretty fun :D
[*] [b]Music.[/b] It's simply godly. Never gets old. You'll listen to it even outside of the game. Trust me, nothing to say here, enjoy it. Once again, work well done.
[*] [b]Imo art style/graphics[/b] of the game are one of the best there is. I think it's going to stand the test of time and will be amazing to look at whenever.
[*] [b]In game achievements[/b] and steam achievements will actually help you to experience this game to the fullest. It's more than possible to get them all. This is one of my most enjoyable 100% of the game. I really felt like I've done something cool, worthwhile and maybe even significant.
[*] [b]Game supports controller and keyboard.[/b]
I sticked with keyboard but sometimes thought that controller could be better. Don't stress it and pick what you enjoy.
[*] [b]Out of 10. [/b] c:
[/olist]

Hades is a roguelike masterpiece that earns a perfect 5/5 rating. The game seamlessly combines fast-paced combat, a compelling narrative set in the underworld, and breathtaking artistry. Hades excels in both gameplay and storytelling, with procedurally generated levels, diverse weapons, and godly powers offering an exhilarating experience in every escape attempt. The richly developed characters, exceptional voice acting, and visually stunning art style contribute to a narrative that is both captivating and emotionally resonant. Hades is a must-play gem, standing out as a masterpiece in the roguelike genre and the broader gaming landscape. ★★★★★ (5/5)

This game is a blast. Seriously, I'm not even particularly a fan of rogue-likes, but it has been a while since I had so much fun with a game. The characters you meet are plenty and unique, the story, albeit unfinished is engaging and the combat is a goddamn pleasure.

What I particularly enjoy is the very meaningful character progression. You can improve yourself between each game, you can also customize your weapons and eventually add conditions to make the game more challenging and earn better rewards. I also like the way you gather godly boons during a game which can lead to amazing combos and completely change the way you play between two games. It makes each game feel fresh and unique.

It's in early access, regularly updated and already extremely solid. I wholeheartedly recommend it.

Take this from someone who considers Transistor as one of his all time favorite games: This is Supergiant's best work and I'm not surprised it's getting a sequel. 
The gameplay loop and the controls are as smooth as they need to be. The variety of weapon abilities and boons make up for an insane replay value. The enemies and bosses are well designed and each area has its own enemy types. 
The soundtrack is excellent and so is the writing for the characters within the setting.
It has officially made it in my best games ever made list. It's a very good example of how indie developers have stepped up their game these last few years.
I absolutely recommend you give it a shot if you haven't done so already.

Should you try Hades? Absolutely yes. 
It has interesting story with a unique spin on the Greek mythology, looking at them as one big dysfunctional family where everyone are way too good looking.

The roguelite mechanic is really polished and always pushes just "one more run" feeling while also heavily still relying on you getting better as a player, not just the loadout getting better. The fact that there is even a speedrun category for no death clears illustrates that very well.

Music is also superb - each level has it's own identity. Both through visual and audio medium.

But I must admit that after the initial "honeymoon" period I find that I struggle to choose Hades over other games I have installed. I guess because if I jump back in after a longer while, it will take a run or two to get back in the combat rhythm and start slaying.

Or maybe it's just my wrist pain, that unconsciously makes me choose games that doesn't require extensive attack button mashing.

In any case, I still stand by what I said - if you at least consider purchasing it, it's totally worth it and I can see how you could pour lots and lots of fun gaming hours in to this gem.

One of the best roguelike games out there, focusing on a solid narrative. Combat is good; while the art, music and writing is great. There are 4 regions that the protagonist Zagreus needs to clear, each with a randomly arranged sequence of dungeons and minions (like the various Acts in Slay the Spire). Most of the variety comes from changing your weapons and the boons you get from Olympian Gods. But, the boss of each region is always the same (with some variety via the endgame punishment pacts) and the 6 weapons don't add too much variety (even with aspects). Having said that, the grind was fun enough to have grabbed me for 80 hours, but other peoples' mileage may vary. Highly recommended!

Excellent game, excellent story and replayability

I have no complaints about the gameplay: movement is fluid and killing enemies is satisfying. Apart from that, the heat mechanic makes for some fun challenges that aren't just artificially difficult. As far as the roguelite experience goes, it's remarkably good.

My only complaint is how slow the endgame gets. The story starts at a good pace, gradually introducing all the characters. After that, it slows down considerably, with most players not even reaching the epilogue, as it takes many half-hour to hour-long runs just to advance two pieces of dialogue. Speeding up the end of the story could've made those final runs feel less like a chore (if you're interested in the story at all).

Pretty addictive! I didn't care for the voice acting, the story or the characters but the gameplay and art direction alone more than make up for it. It's challenging and definitely does not hold your hand, but it never gets frustrating (unless you artificially ramp up the difficulty to an unfair level after the first playthrough, but at that point that's on you). Recommended if you're looking for a unique game and a fair challenge.
