You start off kinda weak and slowly get permanent upgrades as you gather material over different runs. You can turn on God mode to get stronger without having to gather anything, but odds are being able to talk to the excellently-voice-acted characters every time you fail a run (which will happen frequently, early on) will keep your mind off the failure.

Eventually getting to the final boss, failing repeatedly, and eventually beating them, only to find out that that was only one of the first steps in unfolding the main story makes for one of the most memorable moments in this game. 10/10 would wipe my memory to experience that for the first time again.

Absolutely recommend. My first rogue-like game and it blew me away. 73 hours at time of review post and that's 73 hours of fun that I've had. I cried and laughed at the end of the story and will continue to play on :) Can't wait for Hades 2!

30 hours in, killed the 4th boss after 17 total escape attempts, 4th boss was much harder than 1 2 or 3, taking 4 tries to kill them (attempts 9, 11, 16, and 17, whereas 1 2 and 3 each only took me 2 tries.  All in All the game seems well balanced. I did not need to turn on "God mode" which makes the game 20-80% easier, scaling the more you die.  (After 17 attempts it would have been 52% easier on the 20-80% easier God-mode Scale)  The game is not over, there's more story-line and more game-play, so after 30 hours I feel like I got a good amount out of the game, and could play it for another 200 hours to 100% or lets say 99% everything, but this feels like a good time to make a review.  The different ways to attack and the different modifiers do to things I like, you can pick how you want to play, and you it changes it up each time a bit too. Some of my play sessions were drastically different from others, and I found some things I like a lot better than others, but multiple ways have been really fun.   

THE MUSIC! I can't end my review without saying that the music is so good. There are only a few games I'd compare this music too that I've played in my life, Some of the Bethesda games like Skyrim, the Age of Empires / Age of Mythology series. The Hades team did an amazing job creating music for this game.  

The story is great, and certainly long enough, the gameplay is fun, just difficult enough, if you don't have this game, get this game. I'm extremely frugal and waited till it was 50% off, but now can say it's worth full price for sure. I think I've babbled enough, go play Hades!

A fantastically fun rougelike title that kept me entertained for many hours and will keep me playing for many more. As a player who has grown fond of rougelike games as I have discovered the genre, with other titles I've played including Binding of Isaac: Afterbirth and Enter the Gungeon, Hades has become one of my favorites. 

The story painting Zagreus as a rebellious teenager trying to run away from home and his overbearing father is a brilliant angle on the Greek mythos. The artwork for the characters and environments is stunning! The voice acting for all the characters makes them seem real and alive, making it easy for me to care about them, thus making an effort to jump back out the window to find Nectar and Ambrosia for them all the more worthwhile.

The sense of progression feels very natural. Fighting your way to the end boss of Tartarus feels like an uphill battle for the first handful of escape attempts, but collecting Darkness to acquire passive upgrades and learning each main weapon earns the player more power to take on the boss and navigate the higher floors a bit better on later attempts. Fighting the last boss is an insurmountable task the first time, but the adrenaline rush you get after defeating them the first time is exhilarating, and makes you want to come back to do it over and over again!

I would recommend this game to anyone who is learning to love rougelikes as I am and players who enjoy constant fast-paced action.
I did question whether I'd enjoy this and eventually decided to buy it after seeing a lot of positive reviews and recommendations. Now I join the masses, buy it, you'll enjoy it.

Hades is truly a fantastic game. It had hooked me into playing it from the moment I began the first escape, and I still get excited to play it. 

For players like me who don't play this kind of genre very often, I thoroughly enjoyed it, especially since every run is unique in regards to the chambers, the boons you get, how you choose to play it, and how you choose to end your run. It has different difficulties and different playing styles, so a player can truly create a unique experience fro themselves and have fun trying to escape over and over again.

As a fan of Greek mythology, I really loved the characters and how they were portrayed, as well as the main and side stories. It was awesome to experience such touching moments, but also to laugh at some of the silliness from the dialogues. The voice acting, the art, the music, everything is just stunning.

Thank you Supergiant Games for creating such a masterpiece, and I cannot wait for the magic that will be Hades II.

You could write a full essay on the dialogue alone. You could talk about all the niche interactions that appear under very specific circumstances, as well as there being 21,020 voice lines! Even Charon, a character who literally just groans, has 120 unique voice lines. This game is the absolute peak of detail and content.

The dialogue is just one part of this indescribably massive game. So much depth, so much mechanical complexity, so charming, so many ways a run could go. Of course, that last aspect is common among all roguelikes, but where Hades shines is in it's story progression. Considering roguelikes forego story almost entirely, seeing Hades still have story progression even after death is extremely refreshing, and something I never seen before.

Despite my (as of time of writing) full DAY of playing this masterpiece, I had never had the same build, nor the same playstyle. I cannot stress enough the fact that I feel like I only scratched the surface of this game, and I seriously feel like 100 hours on this game is still not enough. This game is so intricate that it really feels like a living breathing world.

The devs made an indescribable amount of love, care, and passion, and crammed that into every single corner of this game. I would happily pay 100$ for this game just to support the devs alone while you couldn't pay me 100$ to play an average modern AAA title. I could go on and on, like how Zagreus is a perfect vessel to experience the game through, being hilarious, as well as always asking the same questions the player was having, but I think you get the point. Buy it. If you read this whole review, thank you, it means a lot.

Oh yeah, and the endgame is really good too.

TL;DR, game good, is funni, is fun, BUY IT

This is a frenetic action rogue-like that delivers an amazing overall experience and package.  This is not my go-to genre but it is a solid recommendation to any gamer.  I'm 44 and not the target demographic but the following really captivated my attention:

1. Story writing.  To have a story this engaging for this type of experience is not super common.  It's very well written, cheeky humour and overall very witty.

2. Acting is 10/10 and their voice work is better than most AAA studio's.  I forget who you visit around mid-game.  It's a female character that is cooking and offers a variety of power up options.  Her singing is truly mesmerizing and something you would hear on American Idol or playing in your home it's so relaxing and pleasant. 

3.  The Core as I touched on just before is truly 10/10.  

4.  Animation work is pretty flawless and all the effects, weapons and boons have their own unique personality.  

Overall, the fun factor is high and while it may not re-invent the genre, it sure does everything really well and it's a solid purchase on or off-sale.

An extremely fun rogue-like. The strength and design of enemies is almost perfect. The movement is generally fun and fluid on controller and generally acceptable (albeit less flexible) on keyboard/mouse. The discretization of difficulty in rogue-li(t/k)es is often coarse, but Hades has literally refined it to a very high degree of customizability. I highly recommend this game for those looking for a highly mechanical action-based rogue-like with a greater emphasis on movement and enemy attack avoidance rather than numbers games and economization. Hades does eventually play the numbers game once the player turns up difficulties that require the player to clear a run within a certain time and make enemies more difficult to face, but it cleverly does not force these things upon the player until they are ready.

[i]Hades[/i] has an achievement titled, "Something From Everyone" but in reality the game has something for everyone. [b]SuperGiant Games[/b] captured lightning in a bottle with their story driven meta-progression rogue-lite. The game literally has a story.

It should be mentioned that the story contains optional adult romances. The scenes are not explicit but are highly suggestive. With that being said, if the overall theme of the game isn't a problem then I personally find it doubtful any of the romances will be. 

The story itself really helps to give a good change of pace between runs. Although, one of the biggest chores is to get a particular npc, that I shall not name, to complete it's dialogue. I must have missed a suggestion to upgrade the lounge! The game has a 98% positive reviews for a reason and hopefully lightning will strike twice with the upcoming sequel, [i]Hades 2[/i]!
[spoiler]Paid: $12.49[/spoiler]

Update: Still fun to do a run every now and again even after platinum!
It's very fun, engaging, thick with mythology, and dying isn't a penalty until the end when you really want to finish runs to prove your mettle.

TL;DR: You have to get invested with the story. Playing only for the action is the "wrong" way to enjoy it (maybe not for everyone, but it was a mistake on my part).

I've played this on the Nintendo Switch back a few years ago. I didn't like it. There was something that felt unsatisfying about the game, and after I got to the end a few times, I thought "that's it?". I didn't understand quite what people revered the game for.

Then I got into roguelites and roguelikes, I've gotten obsessed and binged on every single one that I could get my hands on. The last year, that's almost everything I've been playing.
Then I got back to Hades, give it another shot on the PC to learn why I didn't like it, because it has to be a problem with me and not the game somehow. So then I try my best to like the game as a roguelite.

But the thing is, you have to like the story. You have to get invested into the story and the characters. Feel for them, feel with them, listen to them. Because if you only play for the action, something is missing. And I swear, once I got invested in the story, all the action felt fulfilling.  There was meaning in getting to the end, over and over.

Not the greatest review.  This is only how I learned to love the action, and it was worth it. Personally, story-based games are games I mostly try staying away from. Maybe because I always think they won't be fun. But I'm always wrong. When I do get into a story-based game, I really get into it, and those games are ultimately the ones I remember and love the most.

I was playing/loving Elden Ring and no game could pull me away, even games I'd been playing since 2014. I watched some Hades runs (@BarbarousKing) to see if I'd be interested in the game and it looked like a good time. My Hades playtime now rivals the ~420 hrs of Elden Ring and I don't think I'll ever entirely give this game up. The plots are intriguing/ fun/ surprising and the interpersonal relationships grow as you progress. The main character is kind-hearted and learns plenty about the role he may be destined to play while he journeys through the underworld encountering varied, challenging, and (mostly) enjoyable enemies of various degrees of importance. It's tough but learnable. As frustrated as some enemies and rng made me early on, I learned to love the challenge of a difficult foe and the risk of something unexpected as I attempted some wild, fun, and sometimes awful boon combos. "It's 7:48."      10/10

One of the best story-driven roguelikes ever. Characters are so rich in... well, character.

Hades is a perfect starting point to jump into Rogue-like games. It has fun and rewarding game play, interesting characters, an amazing soundtrack with a distinct and brilliant art style. 

The Combat covers a wide variety of playstyles with it's roster of weapons, boons and abilities. Crafting the best builds for the different weapons was the part of the game I had the most fun with.

The Story is interesting and keeps you wanting to do more runs, however once beating the "main" story, it can be difficult to get the side character plots to progress sometimes resulting, in some side stories taking a long time to complete due to pure random chance.

Hades, performs very well on high end computers and would run decently on most modern computers, my very not gaming laptop can run it with ease.

Overall, a great game to pick up as I believe anyone could complete it, though the 100% experience can get tedious really quickly.

I used to have an erection issue for video games, which means that I cannot get engaged in any video games, no matter how attractive they seems or how much praise they received, I just don't want to touch them, and they all lose the ability to turn me on. I don't think its an issue of me, but a systematic issue of the whole gaming industry. Every game is just another copy of another game, and they all look the same. I was in my stage of lost, lost of my perception of attractiveness. Finally, I met Hades. At first I though it's just another roguelike game that being really popular, but until I went into the middle stage of the game, so probably like 30 hours or something, I found myself fully immersed in this game. Not only a perfect designed system, the randomness in and out of each run, but also a really good story let me be curious of the tale of Greek gods and their fvkk stories. I felt that every character has their soul and characters, and our protagonist is also a likable character who continuously pursue his family and meaning of life (even he lives in hell). The battle is perfect, the music is beautiful, the story is engaging, I can feel the life and attraction of video games again. Although I still don't know if wasting time on video games is a good thing to do, damn it, it feels good. It feels good to look forward to something when you get home and with a box of beer, and it feels good to overcome the challenges followed on by another. I guess we all need something to remind us that we are alive, but video games probably be a bad choice to choose. maann, I got philosophical sometimes when I think about all the time I spent on stupid video games.

Game is a little bit over hyped, but great would recommend 8/10, here's why:

Gameplay is amazing, plenty of different styles you that can play and fit your taste, with decent amount of boon choices (power ups).
Game encourages you to get our your comfort build and try other weapons and for that it rewards you, which is great, I had so much fun experimenting and trying to make shit work, and this brings me to the 

games biggest problem, the length and variety, you go through same 4 regions and basically same bosses over and over again, no different paths to take and not much enemy variety. It's not balanced to pair the wapon/power up system. (pact of punishment does not count by any means, it just adds perks, does not change enemies.)

Also, if you're 100%-ing, it gets grindy, for same reason.

To end it on the positive note, everything else is so good I would recommend at full price to anyone.

Probably the only game so good that I can't even think of a way to leave the review as nothing more than a joke. This entire game is a truly unique experience that everyone should go through. The unique artstyle is simply stunning, the story is incredibly engaing and captivating, the dialogue feels real and authentic and the voice acting for every single character absolutely nails their role. The rng factor can be a bit frustrating at times but that is more than compensated for by the insane amounts of fun that come with any half-decent combination of bonuses. The game is just the right amount of difficult and has a lot of ways to both increase and decrease how much of a struggle it is, ranging from perfect for those only interested in the story to a challenge for even the most experienced players out there. The boss fights are all vastly different and feel like actual bosses rather than just some regular enemy with inflated stats, something that not many games manage to pull off successfully. This is one of, if not the greatest roguelikes ever made and there's nobody on this planet that I wouldn't recommend this game to.

Hades is an amazing roguelike RPG, and a testament to good game design. Its engaging, has a great story you tease out over multiple runs, great gameplay that doesn’t punish you unnecessarily and an amazing soundtrack and vocals. I can’t recommend this game enough, if you haven’t played it you should. 

[B]Story[/B]
You play as Prince Zagreus, son of the god Hades who is desperate to escape his father Hades, and his infernal realm. After the gods of Mt Olympus become aware of your existence they make contact with you, and offer boons in order to help you in your efforts to escape. Each run has different gods contact you and bestow different blessings, and slowly introduces a wider range of side characters you can interact with and explore their stories as you get closer to the surface and escaping. After my first escape (after many failed attempts) I thought it was a great story, only to find out that it’s really only the beginning of the story and as you complete more runs and converse with the NPC’s you expose all the secrets that gods have been keeping and start escaping to help avert a war between the entire pantheon.  Most of the creature and locations lore entries are expanded by visiting or encountering them enough times, however NPC’s need gifts after a set amount of visits.

[B]Gameplay[/B]
The gameplay while not being unique, is extremely rewarding. Essentially you start off in Hades palace where all the dead arrive, where you can converse with NPC’s (which moves their stories forward one conversation at a time), get scolded from Hades for being useless, trade items for rewards, spend money to upgrade the Palace and edit the weapons, perks and difficulty of the next escape attempt before setting off.

While every escape attempt is different, the premise is the same, with you having the clear 3 layers of the underworld and the temple of Styx you have to trek through, defeat their guardians and inhabitants who are being ordered by Hades to stop you. It’s a neat idea that by “killing” the inhabitants you are meting out the punishment they deserve, and that by stopping you they are ensuring the security of the realm (no dead souls have ever escaped), or in the Satyrs case killing the heathens who defile the temple of Styx and don’t venerate the gods.  
 
Everything useful to you during a run is lost upon escaping (or death), and it becomes a balancing act of deciding picking boons that help you in the current escape attempt, or items (gems, darkness, gifts) that will be used for future upgrades or conversations with the NPC’s and various gods. 

Replayability is very high and hasn’t just been tacked on as an afterthought as the whole story revolves around completing multiple escapes. The game actively encourages you to increase the difficulty (after a successful escape attempt) by limiting the items required for permanent weapon upgrades and different weapon aspects (each weapon has multiple forms that all change how they function) to only be awarded by each boss once at each difficulty level. When making runs harder you have full control over what setting you increase (it could be extra enemies, standard enemies have abilities, harder bosses, you lose boons as you progress ect), and you eventually get to a point where you need to have multiple of these selected. The game also keeps a record of the highest difficulty you have escaped with for each weapon, and the fastest attempt for those who limit to compete.

Each of the god’s boons can affect your primary moves in different ways (dash’s, attacks, magic casts, dodges and summons), and have different effects depending on which other boons are selected or what weapon is being used. Each of the boons have different tiers and levels, with a higher tier boon having better effects (say increase in damage %) over a lower but higher level boon. The Gods (while sounding friendly) are jealous and can offer to replace an existing rival’s boon with a higher tier one, or very rarely combine boons together so you get unique abilities that combine the best of both gods.

[B]Graphics[/B]
For a game that’s essentially a display on family dysfunction the graphics are crisp and colourful in a way that cel shading exploits. Each arena has an abundance of hues that help define each layer of the underworld, with Tartarus having a darker dungeon setting, Asphodel being the traditional hell of bubbling lava and Elysium having softer blues and greens where the righteous live in dead. As the relationships expand you can tweak the house with different upgrades
Characters and enemies are all animated extremely well (enemies have tells to advise you of their attacks), and secrets are hidden in plain sight in the fishing games. The UI is minimalist so it doesn’t interfere with the action happening on screen, and each character really stands out. Traps aren’t hidden, though will catch you unaware if you don’t pay attention and the action can be quite hectic. The De-motivationals that usually play at the start of each run are hilarious (basically Hades musings on how you will fail, or why everything sucks).

[B]Music[/B]
The vocals and music are amazing. They absolutely nailed the soundtrack for the game, with plenty of string and percussion tracks that align with the action happening on screen, with the more sombre music or tracks with vocals playing in resting areas or after certain events. The vocals are also amazing, with the dialogue between Hades & Zagreus being a standout. Hades put-downs are quite humorous to listen to (of you, when you change items around the palace and when he’s berating having useless minions or those in his court who displease him).

[B]Achievements[/B]
Getting 100% achievements will take multiple runs through the game due to the random nature of stage rewards and conversations, but is highly worth it and nothing too strenuous, though time consuming

For more reviews please visit https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31327216/

Hades is an isometric roguelite dungeon crawler in which you play as Zagreus. Zagreus is the prince of the underworld, son of Hades the god of dead. In this game you are attempting to escape your father's domain, and make your way to the surface.

Gameplay - 9/10

The gameplay is pretty astonishing, and stayed fun for many many hours. There are several abilities which can each be used in different ways, with several weapons that handle completely differently, as well as several upgrades you can get for each weapon that can completely change how they are played, as well as boons that will affect how you can use your abilities as well as duo and legendary boons that can change them even further. There are SO MANY potential builds you can have that you will struggle to find guides, as you almost always end up with a different build each time. The game has a lot of RNG features and while the game does provide many ways to circumvent this and put control back into your hands, sometimes you just screwed over and don't get the legendary or duo boons you wanted because they just weren't offered to you. However, the game is very fair and even if you have basically nothing it is definitely still possible to win and it can feel great when you do despite having a crappy build.
The pact of punishment adds another layer of difficulty, letting you customise how you play the game and how you increase the difficulty in your own way. The game has a system as well that encourages you to seek out and use upgrades/boons you haven't tried before instead of locking yourself down to the same weapon/boon/upgrade. [spoiler]Unfortunately, after the first few clears the game does slowly start to feel less and less rewarding, especially when you finish the game as there is no story incentive and before that when there is story incentive dying at the very end of a run acts as a blockage to reaching story you want to have. It can be frustrating. They try to prevent this feeling by having lots of other progression systems, but it still feels like a punch in the gut when I value the story over all of them.[/spoiler]


Story, World and Characters 8.7/10

At first the story amazed me. Roguelites typically don't have stories so to find a game not only flowing with story but also fully voiced, it was incredible. The characters are so good too. Hades, probably my favourite character, is great. An intimidating and powerful ruler constantly belittiling you. Over time you can give Nectar to characters, and they will start treating you with more respect. There are so many dialogue options that even after 10s of hours I was still finding new dialogue. However, over time the story slowly gets spread further and further out. You have to wait longer and longer between dialogue that progresses the story, since the game seems to prioritise random jokes and yapping from characters than important dialogue you want to trigger. There is a reason why less than 10% of players have completed the epilogue, and that is because it takes so long to fulfill the long list of criteria to activate it. I remember I went to Hermes several times with the requirements needed for the 
dialogue that progresses the story to activate and the guy just wouldn't say what I wanted. When one of the best ways to progress the story is by continuously dying at the start of the game to trigger new dialogue options, the game starts to get tedious when you play through full runs like I do. At around the 50 hour mark I got fed up, and no longer cared about earning the game's story opting instead to watch the game's final ending online. This wouldn't be an issue if I didn't play with the incentive of finishing the story as I often do in games. If you decide to play this game definitely but the story on the back burner and only be there for the gameplay. The best way to play is by letting the story play out in the background as you play it, rather than play to complete the story. Overall, the story is decent especially for a roguelite. However, due to how the game is made and how progress is achieved it would have been extremely difficult to get a story as good as you can find in a dedicated-story game.


Graphics and Audio 9.3/10

The game looks great, with thousands of hand-drawn graphics and animations. The main problem is that sometimes there is so much visual clutter that I can't actually see what I am supposed to be doing. Sometimes because of this I felt myself almost "button-mashing" especially in the River of Styx sections when there are lots of small rats. The music rocks, with tens of in-game poems that you can buy and listen to. The fact that all the dialogue is fully voiced is amazing as well.


Replayability, Value for Money and Extra Content 10/10

The game is designed to have hundreds of hours of replayability. With an insane amount of extra side content and variety between runs, I can see how you could easily get hundreds of hours in the game and not get bored.


Innovation, Impact and Technical Execution - 9.7/10

The game innovates on the roguelite genre massively, and has greated a major impact in the gaming landscape. This game will have a major impact on all future roguelikes and roguelites. I very rarely encountered any bugs or issues, both on PC and Xbox. The only issue is that if the game crashes, or your PC crashes, or your power cuts, then the game treats it like a "Give Up" and sends you back to the start of the run, which happened to me multiple times while playing. This was probably on purpose to prevent cheating from save-scumming, but since this is a solo game it detracts from the game instead. The game feels great to handle, both on controller and on K+M.


Overall - 93/100 - There Is No Escape...

An incredibly experience, that was a blast but went out as a fizzle. With an amazing replayable game, as long as you don't play to finish the story and just play to enjoy the game you will have an incredible time. Truly an exceptional game...

Hades is the first roguelike, or "roguelite" if you'd rather; I've ever played, and it definitely left an impression. A beautiful art style, a banging soundtrack, a story with complex characters well-drawn. A truly great story is always about now, and though its characters may be pulled from Hesiod and Homer, it tells a modern tale of family, fate, and finding purpose in a futile struggle.

As you battle the wretches of the underworld in top-down isometric hack-and-slash style, striving to escape your grim and harsh father, the god of the dead, you are presented with a variety of boons from the gods of Olympus. These are modifiers that change your abilities or boost your stats, all themed to the various gods. These can take the form of; the chain lightning of Zeus,the surging knockback effects of Poseidon, or the poison DOT effect of Dionysus.  These In combination with 6 different weapons, all of which have 4 different aspects, leads to a huge variety in build composition and approach. Sometimes you'll struggle; other times, you either, through luck or strategic planning, feel it all click together as you send the assembled minions of the underworld to an even deeper part of hell.

The real secret sauce is the synthesis of narrative and gameplay; there's no Ludo-narrative dissonance here. Your struggles as a player mirror the struggles of the Prince as a character, and thanks to an astonishing amount of excellently voice-acted dialogue, failure stops feeling like an end state and becomes just another part of the journey as you are greeted by unique interactions with the characters that populate the House of Hades each time you return.

"One must imagine Sisyphus happy," well, no imagination is needed here. You'll see the grin on your own Sisyphean face reflected on your screen as you toil endlessly against the legions of the underworld only to end up back where you started, promising yourself "Just one more run."
In the name of Hades, you need to play this game.

It's a very solid action rougelite with great visuals, good power/skill progression, great music and a great story that unfolds over potentially 100+ runs as you engage with steady conversations with the many cast members.

The one I feel iffy about is the isometric camera angle. It can make it a bit difficult to keep track of all the foes and projectiles on screen at any given moment, which can be a huge run-ender for players who are trying to learn the general gameplay loop and foe/boss patterns.

I stalled on this for way too long...

I liked Bastion.  Transistor seemed ok, but I never quite seemed like my style.

This one though... is a whole different beast.  Aside from the great combat mechanics, they really work the whole dying/trying-again deeply into the story.  So much so, in fact, that "beating" the game is only the start, in a way.  I'm ~57 hours in at this point, and still have tons of unlocks and story to still discover!

10/10 - if you like roguelites at all, believe the hype here.

Easily the best rougelike I've ever played. Gameplay stays interesting on every runthrough, with boon builds a fresh challenge each time. Progression rewards are satisfying but not overly powered, so there's always a craving for the next "thing". Plenty of content beyond "beating the game" too, so it keeps scratching that itch even after the main storyline is complete.

Also, the most beautiful game to play, ever. Stunning graphics and art design, consistent all the way through, with gorgeous character design and so many lovely settings. The soundtrack is often haunting and soothing at the same time, then seamlessly bursts into an invigorating fight sequence. It's easy to get lost in just the glamour of the game's aesthetics.

Finally, it's also an incredibly attentively researched storyline, incorporating mythological characters and stories in a delightfully unique retelling. You'll see mainstream gods alongside some of the lesser known figures, each with their own personalities and bonuses to offer.

Definitely check this one out, it's not to be missed.

This game takes the best elements of modern rougelites and combines them with a compelling linear narrative, to create an experience that is enjoyable to hardcore fans of the genre, while remaining highly accessible to newcomers. The gameplay is fast and fluid, with runs feeling distinct and varied, and the meta-progression system helps to soften the blow when you do inevitably die. This all goes without praising the art direction and voice acting, which gives a sense of immersion rarely seen in this genre. this game is a genuine masterpiece, and an absolute must play for fans of action rougelikes, and newcomers alike.

Beautiful game with probably the most charismatic art, voice, and music amongst any video game title.
So why the thumbs down?
The gameplay loop can be repetitive and downright tedious.
If you arent good enough to beat the game by your 2nd or 3rd try you are subjected to playing 40minute loops just to get 50 out of the 500 <input currency> you need for an upgrade to make you stronger, and hopefully carry your a bit further. Unfortunately getting a little bit further doesnt really mean anything. Getting to the next boss probably means you are getting 5% more currency. 

Whats worse is that the bosses pretty much turn into damage sponges that fill up the screen with AoE, which will have you spamming your dash button.

The ending is unique and downright wholesome..until its completely ruined by the fact you have the beat the game 5+ times to get the full ending. Endings 2-4 just have you going back and forth passing notes along. Basically meaning that a 5 minute ending is expanded by having you play 10 more hours. 

If you are one of those individuals that accidentally made it to the last boss your first time you played, this probably doesnt apply to you. But if you are player that needed meta upgrades to progress, it can be joyless adventure.

I have spent so so much time playing this game (and gotten a few others to play it) because it is an absolute masterpiece. The art, the music, the voice acting, and most importantly the gameplay is just so well done. It is engaging and fun without feeling too repetitive, even when you run out of story because you've played through literally the whole game and all the quests and prophecies... I'm just working on unlocking the themes for fun now ;)

The character storylines are incredibly well written, my favorite is probably Achilles and Patroclus but I'm biased because I love both greek tragedies and queer romance. 

And of course the most important thing to know about this game; Yes you can pet the dog! Cerberus loves neck scritches <3

This is my favourite rouge-like of all time that I will judge future rouge-likes that I will play against. The story is simple yet heartwarming. You're basically the relationship therapist for the entire Greek mythology family. It's a lot of grinding to get these characters back together and I feel like it is very worth it.

The gameplay is simple to learn, but can be hard to master if you really want to get down to the tiny details. You get a variety of weapons to choose from and honestly you only just need to use the one you enjoy the most if all you care about is the story. You will die quite a lot at the beginning and like all rouge-likes, the RNG you get can make or break your run, this is especially true in the early game or late game pact of punishment. I remembered my 3rd or 4th escape attempt I got such good RNG that I managed to reach the final boss before eventually dying. But no run is wasted as you will be grinding out currencies to upgrade your talent tree and make your future runs easier. Each run you do will always be different which makes things feel fresh. I enjoy the fact that anyone of any skill level can play and finish this game. Of course, the game rewards skill by rewarding harder clears and you can reach goals faster but for the most part, if you're a casual player, you can still finish the epilogue with no issues. The pact of punishment is unlocked after your first clear but is completely optional if difficulty is not something you are interested in.

The characters are very well written. There are so many dialogues that each character can say to you depending on your save file. (for example I didn't know that Hermes will comment on how you broke your clear streak until I broke my 15 clear streak T_T) Small details like this is what makes this game charming. I enjoy how it feels like the characters are reacting to what or how you're doing, feels lively. 

There is a lot of replayablity in this game. Once you complete your first escape, you have to do it 10 more times to get the ending. Then you have to grind even more times to get the true ending. The game doesnt stop once you get the ending. There is just so much to do.

I originally bought this game because of the art style. I never played any rouge-likes before so I had nothing to judge it on. But after playing so much, I started liking rouge-likes more so I expanded my library. I now play more rouge-likes but at the back of my mind, I will always judge it against Hades. The art is amazing, great colour theory, great lining style, reminds me of comic books a little... The music is so hyped. It's a mix of metal music for some of the boss fights. I listen to the soundtrack in my day top day life to hype myself up.

TL;DR:
Art 10/10
Music 10/10
Game Feel 10/10
Overall 10/10

P.S I love Thanatos <3

Overall well put together game but i don't think i'd recommend this game to anyone as the genre has really advanced and other games do it better(game play wise not graphics this game looks fantastic). 

The drawback and the reason I don't recommend is the game is that it's too balanced(hear me out)  because you are limited from a lot of content and upgrades early on and getting them unlocked is quite the time investment and as you progress you have to raise the difficulty to keep that progression and never feel like you are getting anywhere.  I put in a ton of hours on console and recently re downloaded to steam to get back into it starting from scratch and it's rough. 

The only way to be successful out the gate is to play like it's a dark souls and be extremely defensive which isn't the optimal way to grind out the materials for the good upgrades so it's counter intuitive. You end up not playing to win but just grind for materials. What makes it tough early on? the builds are very balanced... too balanced, so much so getting the rouguelike OP god build is near impossible, when you do find a good combo they require the boons/upgrades to be very high LVL AND high rarity to progress. Higher rarity is very similar to being higher lvl but you can get higher rarity only from RNG(and one other way with limited use) while the levels require specific drops and you start at lvl 1 no matter what. You can improve your RNG but only after purchasing the right upgrades.

In addition a lot of abilities don't stack like you would want them too likely due to balance. Example you can unlock an upgrade that turns your basic attack into projectiles AND get a boon that turns your basic attack into chain lightning on hit. one might think now the projectiles from the attack also count and create lightning on each hit but they don't only the initial attack(the initial swing in melee range) will proc this sadly. They have no interaction and this come sup a lot in this game. Hoping the next installment will let things get a little more out of hand with the right luck and play into the rogue like fantasy. After all even the most OP run must come to an end.

Way too overhyped, this game has huge issues hidden behind the mirage of great artworks, with the largest issue amongst them, that you interact with the most... the combat.

---Pros---
Artwork, Music

---Cons---
-Game Progression: The game is desperately trying to keep you in the loop with new encounters. Once the new additions to the game are done, you have to repeat hours and hours of randomized runs for a small piece of the story. By design you progress by dying and are rewarded for dying.
-Story: The story is literally copy pasted from greek mythology, so its only interesting if you were dozing off in history class. Other than that, due to the story itself and the writers portraying it in a twisted way, most of the dialogues (90%+) are filled with hatred against your character aimed to annoy, berate and drag you through the mud as much as possible. Instead of being stoic and focused on the actions of the characters with less words, its just a twitter drama comment section.
-Game Design: You have 3 specific win conditions in the form of powers from gods. If you are unable to get any of those 3 specific powers by the half point of the game, it's better to kill your character and not waste any more time. (Note: you lose all achievements and progress you've made during the run for pressing the "give up" button in the menu). By the half point of the game you probably picked up some powers from other gods and by game design you are more likely to get powers from them, instead of a new god. There's no point in trying for another 10-15 minutes only to have no chance of "winning". You could start a new run and be back to where you were with better RNG.
-Long combat animations/input lag: both of them combined lead to a frustrating and clunky gameplay that are outperformed by classics made in the early 2000s or even some NS games 40 years back..
-Combat: You have to aim and dodge the shadows on the ground 50-100pixels below the enemies/projectiles. Your character has full hitbox together with its shadow, but the enemies (even bosses) have a tiny small circle below them for hitting no matter how large they are.
-Dodging: You have to dodge the enemy's "charged attack" animation where they "slowly" become completely white before attacking, instead of actually dodging its attack. If the enemy charged up their attack and you are in the way, you are 100% getting damaged. There are no iframe dodges, no immunity, if your character hitbox is in the way of an attack, you get hit. There's no last moment dodge.

For the first 20 hours I would give Hades a more or less solid thumbs up. The story is somewhat interesting and the character voicelines are pretty good. The gameplay is simplistic but fun for what it is. Early on the game shows its very grindy nature though expecting you to constantly go through the same sections over and over in the attempt to beat it while your character somewhat slowly becomes stronger from certain buffs.

Once you beat the game for the first time and the advanced options show up is when it completely falls apart for me as Hades literally forces an awful grind on you if you want to continue. After escaping the underworld for the first time the game unlocks a heat mechanic which provides additional difficulties and rewards. Unfortunately all of the rewards are always weapon and difficulty specific. That means you have to complete the game at least 6 times on the first difficulty to unlock the rewards for all weapons. Then you have to repeat it for heat 1, heat 2 and so on. Every run can take over an hour. So you can see how Hades pads its gametime through an endless grind while trying to hide it somewhat bethind story bits and pieces after each run through character interactions in the house.

The story is not that exciting to successfully masquerade the grind for me though and Hades became just a tedious bore for me when the patterns became clear.

If you are looking for something to give you a pure adrenaline rush experience then this is one of those games. Along with it's action, it has a very interesting story with really good dialogue and voice acting. Before each run, you can purchase permanent upgrades using items which make your run a little easier and make you feel a sense of progress but at the same time having everything maxed out still keeps you on edge because of how unique each run is. Not only does it randomize maps but it also introduces new enemies or patterns as you progress. I like the diversity of weapons to choose from as it allows you to choose according to your play style and your preference for boons. There is a huge possibility of builds you can create in this game. The only drawback I would say is the fact that the boss fights aren't the most memorable. They are satisfying to beat but I wish each had a more unique personality to their attacks.

It's a very tightly design game, enemies are tough but fair, everything is very readable and demands just enough of your reflexes to keep you engaged, decision making is fairly important, and in between zones they brake down the themes explored with an appropriate boss battle. Just all around a fantastic game, must play if you are into rogue-likes/lites.

( !!! Minor Spoiler ahead, I talk about characters appearing in the ending); Edit after beating the game and watching the credits roll, the game culminates in a very powerful note, with some of the best hard hitting dialog lines shared between the King, Queen and Prince of darkness after a beautiful and enchanting song, the endgame explanation of letting you keep trying to brake free from the underworld is quite appealing and smart, and they give you total freedom + even more voice acted character dialog, i seriously cannot get enough of this game. I cannot wait to see what mythologies and gameplay mechanics will be explored in Hades II, since there is some room for more weapons and perks to be designed.

I'll end my review by saying that Super Giant Games was not on my radar before even after hearing about Bastion and other cool games they did, but they defensively hooked me right in, they seem to be a bunch of very talented and creative people who actually care about their creations, and I appreciate that.

First rogue-like |'ve ever played and I've been incredibly addicted, to the point I've paused playing Baldurs Gate 3. Music, art style and the use of Greek Mythology in the story are all so well done and creative. The gameplay is also so balanced and nuanced, that dying and starting over is something you look forward to. It creates an addictive and satisfying loop of fighting, dying, and strategising with delicious god drama inbetween.

It makes you feel like Tom Cruise from Edge of Tomorrow.

Even for a noob at gaming like me, the godmode has made it possible for me to enjoy the game while also feeling like I am getting better at it. It is intuitive, but spamming buttons and making good boon choices will also get you there. Many challenging elements for those who want to make it way harder for themselves than necessary would they want to, plenty easier methods for those who want to enjoy the storyline and progress slowly as a simple game they play sometimes to destress. I recommend it.

My brother told me this was a great game, and I believed him. The awards said this was a great game, and I believed them too.

But it wasn't until I played the game that it really sunk in how great this game was. The gameplay is polished to a mirror sheen, its graphics beautiful and imaginative, the music transports you to hell and back, in a good way.

You'd think a game based around failing to get out of hell over and over again would be demotivating, but the combination of the main characters attitude and well-written dialogue just keep you going. Even when the game keeps telling you that you won't escape, it makes you all the more determined to prove it wrong, to an almost addictive extent.

I absolutely recommend this game.

Don't trust the tags. Hades isn't actually a roguelike game. It has immense number of upgrades in-between runs that turn the game from almost unbeatable on the first run to braindead beatable every single run. The game becomes so easy that you need to make runs more difficult with Heat mechanics. Beating the game on higher heat gives you further rewards that allows to get even more upgrades.

I respect the idea of managing game's difficulty on your own, but due to the facts that runs are rather short, in-between runs upgrades provide shit ton of value, and lack of actual combat content (~25 enemies & 4(5) bosses) this game is just not for me. Felt bad grinding in-game currency in a game that is supposed to be roguelike.

Over glorified roulette

If you are unlucky and get only shitty boons from the beginning there is no way you sell your boons and get something better further in the game. R in RNG is not that random, as there is no chance to get a strong build if the game doesn't want you to have it. If you get shitty boons from the beginning you will get them all the way until you die. So if you don't have a decent build before the first boss just die and start from scratch.
If you have 3 resurrections left, go to shop and 2 out of 3 items replenish one resurrection. Why TF do i need it if resurrections are full? If you have 0 resurrections, you won't get a resurrection replenishing item in a lifetime.

No tutorial AT ALL. You see a chest with some currency? Open it and you will be attacked by a wave of mobs. You had 10HP when opened it? oopsie you should've known that opening the chest starts another fight for some shitty currency you can get anyway. You encountered the currency for the first time and have no idea what it is for? your problem.

"Story" and "quests" are a fking joke. You need to go to every NPC dozens of time just to listen absolutely irrelevant gibberish from each of them. Talked to an NPC? you will have to do it again next time you die.

If you want to feel like a brainless zombie doing the same shit over and over again with some RNG this game is for you

A very well-crafted rouge-lite. 
The most important part is that the core gameplay is fun, and with the incentives to keep switching gear and trying new things, it does not get stale. 
There is a large depth in many mechanics, and there were many times when I did something and then discovered that that was merely one aspect or way of doing the thing. 
The art is beautiful, the music is great, and there are so many voice lines for the different characters that it starts to feel like they are actually reacting to what's happening, and there are many surprisingly funny moments in the writing.
It works great on the steam deck as well.
And yes, you can pet the dog.

Hades is one of the best games I've ever played. Its ancient Greek mythology rouge like. All the characters feel original and different. I've talked to them 50+ times and they say something new basically every time. Story lines feel like you have to put in effort but not really feel like a huge grind.  And like most rouge likes it has huge replay ability. If your bored playing with the sword you can equip one of the other 5 weapons. There are many different boons that vastly change the way you play. All the gods boons have there own theme going on. Poseidon has knock back, Artemis has crit chance, ect. you could play this game a  thousand time and never get the same build twice.s (Warning spoilers ahead.) If your starting to get bored by how easy the game use the pact of punishment to have 15+ different ways to get harder. And even after all that you think that the game does not have enough weapons you would be wrong. after enough runs and meeting certain requirements you unlock 2 new ways to play that weapon. One of my favorite games of all time. The combat is simple but challenging, forcing you to learn what builds work best for your play style. The art style is really eye catching, the sound design is great (especially the voice acting). The difficulty might be an issue for some but every run helps you get stronger. Whether its from unlocking new abilities, skills, or just learning patterns of enemies. The ability for replay is there due to the nature of how the game is designed. It encourages multiple runs and with the decent weapon count, you'll want to try them all out. So many cool secrets to find along the way. Hades II can't come fast enough.

This is THE rougelite rogue-like. RNG can be a bit rough, but there are so many ways to play. 

There is a wide range of variety that keeps each run fresh: weapon types, of which there are 24; daedalus hammer upgrades that change the way weapons function; boons that add abilities, both active and passive, have different rarity levels, and they can interact with each other, which unlocks duo boons; artifacts that add bonuses to various things like increased boon rarity, additional HP, stronger attacks in certain situations, etc; mirror of night upgrades, which do things like give you additional dashes and casts, or change the way death defiance (a limited number of 'extra lives' before you die and start over) acts; my last example, the pact of punishment, or heat level, which can be used to add different types of difficulty to a run.

Then, we get to the story, which has plenty of depth, can advance relationships with many of the characters, and unlocks active ability trinkets gifted by advancing some of those relationships.

I'm 140 hours in and I haven't explored the entire game. Sometimes I just get caught up in figuring out new ways to make a specific weapon capable of a beat down. I put just as many hours into playing on the steam deck as I have on my PC. Game play is flawless either way.

If you enjoy rogue-like games, this should be in your library.

Hades, a game i've seen many sing the praises of. Finally giving it a shot it is probably one of the best games ive ever played. Already bein a fan of rougelikes like Deadcells & TBOI, I was very excited to dive into the experience. While I have seen gameplay in the past I never dove too deep into it since I knew eventually i'd play it, and wow. The feel of the game is just not something i've experienced before and it just felt so good. The unique artstyle, amazing character designs, fluid gameplay and astounding soundtrack really fuse into something really fantastic. I felt immediately immersed into the experience and seein what Zagreus was goin through. On top of that all the special interactions between the gods & other characters is really fun and intresting. One of my main concerns though for the gameplay which is one I know from many rougelikes is repetitiveness. I personally do not mind gameplay loops but others do find it a bit boresom. From playing i've seen their are so many different combinations of weapons, boons, weapon upgrades and keepsakes that really shift up how you play. It truly is a great experience doing one run with a sword focused on raw damage & lifesteal, to goin to a spear zipping around with lightning strikes. Genuinely I love this experience and would highly recommend others give this game a try, especially if you're a fan of rougelikes. Truly an amazing experience so far, can't wait to delve deeper into the game.

I somehow slept on this game when it was first released. A few years ago, one of my friends, who is much more of a gamer than I am, was telling me about some games he wanted to try and Hades was one of them. After that conversation, I immediately went onto the Nintendo store from my Switch and purchased the game. After first run through, my skepticism melted faster than an ice cube on an Arizona sidewalk. I have 150+ hours logged on the Switch version and I can confidently say this was one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had.

The fast paced game play is buttery smooth and only get's better as Zagreus becomes stronger. The game's design is impressive in it's own right; from the story-telling, all the way down to the game menus. It was obvious after the first few hours how much love, dedication, and craftsmanship went into this game. Don't sleep on it like I did.

One of the best things in this game is its replay value, different builds, depending on the BOONS you select (from different gods :  Zeus, Dionysus, Atena, Ares, Demeter etc ). Overall I would say this game is top notch in its game design, and is a must have for people who enjoy the rogue-like genre. (very immersive gaming experience)

At first I was having fun with gameplay loop, until I began having these weird runs again and again where either garbage boons kept dropping or hardly anything at all. I got to hades 2nd form after my 20th run and it dawned on me, I don't actually like roguelikes. I hate games that center around rng now. So Hades is great if you like rng and fun combat, but for me.. something clicked and i dont like this genre anymore. no offense to people, i just cant take it anymore.

One thing that pissed me off alot which might actually be the reason I quit, is that you have to talk to npcs and interact. You can skip alot, but its really frustrating when you lost a good run and need to watch a slow death scene and zip past everything mashing dodge to restart. I would have loved if there was a simple retry and go from the start right away. I dont care for the story at all, and it sucks having to listen to it sometimes when you get pissed at losing a run. Its like a slap in the face and you have to suffer this right after.

Game is absolutely phenomenal. Anyway, here's how you can make a Black Forest Cake.

Ingredients
Cake:

2 ⅛ cups all-purpose flour

2 cups white sugar

¾ cup unsweetened cocoa powder

1 ½ teaspoons baking powder

¾ teaspoon baking soda

¾ teaspoon salt

3 eggs

1 cup milk

½ cup vegetable oil

1 tablespoon vanilla extract

Topping:

2 (20 ounce) cans pitted sour cherries

1 cup white sugar

¼ cup cornstarch

1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Frosting:

3 cups heavy whipping cream

⅓ cup confectioners' sugar

Directions
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease and flour two 9-inch round cake pans; line bottoms with parchment paper. Place a medium bowl in the refrigerator to chill.

Whisk flour, sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Add eggs, milk, oil, and vanilla; beat until combined. Pour cake batter into the prepared pans.

Bake in the preheated oven until a toothpick inserted in the centers comes out clean, about 35 minutes. Cool layers in pans on wire racks for 10 minutes. Run a paring knife around edges to loosen and invert carefully onto racks to cool completely, 1 to 2 hours.

While cake layers bake, drain cherries for topping, reserving 1/2 cup juice. Combine reserved juice, cherries, sugar, and cornstarch in a 2-quart saucepan. Cook, stirring constantly, over low heat until thickened. Stir in vanilla. Let cool at room temperature for 30 minutes. Transfer to the refrigerator to cool completely before assembling cake.

Combine whipping cream and confectioners' sugar for frosting in the chilled medium bowl. Beat with an electric mixer at high speed until stiff peaks form.

Split each cake layer in half horizontally using a long serrated knife. Tear one layer into crumbs; set aside. Gently brush loose crumbs off top and sides of remaining layers using a pastry brush or your hands. Reserve 1 1/2 cups frosting for piping decorations on cake; set aside.

To assemble, place one cake layer on a cake plate. Spread with 1 cup frosting; top with 3/4 cup cherry topping. Top with second cake layer; repeat layers of frosting and cherry topping. Top with third cake layer and frost sides of cake.

Pat reserved cake crumbs onto sides of cake. Spoon reserved 1 1/2 cups frosting into a pastry bag fitted with a star decorator tip. Pipe around top and bottom edges of cake. Spoon remaining cherry topping on top of cake.

Store covered in the refrigerator until ready to serve.

This game is fantastic. It's a lot of fun, has a lot of different ways to do runs, and gives a much more real sense of progress than most roguelites. It also has a great story and characters. I'm excited for the sequel, but honestly I'm probably not going to be done with this one when it comes out.

Easily among my top 10 favorite games of all time, and probably sits in my top 10 most played when adding time played on PC and Playstation. Nearly everything about this game radiates quality. The story is very entertaining and emotionally compelling, and the narrative is in perfect congruence with the gameplay. The voice acting is on par with my favorite RPGS, with so many unique lines of dialogue that I only stopped hearing new ones after well over 150 hours on a single save file. The artwork is fantastic, especially shining in the enemy designs and weapon movesets. Portraits ooze the personality of the character speaking, and I can't think of one I thought was lazy or a poor fit for the character. The music is great, I think the final boss music is the best example of how much the music adds to the game. The twangs at the beginning begin to invoke anticipation rather than nervousness, and whenever the theme comes on in my playlist I get a shiver that is only matched by Wake Up Mr. West transitioning into Heard 'Em Say. And when you've mastered the fight, the Extreme Measures version of the song jarringly ramps up, perfectly coinciding with a panic the player is almost certainly succumbing to. But thats all fluff at the end of the day, as most of my time with the game was spent doing repeated runs with 10 aspects listening to Destiny debates or blasting my own music, and those are my favorite memories of the game. 
The reasons I kept playing for several hundred hours after acquiring the platinum trophy were the genius Heat system, the variety and flexibility of builds, and the fundamentally excellent mechanics. The heat system is a collection of difficulty modifiers that unlock after clearing the first run, which range from basic stat modifications (take more damage, face more enemies, enemies move and attack faster, etc), to adding a time limit to every zone, to giving every boss more health and a majorly enhanced moveset (and dialogue). Each modifier has a Heat value, granting more resources when escaping at higher and higher Heat ranks. There are also 3 trophies you walk past before starting a run, each being unveiled at 8, 16 and 32 heat respectively. Most difficulty modifiers are manageable on their own even when maxed out (except routine inspection), mixing them to reach 32 heat can become unbearable though. So far I have cleared 32 heat with all 4 aspects of the Bow, 2 aspects of the Shield, 2 aspects of the Adamant Rail, and 1 aspect each for Stygius, the Twin Fists and the Eternal spear. Each one of those aspects plays very differently from the next. Unfortunately not every weapon has a selection as excellent as the bow, with the fists especially standing out with only one great aspect, that of Demeter. Every aspect can have a great build come together with clever usage of RNG manipulation and the right upgrades however, and the best aspects have many viable builds. Merciful End with divine dash and Doom on the attack is good on basically anything, but shines with the swords special/dash attack combo, instantly triggering and dealing doom damage with every dash attack. A crit build is also hard to mess up, working well with fast hitting and slow hitting weapons alike. Zeus attack/call with aphrodite special and their duo boon is a winner with the aspect of Demeter or Eris rail, fast hitting chain lightning being able to clear whole rooms and having very easy access to a very powerful damage dealer on an automatic cooldown. Eris especially so with Cluster Rockets, easily capable of killing the Heroes of Elysium in under 30 seconds. Any chunky cast with some Duo boons centered around cast damage will contribute to the highest damage numbers you'll ever witness with the aspect of Hera and Beowulf. A build can be built around practically every Duo or legendary boon however, and the variety is part of why grinding dozens of high heat runs was so bearable. It doesn't hurt that every boss becomes incredibly fun once you learn their moves and figure out which moves you can exploit for huge damage uptime on the boss. Extreme measures and Middle management keep the fights more engaging and varied, as well as learning to fight every boss when they are swing and moving up to 40% faster (depending on your heat modifiers). Bosses in most games become fairly boring after repeated kills, with every souls game until Bloodborne and Ds3 being especially egregious in my experience. The bosses in Hades hold up on a second encounter though, and Meg holds up even on my 300th. Smacking around basic enemies becomes incredibly rewarding when you become skilled enough to lock down entire groups of enemies, clearing entire biomes only getting hit in mini boss or boss encounters. Movesets are very well telegraphed with a handful of exceptions in elysium particularly, but most enemies can be reasonably dodged even with 40% extra attack speed. Benefits package (a heat modifier that gives armored enemies special abilities) makes every encounter meaningfully different from the previous chamber, adding many more things to worry about and counter. Rooms rarely start to feel unfair before pumping the Heat meter past 20, but some nasty combinations can start to cause problems especially in (again) elysium.
Aside from some issues with RNG not giving you a specific upgrade needed for a build or some overwhelming enemy layouts forcing you to lose a death defiance, the game is incredibly polished. Most games with great dialogue or stories have boring combat (The witcher trilogy) and most games with great gameplay have boring stories (Sekiro). Games like God of War and Hades that excel in most areas are a rarity, and it easily cements Hades as one of the most well rounded games I've ever played. Banger.

Hades is a beautiful fast paced hack & slasher with tons of meta and story progression.

It's really fun to play, even if you're bad at these types of games (like me). Combat is very smooth and the update system adds tons of different builds and allows for both melee and ranged play styles. The weapons also change your combat style quite a lot and each of them can be modified even further which delivers a lot of replayability.

Gfx, sound, music and voice acting is outstanding. Almost every time you'd encounter any of the gods (your 'family'), you're given dialogs that progress based on how far you got and what you've done previous or current run. It's amazing how much voice acting is in this game. And if you're not interested in all that flavor text, it's easy to skip.

I played this game after rage quitting Sekiro which was way too tough for me.  (Not that this game isn't challenging.  It's not easy, but it's fair.)  This was a great palate cleanser.  It is easy to learn but hard to master.  The graphics are super crispy and smooth, the music is great and justifies the vinyl release, the writing and dialogue is great and the amount of it is astounding.  The voice over work is top notch with a great dash of comedy thrown in.  I found it really refreshing not having to devote a thumb to moving a darn camera around.  This game reminded me of an evolved version of Gauntlet and of the great SNES games I played as a young thug.
I killed hades

Heard lots of great things about this game, but knew nothing about it. Picked it up on sale and man this is an absolute gem. I don't normally like rogue-like games, but Hades' gameplay loop is really addicting. Combat is very responsive, plays great on mouse and keyboard, and is one of the very few games where I can visibly see myself getting better through repetition.

The first 5 or so hours felt a bit frustrating, but really happy I stuck with it because everything started to click. Got my first clear on attempt 25, and it was just a total "aha" moment -- had a streak of a bunch more clears from the first. The upgrade system (boons, hammers, poms, etc.) started to make more sense, "Builds" started to become clear (e.g., which boons go well together with which weapons). It's a really unique loop that most games don't have.

Aside from mechanics and gameplay, the story story is really captivating. Artwork and music are also outstanding. Definitely recommend even if not on sale, well worth the asking price.

It's a good game. Tight gameplay, nice art style and soundtrack, good voice acting and writing.

My problem with the game is that the level variety, enemy variety, and boss variety are just not there at all. Not by a long shot. With the amount of runs you need to do to unlock everything, the game gets pretty old pretty fast. I do like the weapon and item variety though. Boon variety is alright. 
I'm hoping the sequel can improve on the content and make each run more dynamic compared to the last. 

Also, the game was a bit easy in my opinion. I know it has a built in difficulty slider, which I did use, but the bounty system encourages a very slow and gradual increase in the difficulty slider. Doing that, I was beating the final boss nearly every single time. Out of 57 runs, I escaped 33 times. With the majority of the fails being either in the beginning before unlocking weapons and items, or at the final boss. After that, I started failing runs on purpose to speed up the process of unlocking content. 
I'm conflicted on the process of unlocking stuff. It's random. In some ways I like it, but it does require a grind if you're going for a specific thing, and that's not fun. 

I found myself constantly comparing it to Binding of Isaac. Which I've only played the original and early versions of Rebirth. But Isaac usually came out on top in my mind. 

Anyway, it is still a fun game. Great game.

Very cool! Combat system, story line, graphics, design - everything about this game is REALLY well done. Game is difficult to beat and super satisfying when you finally progress. System is designed around main character resurrecting every time you fail, and you have to start from the beginning. The catch is that you start just a little stronger with each consequentive run. Game doesn't get boring though, because you can alter your weapon, artifact and build unique skill composition/weapong upgrades every time you start over. The possibilities are endless and so is the fun. Strongly recommend and cant wait for Hades 2!

Hades: the underworld's ultimate roguelike rave! Gorgeous art, epic fights, and enough twists to make Greek mythology jealous. It's like an 'Escape from Hell' holiday with a sassy Zagreus as your guide. 10/10, would forge alliances with gods again! This game redefines 'Hell' as the coolest place to be. this game is too fast. for example, why are you allowed to dodge while simultaneously attacking? the dodging animation itself has basically 0 startup frames and 0 recovery frames. it's just so. fucking. fast. the choices for designing the dash reflect on everything else I don't like about this game. it's not that the dash is the problem, but the developers used the same mentality for designing the dash to design everything else in the game, and that's the best way to summarize my opinion of this game. I just don't feel the weight of each button press like I do in other action games. every input feels so meaningless and inconsequential. it's not fun. maybe for some people, being really fast is fun. for me, being really fast is very boring.

that brings me to one last criticism - the game is built under the assumption that the player will eventually start speedrunning it. that's the endgame of hades. speedrunning. that's the most difficult content in this game. if you plan to play this game for 1k hours, expect to be a speedrunner at the end of it all. if you don't like the sound of that, then this is absolutely not the game for you. 

the game's main adventure is fun and was definitely a positive experience, but at the end of it all I can not stand to think about playing another run. even on high heat I am finding myself being bored.

A great product worth the price of admission. Does a lot to keep the roguelite format interesting, and there's challenges and rests for players who want a bit more challenge. The storytelling is also great - a story that can only be told in this format. I think a story that you already know where it's going is severely under-appreciated these days - so often people go crazy over a twist ending, when sometimes a straightforward story well-told is all you need.

And I think that's just as well. The game is fairly straightforward - Hades sets out to do one thing really well and succeeds with style.

Hades, the rogue-like dungeon crawler by Supergiant Games, emerges as a visually captivating and narratively rich experience. The game's stunning graphics, dynamic combat, and seamless integration of Greek mythology create an immersive journey into the underworld. The addictive gameplay, blending challenging rogue-lite elements with a rewarding progression system, ensures players keep coming back for more. Hades stands as a triumphant masterpiece, It's a journey into the depths leaves a lasting impression, solidifying its place as a modern classic.

I was going through my Steam Replay for 2023. This was one of my most played games this year, and I can't believe I hadn't written a review for it before, considering I played it back in May. This game CONSUMED about a month of my life and I lost many hours of sleep with the "just one more run" mentality. The artstyle is perfect, the gameplay is smooth and seamless and the ost is one of the best in recent memory, I adore this game. Also, pretty much every character is hot, so...

Rogue-lite perfected. Amazing story, breathtaking art, fantastic voice acting, with engaging and complex gameplay. Characters are funny, well written, and you actually want to talk to them. Seeing each little story arc and decision change your environment, interactions with other characters, and new items is rewarding and gets you truly invested in the story and lives of the characters. 

Unlocking new skills and cosmetics for the house keeps you thinking 'just 1 more run' and the heat system makes repeated escape attempts fun and customisable to how you want to play. Each run feels unique with the multitude of weapons and hundreds of boons to choose from, with lots of options that totally switch up the gameplay, allowing you to piece together crazy combos and find builds that fit with your playstyle. Could not recommend it enough and can't wait for Hades II!

[h1]The game is a good game, but the media overhyped it.[/h1]

  As a roguelike game, the early performance of this game is still quite gorgeous.  The exquisite character visual effects and the sexy voice of the voice actor are enough to be a masterpiece.
  But if you play it for a bit longer, you’ll find that compared to other ‘roguelike’ games, this one falls short in terms of gameplay.  The beautiful graphics result in fewer scenes in the game, and there are not many bosses.  You may also notice that the art style of some monsters does not match the background.
  These flaws lead to players purely speeding up the game for the sake of clearing levels, so how can we extend the playtime?  The game requires players to ‘clear’ multiple times to reach the true ending, but the rewards each time a player clears are less satisfying compared to similar games.  Over time, this can lead to dissatisfaction with the game design, especially when seeing Greek mythological characters with strange skin colors.
  In other games, you see the ending after repeated failures and finally succeeding. However, in this game, you are required to repeatedly succeed to see the ending. This game design reflects a lack of game content and also reduces the player’s interest.
  As similar games continue to update and add content, this highly publicized game has not changed much, which is disappointing.
[strike] If you don’t mind the game featuring mythological characters with strange skin colors, then I recommend waiting for a discount to purchase it.
  I believed the media hype and bought this game a long time ago, but it was a terrible experience back then, so I definitely wouldn't give it a good review. [/strike]

-The Hydra Boss Fight, felt really easy and I beat that thing first try. became a really big pain in the ass to fight him at times. as a boss fight which was shown in the promotion trailer, I feel like he should have been way more fun to fight and harder. his different versions were not very special ether. 

-lack of reward, When you beat a boss you get these... artifacts or items, which are used too.... do what again? so the boss fight with Meg and her two other sisters on Tartarus give you the ability to upgrade weapon aspects. The Hydra Diamond on Asphodel was used for what? the commisions to build stuff... but like I am not grinding to do that... which brings me to my next point, to get more of these artifacts you need to beat the boss with diffrent types of wepons. This just makes me not want to do them at all. 

-the spear is clearly broken. idk why use anything else 

-----conclusion-------

I'm no big fan of rogue-likes, but this one is the exception. It has the Supergiant "touch" of high-quality art, game design, music, VO and writing. What stands out to me is how it both honors Greek mythology and makes it accessible and fun.

Hades is a very addicting game. I was relatively inexperienced with roguelike games before Hades, so I was worried the game would get repetitive. This turned out not be the case (at least for the first 50 hours). For one, Hades is a challenging game, so it will take some time until you develop the skill and knowledge to consistently reach the higher levels. Also, Hades consistently throws new mechanics and weapons your way. But the thing that makes this game so addicting is the fact that random drops from the gods helping you means that no two runs are the same (usually).

The core gameplay loop is fun and addicting, but it is everything else alongside it that makes this game really worth checking out. Excellent supporting characters. Excellent music. Excellent character and environment design. Great story. I am looking forward to Hades II.
