Hades is one of the easiest games to pick up and get used to yet it is very difficult to master and the developer was masterfully able to turn this into the main strength of the game. As I started the game and became familiar with the boons and effects, each further chamber I reached became a victory of its own and the pursuit of getting better at the game kept me going. Here the main reward system is not the victories and escapes in themselves, but how much smoother the player becomes in each run and how much more they can do in inflicting damage and mixing better powers. What helps this process especially in the early game is the fragments of story you receive between runs through short conversations. This brilliant method of storytelling helps negate the urge to quit at the time when you're probably the worst at surviving the game. Furthermore, world building, characters, and the unique relationships between Zag and the other NPC's turn the segments between runs a welcoming experience of calm juxtaposed with the violent nature of the escape attempts. This complete formula in game making is the result of repeated experimentation by Supergiant Games throughout their developed games which has come to full fruition in Hades.

Be prepared to die and die again in your quest for freedom from the Underworld in Hades! As Zagreus, you'll repeatedly hack, slash, and dash your way through ever-changing chambers filled with grumpy Greek myth baddies.

Each new attempt retains progression like weapon upgrades, making failure still feel rewarding. Go from zero to hero by mastering the smooth combat mechanics against iconic foes like Medusa and the hydra.

Charm oozes through every corner of the game, from Zagreus' snarky banter to the colorful takes on legends like a boozy Dionysus. Even the gods mock your frequent deaths!

With six weapons offering unique playstyles, no two runs feel the same. Cut foes down with the devilish twin blades, or blast them away with the versatile bow. So many options to turn mythic monsters into monster mash.

Failing never felt so good! Hades' morbid humor and progression system will keep you dying for more. Now get out there and finally make daddy Hades proud!
Dying over and over again has never been so fun

The recorded hours on steam are NOT my real time played. I've bought Hades more than 4-5 times. Between gifting friends, buying for myself and playing on xbox gamepass, this is currently Supergiant Games Magnum Opus. Ive played almost all previous Supergiant games, missing only Pyre, and Hades is the culmination and application of all the experience they have gained throughout the years has indie devs. Its a love letter to their long time fans and themselves. A true labor of love and one can debate its the pinnacle of action rogue lites. 

The art is beautiful, as always, and very unique to them. Darren Korb absolutely kills it again with the stellar OST that just really adds to the excitement and tension of each run, while the more somber songs really sell the ambiance and melancholy felt by its characters. Talking about characters, its truly fun and amazing how Supergiant games were able to create believable, fun and relatable characters out of a over used theme such as greek mythology. The amazing VA really elevates the story telling to whole new levels, and its insane how they achieved such a feat of so many voicelines for all characters and how their appear in game to not repeat unless your starting a new game from scratch. No character ever repeats a single line, and they all have more than hundreds. 

Gameplay what is there to say that it hasnt been said before and cant be appreciated with just the trailers. Its fast, thinky, fun and it pacts a punch. Each floor of levels have unique themes with unique monsters that each requires certain thought into how to beat them effectively, and you can just also try going head first and try coming out alive, either is fine and fun lol. All weapons are very unique yet balanced in a way they are all viable, and all the blessings are versatile to have thousands of possible combinations. Multiple runs in in multiple copies, and ive BARELY scratched the surface of all blessing builds and combination. 

Hades is truly something special. A indie masterpiece and darling that simply CANNOT be denied its greatness and influence in the gaming industry. Its setting a standard of how a game should be released in this modern age of broken AAA games and promises. Hades 2 is the true most anticipated game of the future, and we cant wait for more.

Well, this is one of the best games I have ever played. I do not not specify the game genre on purpose. You do not have to be and I was not a fan of this genre before however somehow this game experience is so overwhelmingly good that I got hooked right at the beginning. 

Your sense of hearing will will tell you right at the beginning that it wants to hear more of what the game can bring. The same goes for your sight ... because you will want to see more first time you die. 

And then there is a story to be unfold. And for that story you will be willing to die countless times and it will not bore you at all because will want to know more about "gifts" from Olympians and how strong can you become combining them. This is especially funny :D ... and as you grow stronger you can make creatures you encounter stronger as well... for which you will be rewarded with stuff that helps you unlock new weapons and their variations that allow you to fight in slightly different way. 

In short -> great story, great graphics, great gameplay,  great music and sound effects, great leveling mechanics, great overall experience

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Hades had been on my to-play list for a long time. I had watched some of my other friends play it and I had heard great things, so I bought it and was waiting for the opportunity to try it out. On Thanksgiving week 2022, I had a lot of time available, because I had contracted Covid and wouldn't be able to see my family that year. On top of that, the day before I got Covid, my dog died. It was one of the worst weeks I'd had in years. Enter Hades. I spent most of my time with Covid sick in bed and asleep, but the time I was awake, I spent playing this game. The sense of discovery this game has is amazing. The voice acting, art, and central premise make the game very immersive, and the finely turned mechanics with new weapons and boon combinations caused me to become highly invested in doing runs just to try new things out. This game is a masterpiece, and a year later, despite in how bad of a place I was in, I still feel nostalgia for playing it fresh. Hades is a 10/10 life-changing experience, and I would recommend it to anyone. Play this one before the sequel comes out, you won't regret it.

Can't recommend this game enough. It's like if Slay the Spire were a 3/4 overhead isometric ARPG. I mean that in the most positive way. Not every roguelike (or in this case, roguelite) is balanced so well. Some runs are "normal" and you combine passive buffs and active abilities as best you can; now and then, luck and/or judicious choices will get you an overpowered perfect combo build that is immensely satisfying to play. Not to mention the wonderful artwork, awesome music, touching story, and lovable cast of characters. Oh and the sexy voice-acting. (I mean literally, most characters have very... attractive-sounding husky voices, I don't really know how else to describe them.)

Lastly, on its own, I want to mention the game's references to Greek mythology. I'm a huge mythology buff and like most mythology buffs, I adore Greco-Roman myths because unlike those of many other cultures, they are comparatively plentiful and well-documented. In addition, I personally have always had a strong affinity for psychopomps and the underworld, so the theme here is right up my alley. It is very obvious that the writers of this game did a crazy amount of research and worked hard to make stuff be both "accurate" to the mythos while also bringing a fresh new perspective to one of the most popular (some might even say overused) stories in Greek mythology. Everything is on-theme from the ambrosia you bribe people with to the personalities of the gods and I love it.

Lastly it must be noted that you can pet Cerberus and he is super adorable! (If any dev ever reads this, I want to say, without spoiling anything, that I REALLY LOVE how you guys dealt with Cerberus.) I know being able to "pet the dog" is a trendy thing in games right now but I don't care... as a dog-lover I welcome every single game that embraces this trend, and anyone who doesn't like it can eff right off.

The good things you've heard about this game are true.

As for the bad... I haven't heard a single bad thing about this game so have no idea if any bad things you've heard would be true, but damn, it does not leave a lot of room for improvement.

I do wish there was more variance in biomes or levels. I wish there were more bosses and not just reskinned versions of themselves with different move sets. But honestly, that's about it. And seeing as how the game is progressing I may change my mind about those things. 

So far, Hades has done a great job of keep a repetitive game feeling fresh, and the grind less grindy. 

The art style is fantastic and the voice acting is god-tier, honestly. The slow progression of story between characters between runs is intriguing and well written. I'm invested and will continue to play.

For what it's worth, I escaped Hades on my 13th attempt, which was about 7 hours in, I think. And while escaping Hades is "beating the game" it's far far far from over. I would pick this up any day of the week, I don't know why I waited so long. If you're at all leery just wait for a sale or return it before the two hour play time limit is up. There's next to no tutorial so you won't have to worry about reaching that time limit before you're even out of the character customisation like some games.

As someone who hasn't really been around roguelike games and also has very little experience gaming, I was a little hesitant about this game. I am still absolutely getting my ass kicked by louts and witches but the game still has incredibly rewarding gameplay even if you feel like you aren't advancing a whole lot due to the interactions that you have with other characters. The world feels rich and vast and I truly cannot complain about whoever decided to draw all the characters Like That. - K

Hades is hands down one of the most incredible games I've ever played. It's like a work of art that you get to interact with. The gameplay is addictively challenging – you'll die a lot, but every time feels like a step toward mastering the Underworld.
The art in this game is downright gorgeous. Every character, every landscape – it's like stepping into a living, breathing mythological world. And the attention to detail is mind-blowing; you can tell the developers poured their hearts into creating this immersive experience.
What really blew me away was the storytelling. The characters have depth, and the voice acting is on another level. I found myself genuinely caring about Zagreus and the others, and the way the narrative unfolds is both clever and emotionally engaging.
And let's talk about the music! It's not just background noise; it's an integral part of the experience. The soundtrack is so good that I catch myself listening to it even when I'm not playing. I definitely recommend everyone to get this game it deserves every penny

[h1]10/10[/h1]
[b]Why do I feel so bisexual?![/b] 

I've been an avid fan of the Roguelite genre for years, yet I've never encountered anything that rivals the sheer, unadulterated fun offered by this game. Embracing death as a new player may initially seem like a negative, but the struggle to escape the pits of the underworld immerses you in the narrative of a naive boy attempting to break free from his father's tormenting realm. The first encounter with Styx immediately reveals the benefits of progressing in a run, granting substantial upgrades for subsequent attempts. However, it doesn't end there; when taken by Styx, you return to the House of Hades, where character interactions advance storylines, each character offering valuable upgrades or trinkets. The game's fully voiced characters, portrayed by expressive actors, add charm and depth, and the captivating plot draws inspiration from Greek mythology in countless ways.

Just as monotony threatens to set in with your move-set, the game introduces a whopping five additional weapons, each boasting four unique styles. The plethora of synergies and creative builds achievable with just one weapon style is downright absurd. The attention to detail and love poured into the Roguelite system's balance are unmatched. Completing the game doesn't mark the end; players, upon finishing their first run, are presented with the option to heighten the game's difficulty in exchange for rewards throughout subsequent runs. I've never encountered a game offering players such flexibility in determining the level of challenge they desire. Do you want bosses with new movesets? Or perhaps everything dealing one hundred percent more damage? Maybe you fancy traps instantly ending your run? The choice is yours, and I doubt I'll ever perceive difficulty in games the same way again. In summary, this game is a masterpiece—captivating characters, a unique story, and gameplay that consistently beckons me for more.

9.8/10. Amazing game, although nothing is perfect,  this is probably the closest game I've every played that comes remotely close. Hades incorporates an easy to grasp yet challenging combat and gameplay structure, whilst simultaneously featuring a captivating design and intriguing narrative. The game takes place in the underworld, and the way you play the game, feels akin to a story dictated in an amphitheatre in ancient Greece rather than a game which yearns for you to rip your hair out. This game is unlike many of its genre, where it rewards you with unique dialogue each and every turn throughout the game, as well as by providing different challenges through the randomly generated nature of the rooms and runs in the game. The game actively rewards for doing things differently each time, and even rewards you when you fail! The replayability of this game knows no bounds, since it always never fails to bore me since, it isn't all that repetitive. While the lore and gameplay is in a whole other, you should take the time to truly appreciate the aesthetic and design of the underworld and its inhabitants. The vibrant palette of colours and textures accompanied by the hellish yet beautiful landscapes of the regions in the Underworld, is truly a curse if you don't appreciate detail on the finest level. However, the icing on this devilish cake is the music by Korb, the compositions made by him truly encapsulates Zagreus' innumerable perilous escape attempts in the Underworld, and seamlessly transitions well between combat beats and haunting melodies, immersing you in the world of Hades. This game truly deserves to be in every gamer's library, and is a modern classic that takes you on an odyssey that beckons to be returned to.
I wanna get dominated by medusa 8/10

TLDR: I cannot recommend this game to others, genuinely. This game was not fun for me.
I really struggled to get through to an official ending of this game.

But to call this a bad game? No way. 

I came to know of Hades through rave reviews via word of mouth from friends & coworkers alike.
And to my experience, the game's got beautiful art / graphics, excellent sound design, engaging game-play, meaningful lore / relationships, and a wonderful fundamental story arc that ties everything together.
It's even boosts its replay factor with randomized boons, randomized weapons that are bonus drops, optional difficulty increases, weapons with different play styles & variants, etc. It even had features for players with skill-issue like God Mode, etc.

Like objectively on paper, it should sound like I had a blast. I really did try to find different builds or weapons combinations or punishment conditions to make it a more fun game. It was an engaging, but I did not have fun.

I'm guessing that I just might not like games of this sort of genre, since Hades is the 1st of this genre type I've played. I'm sure it's a great game for its genre, just not for me.

Hopefully, this doesn't deter people who know they like games of this genre, but for people who know they don't already, it's okay to not be interested in a game like Hades. Just don't go around bad-mouthing it.

Hades is the only fucking story based rogue-like, where dying doesnt feel like a defeat because now you unlocked new dialogue options with your gay roomate.

The level variety is good enough, although after 7 billion runs some rooms do start to seem more and more familliar. However, there are a lot of different enemies that appear on different floors to make you feel like there's more variety amongst the different levels.

There really isn't a whole lot of content in this game like reviews would bait you into believing. There are not a lot of different rooms, enemies, bosses, and no matter what boons or weapons you take, there isn't really any such thing as a 'build'. Taking 10 boons in one run, and 10 different boons with a different weapon in another run won't make you feel like you've actually changed things up. The game actually has very little content, all runs will feel very similar and you'll probably die around the same time every run.

That being said, i'm at 37 hours and i'm no where near bored or done with the game, i very much like the gameplay loop of playing a run, unlocking meta progression stuff for permanent upgrades, and doing another run.

Just don't go in expecting interesting build combinations, lots of different enemies etc. All of the negative reviews telling you that every run is the same and that the weapons & boons make no difference are not lying, at all.

TL;DR version: Buy this even if you're not into rogue-lites (I'm not) and/or if you enjoyed any previous SuperGiant games. The game has much more depth, humor, and plot than I was expecting, and the gameplay is fair and fun.

Long version: I'm not usually big on rogue-lites, but after I enjoyed Pyre so much, especially for its surprising depth, narrative, and character arcs and relationships (which I was not expecting in what is basically 3-on-3 cosmic basketball), I decided I'd take a chance on Hades. I'm really glad I did. For a start, the way that you retain certain upgrades after each attempt, while losing temporary ones, means the game does get easier the more you play it, but also stays fresher than if every run was truly the same in terms of perks and route. I rarely felt bored or like I was going through the motions, especially since my run times got faster and I got better at the game with most attempts. So, the balance felt right, especially for someone who's not really into the genre. 

And like with Pyre, I was impressed with the depth of the game. There's so much going on with relationships between all the characters; I talk to everyone I can in the House of Hades after dying. The dialog is funny, the graphics are clean, the narrative arcs are well-done, the game is fair, and there's a trophy for petting the dog. 

Lastly: if you've beaten the game and haven't gotten the trophy for petting Cerberus ten times, what's wrong with you?

I wish I'd never bought this game. It starts kinda mid, and way too tough. That difficulty isn't your fault, though - the game is genuinely just straight up rigged against you to lose unless you buy the metaprogression upgrades, which feels hugely counterintuitive for a roguelike. Metaprogression should unlock new options and playstyles, and maybe make the game easier, not turn it from impossible to playable. 

Then, you get used to the game and unlock more upgrades and items. This bit's cool, but it takes a while to get to - maybe 4 or 5 hours of playing, which is tough to stick through with progression slowly bleeding out. There's a story running parallel to the game, which progresses every time you die, and sure, that's cool in theory. But in practice, I just became far too stressed to enjoy the game, because I felt the need to beat the final boss before the story "ended". Every failure and subsequent progression of the story made me more frustrated and upset with the game.

The story itself isn't even that interesting either. The characters are all really quite boring, bar a handful, and the game is far too dialogue-heavy, giving fully-voice acted conversations that I actually originally listened to the whole way through - until I realised that it's just way too slow. Spending five to ten minutes at Hades' house between runs broke up the flow of the game far too much, meaning it loses momentum. Other roguelikes - Isaac, Gungeon, Nuclear Throne, etc. have little to no hub area to fuck up the momentum. In the end, I'd skim character's dialogue as a chore, because I'd rather play the actual game itself. That, or at least lean in further to the story aspect and give us more areas to explore in the hub world than Hades' tiny mansion.

Speaking of, the gameplay is fluid and fast-paced, which is great, and the boons are kinda neat. Daedalus Hammers and Chaos boons are unique and provide a great change, which is why it's a shame you normally only see two or three per run. The enemies are unique enough, but there's just not enough variety given the size the game makes you think it is. Maybe less than 10 enemy types per area means they become repetitive quickly, and the small number of (pre-built) chambers don't help this problem either. After you've beaten the game two or three times, every run feels like a slight variation of the last.

After you've finished the game, it also becomes a grindy slog to "complete the other stuff", like house contracts (hub-area cosmetics) or fated prophecies (missions), with progression slowing down and down and down until you're left with seemingly no reward for each run. This is the point I'm at, and I just kinda don't care. I don't want to put in another 50 hours to beat the last 5% of this game, it's just a waste of time on something I don't enjoy.

Balance is also a huge problem, both in weapons/boons, and enemies.
If you take any dash upgrade bar Athena's, you're shooting yourself in the foot. All the other ones SUCK.
If you take any attack upgrades bar Hermes' or Demeter's, you're shooting yourself in the foor. The others are consistently worse.
It's harder to beat the game with no difficulty modifiers and an Exagryph than 7 or 8 difficulty modifiers and an Aspect of Chiron Bow. The balance is so UNBELIEVABLY shifted there that it's almost like a joke. 
Of the four areas, the THIRD has the hardest enemies. The warriors who can revive themselves - especially the borderline invincible ones with shields - are so irritating to fight. I end up losing more health chasing after them to finish them off than I do fighting them normally. 
The fucking TINY VERMIN enemy is harder than the FINAL FUCKING BOSS. are we serious right now like bruh

The soundtrack and visuals are cool. I can appreciate them, even though they're not my thing. Team did a good job there. A lot of developers put a lot of hours into this, and it's almost there. It just needs a rebalance and a focus shifted more on combat and gameplay than lore and story. But it's not made to cater to me, so at least it fills that "story roguelike" niche. 

If you're like me and you ADORE roguelikes for their gameplay, don't go in expecting to love this. It could go either way. I regret this purchase and the time I put into it which I could have spent elsewhere.

Just about everything in the game feels perfect. I honestly don't know how they're going to improve on things in Hades 2, but I'm really excited to find out! Despite the fact that this is an action game, the story, characters, and voice acting are incredible. Zagreus' personality and the hilarious and friction-filled dynamic he has with his father really stand out. The art and use of colours is also fantastic.

This IS an action roguelite though, and I think what really shines through the most is the addictive and compelling gameplay loop and the snappy, responsive combat. It makes the skill improvements I made as I progressed through game all the more satisfying. 

I could go on much longer about this game, but I'll leave it there. If you haven't played yet, I can't recommend it enough.

As a roguelike the biggest variation is in your weapon, which isn't that great for a start, then combined with there not being that many, and then the hammer you need to find in a run to change how they work being rare... That's a huge, huuuuge mark against the game. A friend said it gets more varied... it doesn't get varied, it gets to a basic, acceptable level. At least they finally made a satisfying combat system.

I like and dislike many details about the story side, but it doesn't matter that much to me so I won't get into it. Which is actually a huge negative, because as cool as I find this game's take on the Greek pantheon, I've been a fan since before I learned to read, it's part of why I learned, and it should impress me more. The flavor of the whole game is great, including interactions with gods that give you favor. The upgrades (besides the hammer) are mostly inconsequential, which is why people think Athena is overpowered, all of hers do something (the same thing really). There's a lot to unlock in the hub, that's cool I guess. Music is great. Game is consistently pretty and smooth.

Fun for a while, it does a few things great, but it only does those things. Once the novelty of the presentation wears off, the only reason you'll keep playing is to finish the story or because you don't know of the many roguelikes with more content variety. Go try Dead Cells.

Between story and dungeon crawling, this is my favorite game ever. I've never wanted to 100% a game before this one. I have it on multiple platforms and I always come back to it for the art, music and story. I cannot wait for Hades II, and I hope it sucks you in just as this one has. 10/10 think you should give this a go if you like this type of game play.

Short version: This is isometric roguelite Devil May Cry and I love it.

Long version: Hades was my introduction to the roguelite genre as well as to Supergiant games. With its incredibly high quality, has locked in my interest if Hades 2 goes the same early access route: something I cannot say of any other game. 

Gameplay: Hades has four stages, with the fourth having a radically different structure before the final boss. Each available weapon is totally different from the others; on top of that, each weapon has subweapon styles that make the way it plays even more unique. I have most of the game's achievements due to my love of experimenting with all the different subweapons, though I did not get all of skelly's trophies for the last 2 or 3. Those involve manually bumping the difficulty of lategame runs up to very, very high levels beyond what is needed to finish the epilogue. Those are rough if you want to go full completionist.

Graphics: Although the art is 2D, with the outstanding attention to detail, it hardly looks like a game that could have been released 20 or 30 years ago. Alongside its attention to detail, for such a fast-paced game, Hades does an excellent job of drawing the player's attention where it needs to go. Enemy attacks, your attacks, and drops are easy to pick out of the play area.

Audio: The sound effects are appropriately meaty for a fantasy setting and the voice work is amazing, notably the god of the underworld himself. Many people swear by the music of this game, which based on the Noclip documentary featured one of Supergiant's developers singing in one of the tracks, but it doesn't click with me. For all the praise I have for this game, I am not attached to the music, unlike the rest of the game.

Story: As a roguelite, dying sends you back to your home base to level up. What sets Hades apart is how the persistent story develops between your runs. In every other roguelite I have played since Hades introduced me to the genre, I have missed the in-depth story this game offers. Seeing it through to the epilogue requires 15 successful runs, if I recall correctly: something I would not have done if I lacked interest in the narrative. My own interest in the story is buoyed by Supergiant's loving attention to the original Greek myths. Zagreus did indeed exist in the old pantheon and was even venerated to a limited extent by the ancients: a deep cut that a lesser developer would never have considered.

Overall, if I were to rate this game on a 10-point scale, I would give it a 9/10. One point is deducted for the latter heat challenges being punishing and the music not clicking with me. I consider everything else about the game to be perfect and give it my recommendation.

Hades is an absolute triumph in the roguelike realm. It's the kind of game that keeps you hooked with its ever-changing gameplay, an arsenal of diverse weapons, and a difficulty curve that always keeps you on your toes. The visuals are nothing short of breathtaking, seamlessly blending classic aesthetics with a modern touch, creating a world that's both timeless and visually stunning. The narrative, accompanied by outstanding voice acting, adds a layer of depth that elevates the entire experience. If you're a fan of immersive gameplay, eye-catching graphics, and a story that pulls you in, Hades is an absolute must-play.

The game is fine but far from the masterpiece everybody claims it is. I'd say it's successful at doing what other "RPG" games do (story, music, character and ambience -wise) but fails to deliver on the roguelite side of things.

In a nutshell :

1) the gameplay and gameplay-loop is mediocre (see paragraph below).
2) enemies are both extremly weak in variety (the roster) and designed to be frustrating / non-interactive (240° shields, self-revives, endless waves of swarms, poison puddles, groups of bowmen sniping you across the room and skatering if threatened, ...).
3) the roguelite element (the mirror and weapon aspects) is a forced 60 hours grind so that you can max out stats that should've been given to you for free (or maxed out after 10 hours at worst), which is surreal.

6 weapons, each having only 2 attacks. Every weapon has 4 aspects, but there only ever is one (or two in rare cases) that is viable per weapon. So based on weapon alone, the gameplay variety is very lacking. Now, where's it's supposed to come from are the boons that you receive during runs. Except 80% of the boons are trash, generic and inexpressive. Weaken, Hangover and Doom are simply alternative ways of dealing damage which all feel awful. No boons (except duo-boons, more on that later) ever truely give you an alternative way of playing the game. Picking up boons that do not contribute to a perfectly optimal build feels as if you didn't picked up antyhing at all, they are deadweights (like why would I ever pick Ades cast saw blades ? It's a dps loss). And the best boons (duo-boons) are locked behind a very specific build order (so no freedom) AND the mirror stat grind... bascialy, expect mindlessly spamming X and A for 60 hours before looking into the 6 playstyles available. Only good thing are the hammers but they restrict your gameplay a lot too.

I'd like to preface my review by noting that Hades is an impressive and enjoyable hack-n-slash roguelike with a highly addictive gameplay loop. So addictive, in fact, that I would actually suggest that people with addictive tendencies should actually *avoid* playing this game. Between the heart pumping music, constant action, visual overload, and seemingly infinite dialogue, it is *very* easy to slip into the "just one more game" cycle with Hades.

Now, onto my actual review.

--First Impressions--

What impresses me most about Hades is how deceptively deep the game is. You're dropped into the game as a guy named Zagreus who is trying to escape the Underworld, and by the time you finally escape the Underworld... you have only scratched the surface of Hades. There is *so much dialogue* and every single bit of that dialogue is voiced. Even after a hundred fifty successful and unsuccessful runs, I am still occasionally hearing new dialogue. There are literally 21,000 voice lines and roughly 305,000 words of dialogue in the game according to the developers. That is roughly the same voice line and word count as *Mass Effect,* an RPG well-known for its sheer scope. As I kept hearing new lines and tidbits, I kept thinking "how did these indie developers manage to afford *this* many lines of dialogue?"

It isn't just the massive scope of the written story that manages to impress, either. The gameplay itself appears very shallow on the surface, and yet it has proven to be very intricate underneath. My earliest successful runs largely consisted of succeeding by virtue of sheer luck and existing mechanical skill, resulting in some hard won victories. My later runs made the base difficulty of the game a breeze: the game heavily rewards knowing how to manipulate boon RNG to get your desired build.

--Customizable Difficulty--

After beating the game on base difficulty, the Pact of Punishment system is unlocked, allowing players to very finely tune and customize the game's difficulty, which is overall represented by "Heat." I found it somewhat similar to Slay the Spire's Ascension system in the best of ways: the various conditions aren't difficult to deal with individually, but combined they can ramp up the difficulty quickly. The in-game rewards cap out at 32 heat, which I myself ended at. I was a little surprised there wasn't a Steam achievement for a 32 heat run, as 32 heat is still a very manageable difficulty.

I do think that zero heat/base game difficulty was a little *too* easy, as I nearly beat the game on my third try despite knowing very little about the mechanics at the time. I also don't like some of the heat conditions on account of how they can rule out certain playstyles entirely.

--Midgame is too grindy--

My biggest criticism of Hades is that everything about the midgame is too grindy. By that point in the game, I'd had enough successful runs under my belt and built a lot of confidence in my game knowledge, but the lack of meta-resources meant that my ability to freely experiment with builds and weapons was limited by my willingness to grind for Darkness and Nectar. This proved to be extremely frustrating, as the best way to farm for these bottleneck resources is to replay the game on zero Heat (which is, as mentioned before, too easy, and boring to repeat).

Even more frustrating is that advancing some parts of the story required that I deliberately fail runs. It feels like a massive waste to play for fifteen minutes to slowly deliberately die to specific enemies, or to pray to RNGesus that the right NPCs will show up so I can talk to them later.

However, the most frustrating part is that Hades does not need to be this grindy, as the game itself already provides all of the necessary enjoyment to keep playing. For me, the best part of progression was not unlocking new talents in the Mirror, but the way in which my growing game knowledge started translating into successful streaks and pushing Heat.

Once the midgame grind was over, my first thought was "Now I can finally play the game," and the experience became far more enjoyable.

--Too much clicking--

This will sound like an odd complaint, but I also felt like the game was a little too clicky. Because the gameplay is so fast paced, a lot of strategies in Hades require an enormous amount of spamming the dash button and spam clicking your attacks in order to stay alive and maximize your DPS.

I feel like this setup is unnecessarily hard on both players' hands and on players' gaming equipment. There are certain in-game upgrades that I will always take because they serve as quality of life upgrades: being able to hold down left mouse button for auto-attacking rather than being forced to manually click over and over feels like I'm saving a year's worth of service life for my PC's mouse.

With my spacebar feeling *significantly* looser since started Hades (and I game fairly heavily on this keyboard without much issue prior), the excess of clicking is a major reason for why I've stopped playing Hades.

--Those Loading Screens--

After over 150 runs, I would kill for the ability to skip/shorten certain animations in the game. Namely, the victory screens come with voiceover narration that I assume are hiding a loading screen, but if not, I would love to be able to skip them at this point as I've heard them all. I think I've spent a solid five hours of my life sitting through some of those sequences, over, and over, and over.

--Concluding remarks--

Despite my issues with the grind, the clickiness, and the frustratingly addictive qualities of the game, I, overall, wholeheartedly recommend Hades. There is an enormous amount of craftsmanship, love, and expertise poured into making this game, and it shows; every inch of it radiates with the developers' passion. If possible, I would strongly suggest that you play this game without spoiling *anything* about it for yourself going in, not even gameplay mechanics.

哈迪斯是我接触的第二款肉鸽类游戏，也是我认为完全可以和死亡细胞比肩的一款游戏。
这款游戏的画质，剧情，人物对话极度丰富，细腻又清晰的剧情让玩家每次死亡回到家里，都能解锁很多新的对话和剧情。玩法来说，这款游戏较死亡细胞内容确实少了很多，主要就是通过选择武器和祝福搭配来获得不同的效果。虽然祝福种类多种多样，可供选择的武器有24把，但是武器大概也只分6个大类，而核心祝福也只有5个大方面，其余的祝福更多的起辅助效果。虽然这款游戏打击感强，非常好玩，但是不得不承认他的内容比较有限--在完成主线剧情（通关10次）以后，这款游戏可玩的地方就是装饰自己的家，挑战更高难度（但是关卡本身内容不变），或者使劲肝，收集非常多的道具达成真结局。对局中也只能通过祝福来使每次游玩的体验多样化，实在是一个比较有限的手段。打到中后期就会发现每局的重复行非常高，这也是这款游戏最大的缺点。这个过程相当漫长，而且确实比较无聊。不过总体来说这款游戏想要达到主线剧情的结局，难度并不是非常高，而且一般来说也不用花费过多的时间。这款游戏我强烈推荐给所有玩家～～如果你想体验精致的画风，爽快的打击感，紧凑清晰的剧情，有趣的人物对话，在寻找一款难度中等的肉鸽游戏，或者是一位希腊神话爱好者--无脑入，你不会后悔的～

The finest, most consistently enjoyable roguelike I've ever encountered, with a committed, unique approach to narrative that is unmatched in the genre.  No other roguelike even comes close in terms of character design, writing, visuals, and voice acting.

Gameplay is fast-paced and addictive with a staggering number of weapon and power-up combinations to choose from.  The "one more run" feeling is always there and every run requires a slightly different approach depending on build.  The challenge level is on the easier side for the genre, but is customizable with added difficulty offering greater rewards.

My only complaint would be that some of the side content is paced out a little too slowly.  It took me ~40 hours to make the credits roll, and in that time none of the side stories were fully resolved, and I hadn't even had a chance to make a single use of one item type!  I understand they want to leave a lot of content for "endgame" players but it did feel like a slight misstep.

Hades is a game that excels at merging the replayabilty of most common rougelikes/lites and the strong character-driven stories of other titles. The simplicity of the player kit and enemy design allow for a fun little game where there's lots of variation on playthroughs but is easy to understand. You may get a run where you primarily use your special, others where cast is the difference between winning or not. Your offensive abilities also deleting projectiles is an extremely smart decision.

After about 40 hours my only real complaint is the lack of enemy variation. Most enemies in the game key off of another similar enemy, which works well but i wish there was a wider variety of different shapes and sizes of them. 

The heat system is a genius style of difficulty adjustment and i wish more games used a similar system.

From a technical point, this game is excellent. It has good style, music, voiceacting, the controls are (almost always) good, the enemies are (almost always) good, and so on. It is praiseworthy for many things, but I still didnt like it in the end. The reason - it is so monotonous! It is hard to say where the line betwen quality and quantity lies, and this game goes hard into quality, feeling barren at the same time. Just few stages, just few enemies on each stage, just few room layouts, and their combinations stop feeling engaging really fast. The meta-progression is here, but it is very mild, the power you gain are also very mild, none being overly powerfull or not powerfull at all. And having a fair and balanced game is great, even if some parts of it are in your face unbalanced for narrative purposes, its fine. But it just doesnt give anything memorable. I really, really wanted to love this game, doing one run after the other, but as I started dying on purpose after the "what am I even doing here" thought, I knew this game is not for me.

This is just an [b]insanely[/b] good game, start to finish, no questions asked.

When I first heard about it, I was like "oh, Greek mythology, eh whatever, not my thing," but HOOOOO boy, [i][b]don't judge a book by its cover!!![/b][/i] Everything about this game just FEELS fantastic in a way that's hard to describe. The loop of smashing through the underworld, cobbling together a crazy build, and using your resources after every run to unlock MORE power, and more dialogue with all the super well-written characters... So good.

It does everything in its power to soften the tremendous impact that death normally has in a roguelike, and it makes every death feel all the more encouraging. Sure, your run's over, but now you can dump all the resources you've collected in to unlocking like 3 new permanent upgrades that all have very tangible impacts! And in the meantime, you spruce up the lounge with some cutlery and a fireplace, and maybe you give your dog a comfy bed, because he's a good lad.

Probably the only problems / minor nitpicks I have with it are:
- Some irritating enemies [i](though none are too bad)[/i]
- Dark Thirst can be annoying, sometimes made me feel like I had to pick the same weapons over and over whenever it decided to cling to a specific weapon [i](looking at you, Adamant Rail!)[/i]
- Making progress [i]too fast[/i] is a thing - certain NPCs might suddenly talk about things you've done like 5 runs in a row as if they're [i]totally new happenings,[/i] lol

But that's basically it!

Hades is just full of so much love and personality and chaos, it might honestly top Dark Souls 1 as my favorite game of all time. Even though I've gotten all the achievements, I could [i]absolutely[/i] see myself booting it up again and again to unlock every little bonus item and codex entry possible. Can't wait for the sequel!

This is one of the best concepts in a game I've seen in a while. I've completed the entire game on another account up to the epilogue, and it's one of my favorite games ever. The combat is ridiculously fun and, with the RNG and heat mechanics, each run feels unique. The game is at its best when you're able to explore different playstyles and enhance your runs. Despite facing the same kinds of enemies repeatedly, it doesn't get old for me. On top of the gameplay, Hades has a fantastic story that makes the less enjoyable parts (of dying over and over again lol) satisfying to complete. It's rare that I love both the gameplay and story/slice-of-life elements, and I almost never see them complement each other so nicely. Once the game clicks with you, it's so addicting and fun. Though it's technically short, it has practically infinite replay value. Highly recommend.

I love this game. It's not my favorite game ever (I'm one of those weirdos that played Xenogears at that perfect impressionable time in life, so it will always be my favorite), but I 100% believe Hades is the greatest game ever made. I can come back to Hades anytime, and have a blast. This is the only game that as an adult, I can still catch myself up playing at 2am and saying to myself, "dude, you need to go to bed... ok one more run I swear".  I am not good enough with words to explain just how much I love this game.

But I'll try to explain it like this:

I have never been a real hardcore gamer. I've never really been the type to keep playing a game in an attempt to improve at it. I usually find my ceiling in a game pretty quickly, and I'm content with that. As long as I'm having fun I don't care, and since I hardly play multiplayer games who cares if I'm not "good". Hades is the only game I've noticed myself gradually getting better and better at over time. I'm no freak. I still have many many heats left to go, and a lot of weapon aspects I still suck with. The thing is though, I'm not getting better at it because I'm actively trying to learn the game, and get better. It's because I enjoy playing the game so much that I just naturally do get better. I don't know. Like I said, me no word good, but I do own 3 copies of this game if that means anything. The only other game I've done that with is Catherine, and one of those is the remake.

Anyway, 100 out of 10. This game knocks it out of the park in every aspect. Can't wait for 2.

I'm glad that a relatively small studio produced such a successful game, but it personally wasn't to my taste. I play video games to relax, and this game is a constantly grueling adrenaline rush. Even with action shooters like Mass Effect 2, you can get good enough over time that the action sections become quite manageable and relaxingly fun. But this game is built around repetitive and extremely fast-paced combat with very little margin for error, so even experienced players have to stay on their toes all the time. So I would always leave this game feeling far more drained than when I'd started playing. Also, I personally dislike the roguelike game mechanic where you have to keep replaying through the same levels over and over again. That endless repetition process does not feel fun to me.

I want to preface this statement with a fact: I hate rogue-likes. I don't find doing the same thing, over and over again, with small variation, to be fulfilling. HOWEVER! Hades is so good it completely overcame my bias against its genre. This game is gorgeous, sharp, endearing, and surprisingly hilarious. Each and every character sparkles with personality and life (the voice-acting is *incredible*) such that you want to keep playing just to interact with them more. Which isn't to say that gameplay isn't good- it is. The variation in weapon and boon combinations is nearly endless and the Heat system allows you to tailor your difficulty to taste, but that's not what I kept playing for. I got so invested in the story and characters that I was willing to put in -checks stats- over *87* hours and 70+ runs to see their story to its finish. So, if you like rogue-likes, you're going to love this game. If you *don't* like rogue-likes, give it a try anyway, it might just surprise you like it did me. :)

I was aware of that this game was a strong nominee for the game of the year award and already won many other awards. But, i chose to ignore all these information and wanted to play like i've never heard anything about it. So, I started to play the game from a neutral perspective. Everything was perfect for gameplay, atmosphere and story. Only thing that i criticized was soundtracks and sound design but toward the end of the game it also got better. In my opinion, this game has done everything perfectly without carrying any concern about being creative. I'm not saying they are not creative. I am conflicted in giving this a positive review. Generally I loathe games where enemies play by a much more favorable set of rules than I do. Compared to me, enemies have tons of HP and high damage output.  Healing items are too infrequent. By the time I finished, I had learned to dodge constantly and spam attack all over the place. That kind of combat is not fun at all to me. I can rarely understand what is happening because combat is much too fast. I don't enjoy the nature of re-playing the same content over and over again to gain a tiny drop of random story progression. Sometimes I'd complete a story element, then it would be 3-4 hours and 4-6 runs later before some NPC would acknowledge my accomplishment. I don't like how everything is so random. I would have enjoyed a more tailored experience more than this mess. Why should I do another 30 minute run through the same content I've already completed just to get the NPCs to give me 2 new lines of dialogue? It feels like a total waste of time. Given the random nature of how the story unfolds, it never feels finished. I don't like how lategame areas have enemies that lay down huge puddles of poison on the ground right in front of the fountain to cure poison. I also don't like how many bosses can go invulnerable for an extended length of time. Gee wouldn't it be nice if I could do that too? Unfair bullcrap - I hate it.

This review is positive strictly for the quality of the game itself - it is well made. I just found certain design choices to be infuriating and I would have enjoyed a less random experience that didn't rely on split-second timing and lopsided difficulty for combat. The art, lore, world, voice acting, etc., are all very good.

Also the Epilogue was rotten! [spoiler]The NPCs talk about a grand feast they all had and how much fun it was. There wasn't even a cutscene for the experience. I guess these devs never heard the expression "Show, don't tell." What a let down.[/spoiler]
G

Hades is a beautiful rogue-like game. Its visuals are stunning with a mix of 2D portraits of characters for dialogue boxes which pair well with the 3D designs of the base game, along with amazing graphics and a beautiful art style. The Ancient Greek mythology setting makes for a great story that explores various characters from Greek mythology as well as adding some new characters into the mix. The gameplay is decently easy to get into if it's your time playing a rouge-like but has a high skill ceiling. The base difficulty is fairly hard but you can make it easier with a setting, after playing for a while you can add various things to make runs more challenging. The gameplay is also very re-playable and there is still new stuff to unlock even after 100+ hours of playing. Finally, the music in the game is stunning at times and it is definitely recommended to play with audio to be able to hear the music and fully voice-acted cast members of Hades.

Yes, there are things about the game that are absurdly high quality, such as the astoundingly beautiful artwork. However, sometimes it only takes one critical flaw to ruin the whole game.

The visibility/visual clarity in this game is unacceptably terrible. If I can't see what is happening on the screen because it's too noisey, or if the enemies tells are too visually subtle to actually notice or recognize, then I can't play the game. End of story. I couldn't play the game blindfolded either -- if I can't see what's happening then there is no game. Sure, I can try and play, but at some point my eyes just glaze over and the feeling of boredom and sadness creeps in because there is nothing I can do to make my ocipital lobe see better.

I'm sure most are not effected by this problem enough for it to ruin the game for them, but this is still an issue, and this game is absolutely deserving of this negative review. Of the hundreds of thousands of positive reviews this game has, this one negative one won't make a bit of difference anyhow in the grand scheme of things (I would not have left a negative review otherwise)

I'm sure people will be flaming me since I played 3 hours at the time of review, but that doesn't matter. I could have played 30 minutes and spotted this issue, it's not the sort of things that required 50 hours of gameplay to discover.

I got this game as a gift and it is the best thing ever! I have been hyper focused on this game for over a year(it is impressive if my hyper focuses can stay consist and active for 3 mouths), i have loved every second of playing Hades and I have 300 hours logged (at time of writing and even tho I'm done with the mine story there is still things to do! I am still lurning new things and getting new interactions. the game play is DIE-namic (not sorry for the pun), unique and flied. you have a ever changing revolving door of abilitys and weapons and yet still enough control for a lot of strategy! it scratches the puzzle solving, strategizing, story telling, curious and music loving parts of my brain! there is so much mythology it is flowering!
 the world and characters have so much depth, the whole thing from story to characters to world feels so cohesive and immersive! i have been engaged with every single part and there are sever parts that I normally find disengaging, annoying, boring or even triggering in the panic attack or bad thoughts kind of way, and between choice, involvement, creative decisions and genuine emotion and me not realizing at first I never disengaged once!    

I have enjoyed every moment of this game I have loved it as a story, a game, an escape, a space to be and feel excepted in a way I haven't felt in a game ever (and in so few places in real life) Hades has helped me thru so much mental and emotional pain /distress (and continues to) , I love it in a way I cant fully articulate but it holds a place that nothing else has managed to come close to
P.S. I am a person who has ADHD, dyslexia and am on the spectrum, I deal with a lot of unexplained pain (like migraines, joint and stumic) regularly, I am Ace( repulsed to neutral) and gender nonconforming the game world felt so immerse, kind and excepting that even if I didn't see any of these thing even if they didn't have story's around theses thing or use are language I truly felt like there was and is a place for me in this world the way I am, no changes no fixes just me I have a place as is in the story I can do theses thing I have a place in the story's i am not just an observer or passive. and I haven't felt that since i was little. 

so thank you to the characters and to every single person that put their hart and soul into this game it is felt and appreciated in a way I do not think I can convey

I had no idea what I was in for when I bought this game. I just figured I'd kinda like it cause I like rogue-likes. Instead, I got probably the most masterfully executed rogue-like I've ever played. The characters are charming and lovable, the weapons are diverse and fun to use, the random elements are able to be influenced often so you can keep ahead of the game if you know what your run needs going from room to room. The fantastic art style is the final nail that sends this game into the stratosphere and on top of that, all the animation work is gorgeous and snappy. If I could nitpick anything, I have some issues with how artificial the difficulty feels on the final region with large enemy health bars with excessive amounts of poison damage. It feels like the polar opposite of what a majority of the game feels like prior, but frankly the segment is not that long and the boss fight that follows is one of my favorite experiences I've had with games this year. Overall, I would recommend this game to literally anyone that enjoys games at their best from developers that clearly care about this game being amazing.

Update: I 100%ed it and was still getting new dialogue 200 hours in. Greatest game of all time. Also I would kiss Zag on his hot mouth

I couldn't pass up on a Greek mythology inspired game from Supergiant though so I had to give it a go.  I've only got 5 hours on Steam so far but have now played, beaten and platinumed the game on PS4.  The characters are all great and the story is fun and engaging and keeps you coming back run after run.  Every run feels a bit different from the mix of Boons, Weapons, Keepsakes, Mirror upgrades and different room arrangements and that keeps it from ever getting boring.

I loved Bastion and Transistor but I have now spent more time playing Hades than any other Supergiant game.  And I haven't gotten sick of it yet.  It's a game that's just really fun to come back to over and over again.

Can't wait for Hades 2 to come out.

as someone who has spent over 200 hours in this game and has 100% completed it with all achievements, i can safely say that this is the best game that i have ever played in my life. before playing hades i didn't even like dungeon crawlers, but this changed my perspective completely. i am so excited for hades II, but for those who haven't played the OG i HIGHLY recommend that you do. the characters are very well written, there's so many different storylines, and it took me over 150 hours to see a line of dialogue repeated. if you aren't interested in the story, i still recommend that you play this game. it is highly addictive and is a happy medium (in my opinion) of easy and hard. and you can always mess with the difficulty! for a solid 3 months this game was my go to escape from reality. just load up the game, turn a podcast on, and bam. instant serotonin. 10/10, would play again and am SO excited for the sequel.

Out of all the rogue likes I've played, none come close to the storytelling, voice acting, and characters that Hades has. Hades' story and its characters are expanded upon during and after every single run you do. Besides the 6 different weapons you can enter a run with, you can also meet many gods throughout your run, offering different play-styles and synergies between each other. The character relationship system is also similar to the Persona series, and in my experience, I still consistently see new dialogue and character interactions 80 hours into the game.

With few moments to rest, your one goal is to fight through the Underworld until you finally make your escape. You won't be able to get enough of this game.

After an immersive few hours and unlocking all achievements in Hades, I felt compelled to share my experience. Hades stands out as an exceptional single-player game, offering an unparalleled value, especially considering its price point on Steam.

While many reviews have thoroughly covered aspects like gameplay mechanics, camera dynamics, action sequences, and graphics, I want to focus on the meticulous attention to detail that sets Hades apart. The narrative is masterfully delivered by a compelling lore teller, weaving an engaging story that keeps you hooked. The dialogues in the game are remarkably situational and refreshingly non-repetitive, enhancing the overall immersive experience. Each character is distinct, displaying unique personalities that add depth to the game world.

The thoughtful design extends to the gameplay as well, with a diverse range of weapons and skills that allow for numerous playstyles. This variety contributes significantly to the game's replayability, a quality that is becoming increasingly rare in modern games. Hades is not just a game you play; it’s an experience that evolves with every playthrough, making it a standout title in the single-player genre.

Let me just say right now that Hades is an incredible masterpiece. I entered Hades as a firm believer in the roguelike genre as a godawful gimmick for individuals who insisted on suffering themselves for hours on end, death after death, with the same randomly generated, mostly non-narrative gameplay. To my surprise, battling my way out of Tartarus as the stubborn demigod Zagreus, son of Hades, has been some of the most enjoyable experiences of the year! Supergiant Games has proven to me that the roguelike genre is more than simply a gimmick, and that there is opportunity for innovation and narrative storytelling in the genre.
Keeps me coming back to try again and again.

[h1]Easily the best thing Supergiant Games have ever released and probably one of my favourite games of all time.[/h1]

Everything about this is just amazingly well done. Here a few examples:

- Visuals and soundtrack are (as always with Supergiant) absolutely beautiful.

- Huge variety in gameplay through the weapons and their variants.

- Weapons are well balanced, all of them feel great to play. Even though I did not like some of them at first after a few runs you will find a good build for them that is fun.

- Progression feels powerful and also gives you ways to experiment.

- Combining a Rougelite with a story is an ingenious move. Failing (or ending) a run is never frustrating when you look forward to progressing the story. The story itself is also well suited for the run-based structure so even if you're not a fan of it, it should not bother you too much.

- Lots of content: If you take your time you can easily spend a hundred hours getting to 100% This is also the only thing I would criticise about this. A lot of achievements are purely based on getting certain dialoges done, so it is quite random how long it will take you to unlock all of them, which can feel a little bit frustrating.

In conclusion I simply cannot recommend this game enough. Apart from those who really don't like hack and slay kind of gameplay I cannot think of anyone who would not enjoy this. So if you haven't already do yourself a favour and get this!

Thanks for taking the time and reading my review! Hope you have a great rest of your day!

Hades is one of the best roguelike games I have ever played. It is fun, challenging, and rewarding, with a lot of replay value and variety. The game has a beautiful art style that captures the mythological theme and the personalities of the characters. The story is engaging and immersive, with branching paths and dynamic interactions. The voice acting is superb and adds a lot of charm and humor to the game. The game also has a great soundtrack that matches the mood and atmosphere of each area. The game is not too hard or too easy, but just right for anyone who enjoys a good hack and slash adventure. The game also has a lot of customization options and secrets to discover, making each run unique and exciting. Hades is a masterpiece of game design and storytelling, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves video games.

Update: Finished the main objective and I still find new stuff pretty much every run. Can't wait for the sequel!!

I'd recommend Supergiant's entire catalog of games--they are consistently excellent in terms of both gameplay and presentation--but Hades has a remarkable depth of replayability as well.  Very highly recommended; one of the best games on Steam full stop.

I'm new to the whole rogue-like dungeon crawler genre of gaming, but now I'm a big fan. The renewal of challenge each escape attempt keeps you going as you slay demons who stand in your way while listening to the beautiful soundtrack by Darren Korb (who also voices the protagonist) and progressing through the 4 stages of the Greek Underworld as Zagreus, its Prince and the son of the titular character Hades.

Definitely one of the rogue like games I have like because of rich details and get good scrub mechanics. Although the overall goal seems to be short, the game play loop will keep you going to achieve those abundant contents and play for more hours.

Art direction graphics 9/10 Nice setup and although repetitive like similar to dungeon crawlers map, every stage was designed perfectly with the setting. 

Sound 9/10 Voice qualities and interpretations are good. Background music are on point. But noteworthy ones are quite limited.

Gameplay 10/10 The loop is fun and really engaging. Love how fast pace is the battle. The randomness of perks makes it strategic somehow to keep your toes always eager. Probably a skill game. Plus for npc relations, upgrades and difficulty adjustments to achieve and unlock more contents.

Story 8/10 Even though the contents are detailed. It is up for players to read the lore and somehow tie it to the main story and the world. The main plot was simple yet the extra world building details rounds the whole setting to make it interesting. 

Value 10/10 Got this on sale. Worth the money. Nothing more to say about it that a rare treasure waiting to be opened.

Hades is an infernally addictive game that plunges you into the thrilling world of Greek mythology. 

It's an exceptional gaming masterpiece, offering a captivating story, intense action, and dynamic rogue-like game-play. With striking visuals, an immersive soundtrack, and well-crafted characters, it creates an unforgettable journey through Greek mythology. While the steep difficulty curve and repetitive environments may pose challenges, the game's replay value make it a must-play for fans of action-packed adventures.

After getting all the achievements, trophies, and a full codex, I feel like there's still 100 hours of game-play to go. That is how much of effort and content these developers put into this. This is a must-play for every Steam Deck owner.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]

[*][b]Engaging Characters:[/b] Diverse cast with heartfelt stories adds depth and emotional investment. Rich lore and intriguing characters create an engaging narrative.

[*][b]Dynamic Rogue-like Game-play:[/b] Unique escape attempts with procedural generation and upgrades.

[*][b]Strong Replay Value:[/b] Unlockables, branching story-lines, and persistent upgrades.

[*][b]Well-Crafted Characters:[/b] Stellar voice acting and multi-dimensional personalities.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]

[*][b]Steep Difficulty Curve:[/b] Challenging, especially for newcomers to the rogue-like genre [tip: Use God Mode if you need to].

[*][b]Repetitive Environments:[/b] Similar layouts and enemies can feel monotonous after a 100 hours.
[/list]

[i]Highly recommended. 10/10[/i]

Personally I find the roguelite genre being very entertaining for three main reasons: replayability, adrenalin driven gameplay and "easy to understand, hard to master" game mechanics. All these elements should be enriched by a sense of story progression and empathy with the main character. 

Hades, as a roguelite game, excels in all those aspects.

The gameplay is perfectly designed. The RNG mechanics are fun and well implemented. The overall atmosphere is gorgeous. You will be hooked on the neverending loop of diying/respawning for a pretty long time. 

Since the game is now out of early access and I've pretty much unlocked/ finished everything the final release has to offer, I have a better overview of the full experience. Ultimately I can say that the game feels complete now, it has a proper story ending and even some endgame content.

The roguelite mechanics are very satisfying. The sense of progression is huge and it's not only related to the stats and weapons you will pemanently unlock, but also to the knowledge and skill you will build up as a player. Basically the game provides 4 RPG core groups (this is a simplification of course): 

1) You have a skill-tree (called Mirror of Night) which can be uprgraded permanently, with different skills you can select for each run according to the build you want to create.  
2) There are 6 different Infernal Arms, each one with 3 different variations (the total number of weapons is actually 18). Before every run (escape attempt) you have to choose one of these, considering that every weapon will differ a lot and will consitute the base of your build, changing drastically the gameplay. Infernal Arms can be upgraded permanently as well. 
3) The RNG mechanics: materials farming and a huge run-dedicated skills spawning system. During each run you will have the opportunity to power up the character with various skills (Gods Boons) which will enhance your stats, your weapons, abilities ecc. 
4) Keepsakes and companions. These are various items you can equip during your adventures, which will grant some benefits and additional skills buffs.

There are 4 main biomes you have to pass through in order to reach the final boss, each one with a set of dedicated enemies and bosses. Finishing a run succesfully will take approx between 15 to 30 mins accordingly to the difficulty level (you can increase the difficulty of the game in order to keep farming materials) and the playstyle. 

In my opinion the story is OKish, but the devs have done a great job in giving all the characters different cool personalities and well written dedicated dialogues. The musics and the artworks are simply amazing. 

Do I recommend the game? HADES YEAHHH

Hades is indisputably the valedictorian of the roguelike genre, more so, the culmination of Supergiants antecedent paragons amalgamated to contrive a quintessential zenith of entertainment. The game roots itself acutely within Greek mythology, sharing the ballad of Hades' son Zagreus. Little was written in Greek mythology of Zagreus since the Greek myth writers feared the manifestation of Hades himself, which emanated into a fear of chronicling the ones close to Hades. This lack of annals molds Zagreus into the perfect protagonist, allowing Supergiant to craft their own primordial anecdote. Hades gushes red with an alluring 2d art style that comes from Supergiant games iteratively ameliorating all of their games art styles into this chef-d'oeuvre. Amazingly, Hades has implemented a dialogue system making triple a development studios lick their chops in astonishment, knowing that npc’s can be so much more than verbal contracts with exclamation points above their heads. Do yourself a favor and support this company because I truly feel that everyone will find something they love with this masterpiece!

[h1]Overall Impressions[/h1]
Reviewed after 100%. What can I say that hasn't already been said about Hades? This is truly a modern classic and pushes the rogue-lite genre in new directions all the while retaining Supergiant Games' renown coating of polish.

[h1]What I Liked[/h1]
This game is a masterclass in game design. From the art direction to the lovingly crafted (Thousands!) of lines of dialogue. I am not even joking when I say that I was still hearing new voiced dialogue in my interactions after well over 100 hours. The whole experience is brimming with charm, and comes wrapped in a package that you rarely see from AAA studios.  

The game-play loop may seem difficult at first, but it's in place to teach you the mechanics. Once you've mastered the boon system, you'll be saying "just one more run" in order to try a new combo you may have thought of..

[h1]What Could Be Improved[/h1]
There really isn't a whole lot I would change about this game. Even after 120+ hours in, I was still captivated. My only real gripe is after so much playtime, the 3 basic environments can get a little stale. If there is one thing I could request for Hades 2, I would hope there is more environment variety.

[h1]Final Thoughts & Rating[/h1]
If you like rogue-lite style games and have somehow missed this one, do yourself a favor and play it immediately. I'd probably put this in my top 10 games of all time category. 

[h2]★★★★★[/h2]
Undoubtedly, this game is one of the best games of this decade, play it and wait for the second version

First things first i have not yet finished the 100% of the game. Let my opinion move from this way knowing this factor.

I have been playing this game since the early access (127 hour'ish on it)
The pros of the game are for sure the storytelling, gameplay and soundtrack.
Why these 3 specifically?
Characters lore and the voice acting is literally what baited me to buy the game in EA, otherwise i would have waited for the full release.
There is NEVER an identical run and the meta progression makes sure to make so (Unless you try to force specific builds).
Every zone, npc, character, boss fight has a specific related soundtrack and it's mixed differently for normal, elite and boss fights. If you have played other Supergiant Games u will know how much Darren Korb is good at creating and composing music.

Coming back in 2023 to still say this is a gem. <3

My only con is that the meta progression is a little slow, but for storytelling purposes it's really well structured.

So much so that even though you're meant to clear Tartarus (the name of the games dungeon which you crawl through) each time, I found myself intentionally dying on purpose numerous times solely to experience the games story which it surprisingly also has. Just be sure to speak to each available character after every clear/death as-well as paying close attention to what each god says when you acquire a boon from them to notice it. Aside from that, combat is refreshing with the various weapons you have the choice to choose from and adds a level of complexity to what may be deemed as an "easy game."
What I enjoy the most is the difficulty  It is just hard enough to be fun when you win but doesn't feel unattainable.

So i am conflicted on this game.  On one hand the story is absolutely fantastic, the characters are all done incredibly well and everything feels like it has a place.  On the other hand the grind required especially for the whole story but also if you want to do such things as max out weapons or items.

The characters and the narrative setting is the best that i have ever seen in a rouguelike.  Every character is fleshed out and has a personality that changes over the game.  The setting builds perfectly into the story and even the side quests and characters have personality and depth I have not seen in many other games (Love Bouldy). 

In terms of gameplay it is very fun in the beginning however compared to other rouge likes there is less overall depth to the builds that you can make because you cannot create synergies as well with different abilities and effects.  That is not to say that it is bad gameplay it is still fun however as you play more and more it can become far more repetitive in nature with differences in play style coming predominantly down to the weapon you choose rather than the boons you collect along your run.

In terms of the difficulty scaling that is in the game that you can activate once having beaten it.  Some of it is very fun adding more challenge to runs and creating obstacles where there normally wasn't before however some of the other perks are very annoying and can feel like bashing your head against a wall at times, this is especially true once you stack a lot of the modifiers together later on in your playthrough.

All in all if you want to beat the main story of the game and maybe complete some other minor stuff i would absolutely recommend however if you are looking to go through the whole story including the epilogue i would still recommend just with the warning that the game might become somewhat stale as you play.  If you are looking for a rougelike that will give you tonnes of replay value and be able to loop infinitely i would still recommend Hades but I would say look at Risk of Rain 2 or Binding of Issac first.

wow this far surpassed all my expectations!  Dont let the the initial graphics throw you off, they are actually a very nice style which allows you to focus more on the combat.  Theres an unbelievable amount of spoken text and story which spans through the game, which kept me going, even though I thought I had finished the game around the 50 hours mark. It's been a blast playing this game for the past few months. There's so much love that's been out into this project, and has such attention to detail that I haven't experienced in a while.

There's always something new to explore in the story when you least expect it, and the quality of this content is so good. Building close relations with each of the characters in the story feels very natural throughout the course of the game-play.

The combat is easy to understand, and offers a lot of customization to fit the player's play style. It's pretty button-mashing heavy, but it's addicting nonetheless. 

The visuals are an absolute 10/10.

The only issue I had overall was the achievements. I am going on a achievement collecting spree (at the time of writing this review), and it has a very "have to grind for it" nature. You'll probably never get 100% if you aren't willing to fully immerse yourself in the game and playing like a pro. I'm just trying to do my best, and I currently have 36/49 achievements unlocked.

I definitely recommend people to try this game, if they haven't already. It was a breath of fresh air to me.
