So I played Hades earlier this year, after a couple of runs ( about 50 or so) I managed to beat the final boss and have my first completed run. I enjoyed my playthroughs alot ( even though I sucked most of the time), and honestly thought that was all and stopped there. But later I was told that the first run is just the beginning. Recently though I picked the game back up in hopes of reaching the epilogue and delved deeper into the game and boy have I been missing out.

This game has soo much to offer despite it just being going through the same 3ish levels over and over again. I began experimenting with weapon builds, combining different sorts of boons, exploring the dialogue, working my way towards the "True Ending", using the pact of punishment for extra challenge and more. The replay value is insane here. Also the fact that the flow of combat, weapons and movement is so satisfying just makes it even more enjoyable and strangely addictive.Then there's the aesthetics, the music, top tier voice acting, art direction and sexily drawn people. The writing and storytelling is just excellent. the portrayals of the Greek Gods are  really well done.

This game just hits every nail on the head that makes it a great no dare I say God-like game! Rouge-likes never were my thing but after playing through Hades, I'm more than willing to give it a chance now. This game may not be for everyone but give it a chance who knows? All I can say is that In the name of Hades.. I can definitely recommend this game.

I've been playing this game for 26 hours and am about to face the final boss for the fourth time. I love this game. Probably to a very unhealthy extreme but it's just so addicting. 

The gameplay is great, the characters/writing is brilliant (even when you absolutely hate a character, you'll love them for how loathsome they are) and even when you're losing you're always gaining something, whether it be buffs to upgrade your health, stats etc. or gems to add additional perks like healing chambers is certain areas of the game.

I don't think you need me to convince you to play a game that's a little over 3 years old (almost five if you include how long it was in early access) that everyone, their mum, and their mum's dog have praised to hell (hehe) and back, but in short: I recommend this game.

If you like Roguelikes, you'll probably like it. If you know nothing about Roguelikes, like myself, you'll still probably like it. It's a game that appeals to a lot of people just by virtue of how much love and care was put into it.

I enjoy the rogue like factor as well as the story and artwork. I don't have any dislikes. Just don't make the same mistake as me and not figure out how to aim for the first few hours of playing :P

Every aspect of the gameplay is so intuitive that you will have fun playing the game before you even know what's going on. As if the gameplay wasn't good enough already, the characters are all full of life with engaging dialogues that will keep you emotionally invested, even if you don't care. Personally I never pay attention to the lore, but this one managed to catch my interest as it keeps mixing aspects of the gameplay with the story and the characters, so that you don't have to stop to read stuff if you don't want to (but you can do that too). That's how it should be done, great work. Also, the game is just that well designed with lots of meaningful details everywhere. And goes without saying that the soundtrack is awesome.
This game is perfect. From the artwork, to the soundtrack, to the gameplay. It just scratches an itch in my brain.

I am going to start off with stating that this review that if you want to see a general review of Hades go watch one on Youtube or find another review. I've played through the game and those types of reviews get the general gist of the game. This is a review of the main gripes I notice about the game and things I would change.

Onto the main gripes:
The amount of time that is just sapped away at not playing, it takes 5 seconds to go through a door, it takes two seconds selecting a boon. Alt-tabbing not progressing game time I can understand but needing to watch the same unskippable animation of the character moving for 5 seconds every minute or so is the worst.
The worst in sapping your time is resetting, the game doesn't "reset" if you quit and close, you have to intentionally die which given an upgraded mirror can take a bit.

The amount of time needed to get to a fully gameplay-complete save file is just too much. See above. You will get to a point where you can see what that entails which you then start to factor in how long each run takes and all those unskippable animations sap away on top of the time spent in gameplay is just way too much. Now there is additional cosmetic features that are included in the game that don't affect gameplay that you can grind that can be what takes a long time to complete but that should be the point if you want to continue playing not to the point of getting to a fully gameplay-complete save file.

The boss at the end of the run is not the final boss. It just doesn't feel right that the end boss you encounter isn't the final one that you have to intentionally turn on at the beginning of your run even though they are very similar. I would feel much better if there was an option mid-run to turn it on or if it was an additional objective afterwards rather than feeling like I am missing out on the full experience simply because I didn't turn it on beforehand for that run.

The game is so close to having all gameplay elements explained to you or figured out after some time. Like you will eventually get all the NPC interactions that affect gameplay eventually but you'd never know that turning on the timer heat shuts off certain rooms.

Great art, great voice acting, great and fluid game play. This games reminds you that you don't need to have realistic graphics to make a good game. Even when I escaped the underworld for the first time, I didn't feel like shelving the game just yet. Hades still had so much more exciting content to be discovered and achievements obtained. Kudos to the creators!

The gameplay can feel a bit repetitive at times, especially towards the endgame, where you basically have to complete 100% to unlock the final cutscene. However, what the game considers to be the main story can be done casually without much grinding. They even offer you an option to take less damage, if you want to focus on the story. I completed the main story and looked up the 100% completion on youtube, but even without doing everything the game had to offer, I'd say I got my money's worth from what I did play.

This is one of the best games I've ever played - it's the most polished, slick, well presented video game I've ever experienced.

It's a greek mythology-based hack&slash action roguelite game that's focused on the son of the greek god Hades and his personal growth.

[h1] Which people probably won't like this game [/h1]

[b] If you don't like roguelite games [/b] (dying repeatedly, playing the same sections of the game over and over again, getting stronger with each death, having meta progression that persists between runs etc.) [b] then you'll probably not like Hades. [/b]

It's simple as - the game is repetitive in its gameplay loop, while the things keeping it fresh throughout its run are the story, the unlocks, build variety and weapon variety - the enemies, zones, bosses and general layouts stay basically the same all the time.

If you hate gameplay and theme repetition, you'll probably not like Hades.

[h1] The good [/h1]

If you're a fan of roguelites and their progression, of build variety, of beautiful art and music, of fast paced, reflex-based gameplay, of a fun spin and take on mythology then this game is for you.

[b] No microtransactions, DLC, expansions [/b] - The game is complete.

[b] Gameplay [/b] - Fast paced, dash-based, reaction-based action gameplay with a variety of weapons. It's fast, it's pretty and it's fun - readability is good, the enemy telegraphs are good, the bosses are amazing - it's mechanically perfect and it does exactly what it wants to. There are some very, very rare attacks that aren't perfect animation/design-wise, but considering how the HP economy works, the learning process of expecting those attacks isn't that annoying really.

[b] Music [/b] - It's great, it fits the theme, there's unlockable tracks in game (in-game currency only), it's even tied to a character in the story.

[b] Sound design [/b] - No complaints here - the sounds are meaty, the enemies sound nice, voice acting is perfect (not one voice line out of many of them is even close to being mediocre, let alone being bad).

[b] Story and characters [/b] - I don't usually play games for the story (barring a few exceptions like Yakuza for example), but the story really is inherently connected to the gameplay and the whole dying repeatedly thing this game like so much because it's a roguelite and it's a nice story, engaging till the end because of the well-written characters.

[b] Surrounding systems [/b] - As you play more and more you unlock more and more systems that help you get further and further - some of them are passive systems akin to permanent buffs, others are more engaging and require managing limited use items (per run).

[b] Graphics [/b] - The game is absolutely beautiful from beginning to end, including UI, the player hub, character portraits, enemy and friendly character models, spell effects, different god powers etc.

[b] Difficulty [/b] - There's a really, really nice difficulty selection and customization screen unlocked later on that allows players to fine-tune their game exactly how they want to (for example giving enemies bonus affixes ala ARPGs like Diablo or forcing themselves to give up bonuses that make up their build every once in a while or even just giving bosses more moves and phases etc.).

[b] Controls, optimization and UI design [/b] - The game is smooth, the gameplay is smooth, the UI is not cluttered and it's not minimalist to the point of being useless, the menus are clear, the game's mechanics are beautifully explained. It's a really intuitive game to get into.

[h1] The bad/mediocre [/h1]

So I've already said that the game is repetitive, but this isn't a bad thing for everyone - I personally don't mind it and it's obvious why repetition is necessary with a game like this and a story like this.

Another thing people might not like (but, again, this is more of a consequence of not liking roguelites in general) is the game basically forcing you to die to progress - theoretically it's possible for a first time player to just never die, but realistically the game needs some knowledge that gets accumulated through multiple runs (which is in sync with the story and is required for the story to actually advance, so it makes sense).
I personally can't lose a run of the game anymore (unless I'm going for ridiculously high difficulties sometimes for fun), so the game does reward pure skill.

Other than that... Uhm... Some weapons become somewhat useless at higher difficulty levels... I guess...

Yeah that's that, can't think of any other con.

If you suck at this game (like I do) it gets frustrating and annoyingly grindy very soon.
Too tanky enemies, too long runs with too little meta-progression.
That is, unless you find the process of bashing enemies fun by itself.

While it's not hard to memorize attack patterns and dodge, the enemies have a lot of HP, so you have to repeat same pattern again and again. 
Hit hit hit dash. Hit hit hit dash. Hit hit hit - one armored lout is down, four more to go.

You can levelup between runs, but per-run rewards are small and most of the options increase your survivability, not the DPS.

What's especially frustrating is that it is [i]borderline[/i] enjoyable - I like the story, characters, graphics, and (in theory) overall gameplay loop.
Maybe I would've enjoyed this game more, if simply all damage (even damage you receive) and rewards would be scaled 2x-3x-4x.
But as it is now... I just can't bring myself to start another 30+ minute run of dash-dash-dash around each enemy while my attacks barely scrape them.

...If only "God mode" reduced enemy HP instead...

First, let me be up front and say: I don't like roguelikes. I also spent over 80 hours on this game, so let me go more in-depth.
Supergiant Games is a studio I trust to have high-quality game design. I've played Bastion and I have Pyre in my game list to play through shortly. I was hesitant to play Hades, as I'm not really a fan of roguelikes (I earned three Boss Souls in Dead Cells before I gave up) even though I do enjoy some hard games. But the setting was intriguing and the art style, as always, was great.
Cue to me actually playing it.
The parts of the roguelike that make it a roguelike got to me. The difficulty and repetition (ESPECIALLY in Elysium) was disheartening to work through. Though the entire process was smooth and easy to manage actually playing the game was frustrating and difficult. I ended up turning on God Mode, with a 44% reduction in damage overall. From there, the game was much more enjoyable.
I didn't 100% the game. I progressed through most relationship tracks and I found the epilogue, but beating the game entirely leaves me feeling numb. It's a great game, don't get me wrong, but I like a game with a defined ending. Roguelikes like Vampire Survivors I tend to need some other certain something to keep me going, in most cases listening to podcasts while I played, and unfortunately the music and sound design in Hades is far too good to play on mute.
So, all in all: the game won me over to at least finish it by having top-tier design and direction every step of the way. If you're even a little amenable to roguelikes I would recommend this game. But if you don't like roguelikes at all, this game will have all the hallmarks of the genre that make it a tough ask, in which case I'd either recommend God Mode, or just watching a playthrough on YouTube.

dating sim disguised as the best rougelike ever made

The game is awesome, but they sprinkled crack on top of it. 

Quality across the board in almost every aspect. In modern day, apparently almost no shining gem escapes the fate of adding mindless grinds to pad content. Most things in Hades are high quality at worst. Combat, voice acting, character development/writing (especially for this genre), art, music... it's all high quality. It's been a long time since I had as much fun in fights as I regularly did here. Upgrades are varied enough, bosses change abilities between runs. Really all of the actual gameplay rocks. I mean all that genuinely, so don't be thrown off by the below. 

Despite Hades' general awesomeness, all big hits apparently need a slow-drip dopamine IV system. The game is an utter grind, forcing you to repeat the same stuff an insane amount of times to not only get upgrades and progress, but see the game's ending. This clogs up the game every step of the way with countless currencies, and many other facets for endless repetition disguised as content. 

You have to beat this at least 9 times to see the actual ending. This feels really exploitative just like the forced grind related to currencies and other unlocks. How is it an enjoyable design feature to constantly give you the choice of "pick crappy upgrade to get further through the grind, or pick actual useful upgrade that increases chance of winning"? The story is well told, yet you have to keep beating the whole game to get a few lines about the actual story - repeat for a couple more. The storytelling could have been done in far less playthroughs and felt better instead of like I'm getting one bite of a cookie a day.

Ridiculous grinds disguised as content are a growing poison to gaming and I'm getting really fed up with it. Still the rest of the game is damn good so I just let it waste my time and pretend it's fine. Addictive substances do sell well, eh.

Masterfully made game; couldn't escape the poison of dopamine drip content padding.

Masterpiece. I finally took the time to fully complete this game after having started it when it first came out, and I am so glad I did. 

One of the best things about the game is that it manages to have a story in a way that no roguelike before has had. I found myself actually caring about the characters and their storylines. The voice acting is top notch, each character's personality coming through wonderfully. It is also incredible that after 65 runs, I don't think I've heard any character repeat a line. Even if I have, it is amazing that there is such variety that I can't remember it. The writing is just so good. It manages both humor and heartfelt moments to such a high degree of quality.

The gameplay is also some of the best I've seen in a roguelike. Even near the end of my playthrough, 65 runs in, I still enjoyed each one because the combat is so satisfying. Each run I could try a new weapon, a new aspect, a new trinket, or a new build with my boons. The variety on offer here is endless. The fact that I was never bored despite all my grinding for resources speaks to how fun and varied this game is.

The heat system is a brilliant way to introduce difficulty. It is great that you can slowly add more heat to your runs to get used to new challenges and modifiers, and it is just another way the game introduces variety.

I'm just happy I finally completed this game. Yet I still have things to see. I cannot wait for the sequel to arrive and hopefully somehow improve on a game that is already so good.

Game is highly reliant on RNG to the point it can make or break you. It's just button mashing and if you have enough luck, you can make it.

The actual game is incredibly short. It's just elongated by having an enormous grind attached to it. Literally had a perfect run that took less than 30 mins... that's how short the game is content wise.

The progression within the game is nonsensical and monotonous with no feeling of reward once you've spent literal hours to earn something. What you can actively make choices on to benefit your character results in a few % points increase if that for something that took ages to grind for. You gain resources to upgrade weapons from 1 boss, but have to kill the boss on the next tier to be able to upgrade the weapons. You are finally able to unlock certain items AFTER you have killed the last boss which doesn't make sense for a game about progression. 

The game promotes being very quick since you end up dying a lot to progress. Yet, there are times where there are valuable chests and urns with money dotted around that are highly useful to your run along with fishing. But in turn, you have to pause to look around for them. It completely breaks the pace of the game, especially when you see one mid fight and forget about it.

Due to the fast nature of the game, i gave up listening/reading dialogue that was often slight variations of what was said before.

Unless you enjoy brainless button mashing and gambling, I don't recommend this game.

The glory of HADES has begun in 2020, although they lost out to "The Last of Us Part ll" in the two top awards of the Golden Rocker Awards and TGA, and missed the best game award. At the time of the release of the'early access" version of HADES, Super Giant Studios is an independentgame developer that has just been established for a decade, and has anumber of acclaimed works, and HADES can be said to be theirmasterpiece.

The fast-paced action of Bastion

The rich atmosphere and depth of Transisto

Pyre uses character-driven storytelling

Together, they created a Greek mythology of greater freedom and freerfighting. They recreate the subtle relationships between the gods of theunderworld and the antagonism of the gods of Olympus, which, inCasavin's own words, "allows the player to observe his own dysfunctionafamily." Then, from the unique perspective of Zaglios, the "Hades escapeprince", it interprets a unique, sacred but comedic "family farce". Becauseof the intricacies of Greek mythology, Kasavin and his team designed morethan 10 hours of NPC branch dialogue to skillfully present the volatilerelationships between gods and heroes (including the problem of multipleorientations) without changing the general direction. Each of the player'sdifferent choices is followed by a non-linear, ever-changing story andjourney;..xxxxX

Working with art director Jen Zee to incorporate ancient Greek art into thecharacter setting, the game's innovative re-interpretation of Greekmythology is the most praised by several media outlets, including IGN andDestructoid. In addition to its unique story and gameplay, HADES is animportant symbol of the new shape of game development and marketinoin the online age.

Man, what a game! It gives me hope for future releases by indie developers.

It's an incredible take on the rogue-like skill-based dungeon-crawling games. This one has story that requires you to die several times for you to slowly progress it. It's really masterful. It keeps you coming back, wanting to do your best gathering resources during your outings to be rewarded with new little pieces of fully voiced dialogue, and all VA did a stupendous job!

The weapons give you a ton of variety, as do builds, compensating for you using the same guy during your probably hundreds of outings when you're done with the game. I love the little nods they give to the Greek mythology they're based on, like the little jokes Zagreus plays on Orpheus about a certain connection to another god. There is tons of character developing while still making sense while your quest has to be never ending, regardless, and if you want to go to the deep end, it'll be a while before you have the currencies to fully pimp out your house and get all the cool knickknacks and useful accessories.

It's just such a blast to decide what your next run is going to be like, and it's always a little bit harder, but just a tiny, little bit in a way you can decide. I'm not kidding. The most challenging the game can possibly be is basically impossible even if you were among the best players in the world; you'd need hundreds of attempts for everything to go absolutely right for you to stand a chance.

Back in the day, I would have reccomended this to anyone, and I did. Now, though? It's harder to with better roguelikes now existing.

First off, the game plays well, and if you just want to play it, try the weapons, and experience the dialogue, maybe use the nectar/ambrosia to get some more, have some nice runs but not try to win, unlocking as much as you want, go for it, that's honestly the highlight of this game for most people.

Anything more than that, though, and RNG, required difficulty modifiers and the last level and boss rear their ugly heads.

To get the basic ending of the game (the one that gives you the credits but not the "real" ending), you need to beat the final boss 10 times and then win one time after (with new modifiers that you set before the run each time if you use the same weapon, so 6 free wins and 4 you have to do with some modifier if you CAN manage to win with each weapon), and then for the canon "secret" real ending after that, you need to progress all the athenean god's relation meters with farmed Nectar/Ambrosia and then visit them each once after to get the real, definitive end of the story.

The problem is getting there, though. Rng will give you gods that aren't just Ares (pure damage) and Athena (Bullet deflection and mitigation), and the last level is literally designed to chip away gradually at your health and revives, and you CANNOT get it all back before the final fight because the shop costs are too high by then. Thus a lot of runs will be failed just because you died too much earlier or took too much damage in the last level, boons and performance beforehand not really mattering too much (if you got enough gold on the way to heal and get your revives back, that is) because the final boss projectile spams and will likely kill you at least twice, so you need at least 2 revives AND enough damage to actually kill him before you run out of hp.

This being said, Hades 2 is in production and that last area issue could be fixed in it, so. Maybe give this a try if you wanna just play it for awhile, but, honestly, just look up the real and secret endings, don't try to get them unless you really, really want to.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

If you are into action roguelikes or Greek mythology, Hades will be your favorite go-to game. Help Zagreus escape the Underworld and discover what a bird even means (he doesn't know.)

[h1]Full Review[/h1]

Let me start from afar. Video games as a medium are a way to escape unpleasant or uneventful everyday life. That is escapism, a necessary psychological device to divert thoughts from sadness, loss, or boredom. You can see it in every type of entertainment, not merely video games. Likewise, roguelikes have deep roots in literal 'escape' concerning their narrative (the hero always tries to escape a dungeon or labyrinth or even their fate). We might call it double escapism. At the same time, stories in most roguelikes only distantly resemble real-life situations. That is where Supergiant makes a difference. They not only create an addictive game with exceptional style and music, but they also tell a deeply allegorical coming-of-age story. You know, the type of story every one of us might live through at some point because there are no ideal families or relationships. It returns us from the whimsical world (should I say Underworld?) to our everyday life with new feelings, thoughts, and a desire to sort everything through. That is the highest praise I could imagine for an entertainment medium.

Hades follows the story of a young godling Zagreus, or Zag for short, and his relationship with his tyrant father, Hades, the god of the Underworld himself. Hades (the god) demands from his son, whom he scornfully calls 'boy,' to be responsible, respectful, and obedient like a servant. At the same time, he is reluctant to show some love or appreciation toward anyone in the House. For Zag, there is only one way to deal with the situation: running away to relatives on Olympus. The problem is that no one can escape the Underworld, even a godling! And so we start our desperate journey as Zag, trying to leave the domain of the dead in search of a better fate. The story goes deep; its narration threads through many dialogs with different characters, intertwined between escape attempts into one whole piece. Slowly, the perspective shifts: the initial father-son conflict reveals underlying problems and broader themes. My favorite includes exercising honesty and outspokenness and why it is not always the best course of action in a manifold family to tell everything head-on. I love Greek mythology and Ancient Greek literature, and I must admit the level of detail is brilliant. There are many myths from different sources; Supergiant mindfully chooses its interpretations for a consistent story. It is worth noting that they had a certain degree of freedom regarding the protagonist and his relations with everyone due to his minor significance in Greek mythology. Even there, though, in late interactions with Dionysus, we can learn about [spoiler]how the Orphic Dionysus Zagreus tradition has an internal explanation.[/spoiler] So, yeah, the immersion in the theme is brilliant. I mean it!

Gameplay-wise, Hades is as addictive as a perfect roguelike should be. You rely on your wit, reaction (sometimes even sense of rhythm), and luck to fight through the ever-changing environment with hundreds of possible adjustments to strategy and tactics. I could play games like Crypt of the NecroDancer or Dicey Dungeons in short sessions, but Hades? Nope. I play it, and play it, and play it. Again and again. It is so very addictive! Different weapons, boons, power-ups, and combinations result in some weird and powerful twists to efficient tactics, which is an example of RNG done right. If you die, you can start again a bit stronger (if you gather enough Darkness, that is) through the process amusingly called Reflecting. [spoiler]This technicality, by the way, means the game belongs to the roguelite subgenre.[/spoiler] Core mechanics might seem harsh, but mastering them requires only time. Just play some more, and you will naturally overcome the obstacle. Despite this 'intentional replayability,' it starts to feel repetitive only when you finish the main story. At that point, the only way of raising the challenge is through the customizable Pact of Punishment, a plot device to make your post-story runs harder.

As always with Supergiant, the voice acting and music are exceptional. Beautiful melodies combined with heavier riffs and reverberations greatly suit the game's style and story. And when Orpheus (Darren Korb, the composer) and Eurydice (Ashley Barrett) start singing, their verses seem out of this world. It is not a simple task to assume the roles of the legendary musician and his partner/muse. Somehow, Darren and Ashley pull it out so smoothly! I had tears and goosebumps listening to In the Blood during credits. Magnificent!

Lastly, I want to briefly mention the Fated List of Minor Prophecies and the detailed statistics menu in the Administrative Chamber. It all adds depth to the choice-making during escape attempts. Nuances like those contribute to the entire thing, making it much more enjoyable. And, well, there is also fishing. Because why not?

Let's start with the basics, what is Hades? Hades is a rogue lite first and foremost. However, what makes Hades different from the other rogue lite games on the market is its narrative and its amount of dialogues which are driven by the game's cycle.

In Hades, death isn't death. If Zagreus dies, he returns to his father but Zagreus is never defeated and that is part of the beauty of Hades as a game. Your character dies and when you get back home, you'll have new dialogues corresponding to what happened in your last run. Then, you'll have some characters helping you and some will even complaint about you defeating them in your attempt to escape. These dialogues and the intricate personalities of the characters makes it incredibly immersive as you'll feel like your previous attempt at escaping the hells (Because yes that is what the game loop is about find out more by playing) feel like they mattered.

When it comes to its progression system, you'll have the opportunity to unlock new passives which will make escape attempts a lot easier. Eventually you'll gain items from characters and by equipping one of them, you'll be able to shape what type of game play you want to go for. That is, do you want to tank the living hell out of every hell's layers or will you make this a full on glass cannon and show off your bullet hell skills? Which brings us to the next point, you'll get to pick weapons which each have specific bonuses in their game play and different boons, some reward timings, some reward dexterity and other rewards being tanky. Eventually you'll even get to upgrade them, gaining extra useful perks by doing so.

In the end, you'll notice that the achievement to escape the hells is pretty common amongst the player base, that is because Hades doesn't end when you think it will. For the sheer reason that I won't get into any spoilers, you'll have to discover that one out for yourself.

Overall, Hades is an incredibly fun rogue lite which nails its core rogue lite mechanics and spices its gameplay up with its game changing narrative. If you're into rogue lite games, you should most definitely give Hades a shot.

If you're struck with a bit of nostalgia when you think about your Dad belittling you and making snarky comments; read no more and just buy the game.

Hades is one of those games where you start out about as strong as a piece of wet tissue, die a LOT, and get a bit stronger each run. Think Vampire Survivors. Combat is not like Vampire Survivors though, as you have full control of the main character.

Great music and art style.

You have to talk to a lot of people, and several stories unfold concurrently during your runs through the stages. Think Soap Opera.

You slowly unlock different weapons, each unique and fun to play. Some make finishing a run easier, while finishing a run with others isn't so easy. Different boons (status effects) are more suited to certain weapons.

I'm not personally much for these types of games where you run through the same content over and over, mixing and matching status effects, and intentionally bumping up the difficulty to see just how much pain you can endure. However, it appears Hades has a cult following. You're sure to enjoy the game whether you buy it on sale or at full price.

As a huge fan of roguelikes and roguelites I knew I would love this game, but this, in my opinion is the epitome of the genre. Considering the games we used to see in this genre there weren't many examples of games that would cover all of the following aspects: amazing gameplay loop, a decent story/narrative and good soundtracks; usually the one that was lacking was the story, but hades takes all of the above to a whole new level, Supergiant managed to make a complex way of storytelling by using the mechanic of dying over and over again and restarting from the beginning that's present in roguelikes and roguelites and also having so many lines of dialogue that it might as well never feel repetitive... and don't get me started about the soundtrack. 
I can't really rate Hades, for me, it's my favorite game ever and I really can't wait for the second game, for anyone that has doubts about the game, take a leap of faith, even if you're not into roguelikes, this might be the one that will make you change your opinion.

10/10 for this hack-and-slash game. Numerous parts of this game deserve compliments, particularly its literature. I understand that not many people would love reading in kind of game due to their literacy, preferences, and a notion that dialogues in many action games are normally designed slovenly and are usually negligent to convey their stories. However, one can clearly see that the dialogue in this game are very well-designed. 

I have played so many types of games in the categories of Soulslike, Roguelike, or Roguelite, and can confidently say that even though this game claimed itself as in those types, it is still not that difficult. Therefore, please don't be afraid of trying it. Ofc, the game is challenging but you will eventually figure it out that when you die in this game, it is typically your fault (sometimes you may perhaps neglect to pay attention), not that the movements and skills of monsters are too complex. 

As I said, the game is very easy and simple comparing to the others in the same categories. In the event that you are new to these types of game, this is a very good first step for you to try out. The game is repetitive but worth to spend your time with.
